PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9 a.m., and—by leave—read prayers.
Consideration resumed.
Clauses 46 to 49.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume clause 46 implies that it covers the entire field. I would like to ask the minister whether, indeed, it does and whether that would basically overrule any decision made at the state level?

—Compensation under the Commonwealth act is pursued by this process. If compensation is being pursued under a state act which is made consistently with this legislation, but as a separate legislative exercise, compensation would be pursued under the specific statutory provisions of that state legislation.

—I have a comment and question on clause 47. During the course of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, a submission was received from the New South Wales government in relation to clause 47. Concern was expressed by the government that the meaning of `acts that are essentially the same' was uncertain. The New South Wales government said that it is not clear what is meant by `acts which are essentially the same'. It may mean acts of essentially the same class or of the same nature, both in effect and time. For example, renewal of a mining lease will be an act of essentially the same class as the original lease. Does clause 47 mean that compensation is paid only for the original lease? Alternatively, the renewal is not essentially the same because it affects native title at a different time to the original lease, even though its terms may be the same.

PARA.TAB: The New South Wales government was saying that it could see the purpose of this clause to avoid double-dipping with compensation but, of course, `acts which are essentially the same' does not really cover it. I wondered what the government had in mind in relation to that phrase, bearing in mind the comments from the New South Wales government?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already debated this clause, including that particular question. If the honourable senator can hold on for a moment, I will remind myself what the answer is. Acts that are essentially the same, for example, in the context of a statutory grant of a mining lease under some special provision of the kind that exists in Western Australia would be, I guess, the passage of the legislation creating the framework for the grant of the interest in question, then the actual grant of the interest and perhaps some further action taken pursuant to the practical on the ground implementation of the development pursuant to that grant of interest.

PARA.TAB: That would be an example of acts that are essentially the same. An example of acts that would not be essentially the same would, I suppose, be an exploration permit granting act on the one hand as compared with a mining grant act on the other. In other words, these are two kinds of acts of inherently quite different impact on the Aboriginal land in question and thus giving rise to different sorts of considerations about their compatibility with the enjoyment of the native title in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 49, subclause (2), and I note there that it talks of acquisition under compulsory acquisition act. It appears to me that that definition, compulsory acquisition act, might not be covered in state legislation dealing with public works and that it may well mean that the states have to amend their legislation accordingly to fit in with this definition. I just wondered whether there had been any liaison with the states in relation to this aspect.
—I am advised that there has been discussion with the states and some of them will have to amend in order to achieve this result.

—Can I just ask which states, and there is a query as to how extensive the amendments will need to be, because this touches again on the Commonwealth-state relationship in terms of what effect this bill is having on state domestic legislation. If one is going to say it is an undue interference by the Commonwealth, part of the argument would be the extent to which the state has to bring in resulting legislation as a result of this bill.

—I am advised that discussions on this matter have taken place with all states and that they do understand the nature of the legislative amendments that may be necessary. They are essentially small in number and scale. They relate to things like the provision of just terms, for example, in legislative context where that kind of provision is presently lacking. It is not a major legislative exercise that is contemplated at the state level in this respect.

—With respect to clause 49 generally, and I suppose the compensation provisions here, and I am looking at the heading `Criteria for determining compensation' on page 27 of the bill, a question which has been put to me on several occasions is: how does one actually place a monetary value on native title which does not really know, or hitherto has not known, any place in our legal system, in our land system? What sorts of aspects does one look to to put a dollar value on it? I could understand how one might provide land in satisfaction of a claim, and it would be somewhat difficult to assess how even the assessment of services equates with the loss of the land. What research has been done in relation to this, and can the minister give us any idea as to guidelines that would be used? Is it simply going to be a dollar per acre, or what?

—This is obviously a matter that has to be left to the tribunals and the courts to determine. There is no further guidance in the legislation other than the provision in 49(1) to which Senator Ellison refers. It will be a matter of case by case determination and presumably the evolution of a body of relevant principles governing this as a result of that common law type, case by case determination. The courts and tribunals are entirely familiar, generally, with dealing with calculations of quantum of loss, diminution, impairment and so on. These are not unusual concepts, although they are being here applied in a new context.

PARA.TAB: It is quite impossible to give any further answer than that, because it will depend on so many variables: the calculation of the precise extent of the native title in question—whether it is a hunting and gathering kind of title or whether it is more in the nature of freehold. It will depend on a whole variety of considerations that will be before the tribunal. While everyone acknowledges that that is an uncertain process, given that we are talking here essentially about compensation payable by governments rather than by private commercial interests, it is manageable that it should be thus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister himself has just expressed some guidelines by saying that it depends on the nature of the title, whether it is hunting and gathering and so on. But why not set down some guidelines for the assessment of this, because at the moment it seems that what we are going to start with is a completely blank sheet? There is going to be no guideline for this tribunal to kick off with, so to speak, and that to me just has the potential for challenges and appeals. Why does the government not start off by giving them at least some of the most basic criteria to go by?

PARA.TAB: I think that what the minister said was good but I cannot find in the bill where it says how the question of compensation is looked at—whether it is a hunting and gathering situation or whether it is a freehold situation. There is a whole range of situations from hunting and gathering right through to the Murray Islanders who were cultivators and had their own sort of land system. Why not put that in the bill as a starting point and at least give the tribunal something to work with from day one when it starts sitting to hear these claims rather than just make it up as it goes along, although I am not suggesting that that will be the case in a derogatory sense?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it would be particularly possible to do better than the courts are capable of doing themselves in this situation. There is no particular magic about what I said about depending on the different kind of native title. That is implicit from the way that 49(1) is drafted, when it talks in terms of compensation for any loss et cetera or other effect of the act on their native title rights and interests. What the native title rights and interests are, the character of them, the extent of them and the scale of them have to be identified in order to begin to calculate what loss or diminution or impairment might be involved. I think it is a pretty self-evident kind of process in terms of the issues that have got to be taken into account. But how those different factors are actually quantified really is best left, we believe, to the tribunals and the courts to work out. I do not think we can do a better job than they could do. And for that reason it is left up to them.

—I have a brief comment to place on the record. I feel that the role of the legislature is to make the law and in that law set down quite clearly how the law is to be implemented. It is also to provide guidelines for the courts which then interpret the law. Oliver Wendell Holmes was asked on his way to court whether he was on his way to do justice, to which he replied that he was not; he was just going to administer the law. There is a big difference, of course, but the role of the courts is really to administer the law.

PARA.TAB: There is a problem here in that there is insufficient detail to set up this totally innovative scheme because what will happen is that not only might the one side be aggrieved by the decisions but another side as well. The native titleholders could be saying that they think there is inconsistency in the tribunals' approach because they gave a ruling for one clan but they did not do it for another. There is a lack of consistency, therefore.

Whenever there is a lack of consistency in the law, we have litigation and we have appeals. Primarily what this bill is trying to sort out is a legislative response to the Mabo decision. I place on record that I think this is a real problem. There should have been consultation with Aboriginal groups and people with expertise in the area, to the extent that some guidelines for compensation at least should have been set down so that, on day one, not only the tribunal but any future litigants would know what they were dealing with when talking about compensation. We must remember that there are two separate phases. One is the determination of native title and the other is the determination of compensation.

If I have a personal injuries case, I know what the standards are when I go to court and ask for compensation for a client because there are certain things I look at. It is very easy in our legal system and with our background to have a set formula for economic loss, pain and suffering, payment for bills and disbursements that have occasioned by virtue of the whole mishap of an accident. But in this area it is completely left open, and I really believe that that is a breeding ground for uncertainty and future litigation. So I place on record that I think this legislation is insufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of technical and legal questions have been asked in this committee of the whole debate. It did not surprise me to hear the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) say that there had been discussions with the states, but it did surprise me to hear him say that one of the criteria that may be lacking in the laws of certain states is the criterion on just terms. That came as a little bit of a surprise to me, to be quite frank. I had not realised that. I had assumed that that would be an absolutely essential criterion for compensation.
—Under existing state law?
—Yes.

—We had a referendum about that, as Senator Harradine may recall, which was voted down as a result of a campaign by various unmentionable people. The fact of the matter is that there is no absolute guarantee of just terms being payable under state law, and there are a number of different state statutory acquisition contexts where just terms are not payable but some other formula is identified. It is important to make absolutely sure that these criteria are satisfied. It may, in a number of cases, involve no legislative amendment at all but just a checking exercise, but it is not to be assumed that state law is in accordance with these principles.

—The detailed questioning that is being undertaken now obviously, on reflection, could have been put to various persons, interested groups, public servants and legal people at a committee inquiry. It has been argued that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs did not meet long enough for all of these matters to be canvassed. Maybe, on reflection, that is what should have happened. It should have been given a longer time. The government is intent on getting this bill through the parliament this year. I understand that approach. What I have done is to float the idea with a number of people that, after the third reading has been adopted, as presumably it will be, the joint committee immediately go into operation. I do not mean immediately after Christmas.
—On Boxing Day?
—No. It could be done at—
—It cannot meet on Boxing Day, as that is the Sabbath.

—No, it could be done. There is a provision—I am trying to help—for a joint committee in the legislation. That joint committee is to look at the implementation and operation of the legislation. My proposal is that another paragraph be added to its functions, that it report to both houses not later than a particular day in February, probably late February, on the implications of the implementation and operation of the act, and whether in the light of such implications any amendments should be made to the act to better reflect the spirit and intention of the common law of Australia in respect of native title and to protect the rights and interests of all persons affected by it. That, of course, is based on the preamble of the legislation and does not diverge at all from the spirit of the legislation, but it would post facto, that is, after the bill has been agreed to by both houses, give this joint committee the opportunity of then calling people to give evidence, of questioning witnesses and of putting a number of these very technical questions to the people who might appear before that committee.

PARA.TAB: Under those circumstances, if it were agreed, it would in fact expedite debate in this committee of the whole stage. I am just indicating that that is what is being floated, and the key to it would be that the sections of the bill, other than sections 1 and 2 and the section relating to the establishment of the committee, would not operate until such time as the committee reported and any amendments recommended were debated by the parliament. I do not want a debate on it here because I understand the leaders are looking at the question, and I canvass the matter with the Greens and the Democrats. When the detailed amendment is available, everybody will be able to have a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subclause 49(3) is headed `Acquisitions where similar compensable interest tests satisfied'. Can the Minister spell out roughly how it works in plain terms for me, please?

—Clause 225 at the back of the bill in the definition section spells out the definition of similar compensable interests, but it will need to be recalled that that has been amended in the course of our deliberations to deal in particular with the definition of `onshore'. To the extent that Senator Panizza wants any further detail about the way in which this particular clause operates, I think he can see it for himself in the terms of the legislation, together with the explanatory memorandum. I am not sure what he wants me to do save and except I would stand here and read it out. I know that is a splendid way of filling in time, but I do not think it is a normal part of the legislative process.
—It is in the explanatory memorandum.

—I do not say at all that it is a matter of filling in time; it is a matter of seeking explanation. It is all very well for Senator Collins to say read the memoranda, and I know it was in the newspaper yesterday that the Prime Minister said, `Read the memoranda', that all these are available, but I am afraid they are not available in the memoranda in plain English. I am quite entitled to have explained how that section works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza is absolutely correct, he is entitled to that explanation. As I said, it is actually quite clear in the explanatory memoranda on page 29 in respect of 49(3). What it says in respect of Senator Panizza's inquiry is this:

SPEECH.PARA: If the native title act involves the grant of an interest which can be granted over ordinary title land, such as a mining interest . . .
I am sure that this is a particular concern of Senator Panizza's—
. . . subclause (3) provides that compensation is to be assessed under the same regime as that for the holders of ordinary title. This is the exception to the entitlement to just terms compensation.
That is the explanation of the similar compensable interest phrase in 49(3) that Senator Panizza is seeking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the minister is aware of the act passed by the Queensland parliament in respect of native title. As I understand it, that act provides that, in respect of compensation where a mining lease might be involved, the competent court is the mining wardens court. Will that mining wardens court fit the requirements of this bill?

—As Senator Parer would be aware, the arrangements that have been set in place are that, in consultation with the states, the Commonwealth will assess whether the procedures that are put in place by the states fit the criteria that the Commonwealth is insisting on, in respect of how the mechanics of native title are going to be administered. The answer to Senator Parer's question is in the positive. The Commonwealth would be looking, in negotiation with the state of Queensland, to ensure that the procedures of the mining wardens court would be consistent with the criteria that the Commonwealth is insisting on. It also re-emphasises the fact that, as a matter of policy in relation to land management, the Commonwealth's central position is that it wants the states to continue to administer that.

—The minister said two things there that were apposite. He said that the response to my question was positive. Then he went on to say that he will `assess'. The question is simply this: is the legislation that has been passed by the Queensland parliament—which incorporates the mining wardens court as the vehicle that would be used to establish compensation—acceptable, or is it in doubt?

—I think it is fair to say that the Queensland legislation appears to be broadly consistent with the aims of the Commonwealth, but the actual discussions and decisions that need to be taken by the responsible Commonwealth minister have not yet been taken. As I said before, the entire policy thrust of this legislation is to provide for the unquestionable constitutional position of the Commonwealth in making laws in respect of Aboriginal people and to also, at the same time, sensibly preserve the matter of land management with the states—where it rightly should be. It is a question of finding arrangements in discussions with the states. I have no doubt that such arrangements can sensibly be found to allow the states to manage their land while at the same time being consistent with the criteria for fairly administering the Native Title Act.

—Senator Gareth Evans said that in respect of compensation—I think it was in response to Senator Ellison—this matter should be left to the tribunals and the courts, and that it would be a case by case evaluation which would evolve. With regard to the mining wardens court, there are already established concepts. Those established concepts are such that, where a dispute occurs or where an agreement cannot be reached between the parties—be they graziers or anyone else—the mining warden determines the extent of compensation, based on some financial loss.

PARA.TAB: This is usually done by determining the sale price of properties within the vicinity. It relates, for example, to where a portion is taken from a landowner's property where there is a reduction in the carrying capacity of that property. There are cases of disturbance, for example, where dust gets on the grass and the cattle or sheep cannot eat it for a period of 12 months. So it is a clearly established concept in the mining wardens courts. The problem that I have is how those established concepts can be applied to native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Gareth Evans correctly said, the fundamental establishment of what will become, without doubt, the benchmarks for these kinds of assessments should be sensibly made by the tribunals and the courts that are going to administer this matter. In a general sense, the same kinds of concepts and grounds for assessment that are made and have always been made in mining wardens courts will also apply to native titleholders.

PARA.TAB: However, the reason for the requirement that the Commonwealth has to ensure that those administrative procedures are consistent with the Commonwealth's position is that that whole concept of native title recognised by common law is a new concept established by the High Court of Australia. In a general sense, the tribunals will make those assessments, consistent with the same criteria that they use for titleholders other than native titleholders, with the additional gloss of having to adjust to and to establish new grounds for this additional question of native title rights.

In conclusion, this is not something which is by any means unique to the law. I know of one area of compensation which did not exist 10 years ago. A whole body of precedent has now been established on that. That area of compensation is the valuation of trees. Compensation now often has to be paid in cases where trees have to be removed from properties. An entire body of expertise has been built up over the last decade in assessing the value of things like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And capital gains tax is paid on the compensation.

—Perhaps so, Senator Bishop. That is really where it is at, Senator Parer. These things are going to be administered by experienced people with the proper legal credentials, and so I have no doubt that the tribunals and the court processes will sensibly establish a body of precedent to establish the benchmarks in these compensation cases.

—I have one final question to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). Is the minister saying that what we are going to have now is a tribunal which, in this instance, is the mining wardens court, where there will be established criteria for one group in society and additional criteria for another group in society?
—No, that is not correct. Indeed, that comment is consistent with the pervasive misinformation which the coalition is trying to insist on, and that is that this is in some way divisive legislation.
—Very divisive.
—It is nothing of the sort. It is quite extraordinary to listen to these arguments about racially based legislation.
—Of course it is. It is based on the race power.

—The common law rights of native title people are fundamentally based on the question of inheritance, which is substantially the same underlying principle that governs the ownership of title in land of our own society. That needs to be laid to rest immediately. If honourable senators want a succinct, clear explanation of this, I suggest they refer to Senator Baden Teague's second reading speech in the Hansard where the honourable senator specifically rejected the assertion that this was racially based or divisive legislation and clearly laid out the inheritance principles on which it is based.
—What is the head of power you are using under section 51?

—As I have just said, the constitutional power of the Commonwealth to make laws in respect of Aboriginal people is clear cut. The High Court has found that native title exists as part of the common law of this country. This is not a matter of government policy. It is a matter of a legal judgment of the High Court. In conclusion, the mining wardens courts will apply rules which are largely consistent with their established precedent in terms of assessing compensation for other titleholders, but with the additional measure—which did not exist prior to the High Court's judgment—of common law in native title.

Why can the tribunal—whether it be the mining wardens court in Queensland under the native title act recently passed, or any other tribunal—not have exactly the same criteria in respect of dealing with a grazier, for example, as it would with someone who is a native titleholder? The government criticised us by saying that we were being divisive, and for saying that there was a different law for different people, and that that was not so. The minister has repeated that there are established criteria already in existence and that there will be additional gloss which only applies to one group of people: that is what he said.
—To one group of titleholders, Senator.

—But title is title. There are already established concepts. The difficulty I think we are having with this is for the government to tell us why you can have a particular tribunal, which has been in quite successful operation for many years, having two sets of criteria, depending on whom it is dealing with.

—The consistent line that has been pushed—and, I regret to say, by people relying on the interjections of Senator Bishop—is that somehow this is a strange or unique situation. The criteria used by mining wardens courts are that there are sums payable for disturbance and so on, but then there are additional sums paid for the particular circumstances of the titleholder involved. This is simply a recognition that the particular circumstances of native titleholders may well be different from those of a pastoralist or someone else.

PARA.TAB: The simplest example to use in terms of different compensation payments being used for different situations is that the compensation payable for a broken back would be significantly different from the compensation payable for a broken thumb. The fact is that the criteria do provide discretionary powers to those tribunals, and do allow the tribunals to assess compensation based on the particular circumstances of the titleholder concerned, while recognising that the new concept of native title does not change that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at clause 49(6), concerning requests for non-monetary compensation, it refers to the person claiming to be entitled to the compensation requesting that the whole or part of the compensation should consist of transfer of property. Could Senator Collins give me an indication of the sorts of parameters that might apply on that basis?

—I will give what would be the most common situation. It certainly has occurred in my experience in the Northern Territory on a number of occasions, and has been resolved by agreement. If, for example, the native title rights have been extinguished, it may well be that an agreement can be reached. This is not forced on anyone, but the opportunity is provided by this measure for compensation to be paid in kind. The most obvious compensation that would be paid in kind would be other appropriate land.

PARA.TAB: The commonest example that springs to mind where this was done was in respect of the stock routes question in the Northern Territory. Under the land rights act, the stock routes were made available for claim but were not necessarily the most suitable areas of land for Aboriginal people to use. By a long process of negotiation, what was commonly done in those cases was Aboriginal people agreed to forgo their claims to the stock routes in exchange for a piece of land which was more suitable for both them and the pastoral owner. That is the kind of situation which will be provided for under these provisions.

I have been reminded that the excellent agreement that has been struck between the traditional landowners and Zapopan, the Mount Todd goldmine, is another example of where these arrangements can be made. For example, housing can be provided, training schemes can be provided, and so on. There are commitments to provide scholarships for school kids and so on. There is a whole range of things which an Aboriginal community might in fact greatly prefer to money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another example would be Argyle Diamond Mines with Turkey Creek. But the minister said that—I am rather puzzled here—it was generally by agreement. Please tell me then, if it is generally by agreement, why there are the provisions. I will come to goods and services later because that is a lot easier to deal with, as has already been mentioned. If it is by agreement, can the minister tell me why it is built into the legislation that the court or person or body must consider the request and may, instead of determining the whole or part of the compensation, recommend that the person liable to give the compensation should, within a specified period, transfer the property. So if the minister reckons it is by agreement, why is it built in there that someone may recommend that a person should turn over the property?

—The reason the provision is in the bill is simply to make it explicitly clear that option is available. But I would point out again: it is not enforceable; it is simply an option which the claimants can ask for. The tribunal is obliged by the legislation to consider that request under clause 6 and, having considered it, it may recommend that that kind of non-monetary compensation should be paid, but that is only a recommendation. At the end of the day, the government is in a position not to provide the non-monetary compensation if it does not think that is appropriate. If it does not, it will have to pay monetary compensation.

—I understand that. What worries me is the court or the body can recommend that the person turn over that particular piece of land, but to me the parameters whereby someone might ask for that piece of ground have not been specified at all. I presume if one is in the Kimberleys, for instance, one would look for a piece of ground in the Kimberleys. If I have a station—which I have not got—in the Kimberleys and there is an application for something on that station, the body corporate in that situation may ask for ground or something in return. I am not talking about goods now, because that would be easily dealt with; I am talking about a piece of land that I envisage would be somewhere near. If they said; `Right, I want your backyard in Perth'—
—Ha, ha!
—Do not laugh at it. That is not a laughing matter.
—Why are you laughing?
—I am laughing because the honourable senator is laughing. Worse still, it could be his backyard. What defence would there be? Do I have total defence?
—My backyard is owned by an Aborigine already, my wife.

—If they are talking about my backyard, they might have to deal with the bank; it might be able to defend me. Let us put it this way: can the minister assure me and put it on record that I have total defence against that?
—Dee or Christabel would give up their backyards.
—Of course.

—In the case of my own backyard, it is already owned by four Aboriginal people, my wife and three kids. No-one else's backyard is in any danger. I just reiterate the underlying issue. If honourable senators go back to the Mabo judgment, it made it absolutely and abundantly clear that freehold and leasehold title, apart from those titles where reservations are contained for Aboriginal people, extinguishes native title. So once again it is no good raising the spectre of people's backyards being placed under threat. The bottom line of this—and have a look at the wording of the bill—is that it is simply a recommendation, Senator Panizza. The government at the end of the day can reject it.

—I fully understand that it is a recommendation, just like mining warden decisions are recommendations to the minister—that is the case in Western Australia, anyhow. I fully understand that. Most of those are appealable to the minister, not necessarily in court, but just by negotiation. Things can be turned around. When it was mentioned that native title would have been extinguished, I presume that when another piece of ground is asked for in lieu of that compensation, it has nothing to do with native title, surely.
—That is correct.
—The honourable senator seems to be saying `native title having been extinguished'. They are not looking for something that has got native title on it, is that correct?

—That is correct. There would be no doubt that the sort of circumstance in which this kind of opportunity—and that is what it is—might exist is where a situation is open to be resolved amicably in favour not only of the claimants but also the person against whom the claim is made. I would envisage that there would be many situations in reality on the ground where that will occur. This simply provides the additional flexibility to get a resolution of the issue not just in favour of the Aboriginal claimant but an arrangement which, in a great many cases, will suit other parties that are involved in this. Senator Panizza is quite right, we are not only talking about being able to make available land which is native title land. A piece of land might be available which the Commonwealth, ATSIC, or some other body, can purchase from the owner if the owner is willing to sell.

—I thank the minister for that; the point is that it is a recommendation. The body would be looking for an exchange of land. Forget the minister's backyard or my backyard or the backyards of Senator Chamarette or Senator Margetts—I am sure they would give up theirs.
—You are the one who raised backyards.

—Yes, I raised them because, if anyone happened to have a backyard in Joondalup—which I have not—they are under the hammer. Let us forget that for the moment. If the application or the request was, say, for public open ground, and far removed from there, in one of the coastal towns, it would be a hard decision to make, would it not? I know that public open ground is not owned by an individual, but there could be need for a trade-off.

—With respect, we really are going around the track now for the fourth or fifth time. I do not disagree with the position that Senator Panizza is putting. It does not make any difference what the particular nature of the alternative piece of land might be, whether it is privately owned property or whether it is publicly owned property. The situation is that this option cannot be forced on people. It is purely something which is provided in a positive sense rather than in a negative sense as an alternative means of resolving a situation of potential difficulty. That is where the parties agree—and this would commonly happen—that non-monetary compensation would be more appropriate. The opportunity for that is provided for explicitly in the legislation. I assure Senator Panizza that, in my view, that would be the best result in determining these issues, and certainly in my own experience in the Northern Territory it is often the result.

PARA.TAB: I am not suggesting that these negotiations are always easy. They can be difficult and they can be protracted. But even though the arrangements leading up to those non-monetary agreements might be difficult and protracted and perhaps even bitter at times, once they are put into place, I have found that the fact that an agreement was reached has formed a pretty substantial base for amicable relationships to exist thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is better than having a court impose one.
—I agree absolutely with Senator Panizza. I could not say it better than that. Perhaps we can move on to the next clause.

—I have a brief question on clause 49 which I have been patiently waiting to ask. Senator Ellison and Senator Parer both went through the process of determining the amount of compensation. Bearing in mind that the valuation profession has always been very closely involved particularly with statutory valuations and compensation, I am interested to know whether consultations have taken place with the Australian Valuation Office, the Australian Institute of Valuers or expert valuers in other fields to determine sets of criteria for valuation methods and whether there is envisaged an arbitration method if there is some dispute over the value of the compensation where it relates to the real property value. There are many examples of that already in a range of statutes.

—I think the answer to Senator Campbell's question in respect of those specific bodies is no, but discussions have been held with what I frankly would consider to be the more experienced people, the actual land management people that run the state systems of land administration. One of the real problems in trying to lay this down in advance in legislation—we have the same problem when we are trying to put down specific guidelines or criteria for how these issues are actually going to be determined—is that we are doing this in advance of actually testing what the situation might be. I reiterate that only one of these claims so far has been settled in Australia and that is the Murray Islands claim. It might get us into more trouble than if we did not lay down the criteria in advance because we might find that in a particular situation which could not possibly be anticipated—try as we might—it might complicate rather than help things.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the overriding issue, I think it is inevitable that difficulties will occur with this legislation. I do not think we could have a bill on any matter—whether it be about taxation, native title or anything else—of this complexity and a brand new issue for the parliament to consider without finding some problems with its operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why we should have a committee.

—No, it is not. Let me say, with the greatest respect to Senator Bishop, and in particular with reference to the suggestion that was made this morning, that a committee after the event would probably be far more useful than a committee—
—You are wrong.

—No, in fact, I am right on that issue. I did not realise that Senator Bishop was around when the 1976 land rights act was being reviewed by Mr Justice Toohey in 1983, but I was. It is a fact that that legislation was comprehensively consulted on. In fact, it was a creature originally of the Whitlam Labor government but was subsequently introduced as one of the first legislative measures of the incoming Fraser government.
—We have to be reminded of that.

—That is right. It was not until the matter started to be heard that the judges that were examining these matters, Justice Toohey pre-eminently among them, started to see in the operation of the act the difficulties that arose and ways of making the legislation better. Mr Justice Toohey was given the job of comprehensively reviewing the operation of the lands rights act. It was a completely workable act, but many of the recommendations that Mr Justice Toohey made in that review were accepted by the government and subsequently appeared here as amendments. What I am saying is that there is no question, because this is a new concept we are dealing with—
—This is bad legislation.
—I know that Senator Bishop and her colleagues want to see this legislation destroyed.
—Correct.
—That is correct. Senator Bishop's non-stop interjections this morning about the racially based nature of this make it clear what the base of that opposition is; and that is that anything that is—
—Mr Chairman, on a point of order—
—Likely to benefit Aboriginal people is going to be opposed by these troglodytes—
—Order, Senator Collins! There is a point of order.

—Mr Chairman, I will not have that on the record. That is an absolute fabrication—untrue! I know it is unparliamentary to say it is a lie, but that is the sort of language it deserves. I will not have it on the record. Anybody who read my speech at the second reading stage would know that that is an utterly unfounded accusation. I was merely asking a simple question earlier in the day about the head of power that the government is relying upon in order to bring this legislation before the parliament. How dare Senator Collins bring in an insinuation of that nature! I demand it be withdrawn.
—I am not going to do anything of the sort.
—Order! I did not hear anything said which is unparliamentary or disorderly.
—It was a reflection on me.

—Order, Senator Bishop! I am happy to peruse the Hansard when it is published to see if there was something I missed. If there was something that was so offensive to you that Senator Collins feels inclined to withdraw, he may; but on the basis of what I heard there was nothing unparliamentary. However, as I say, I am happy to have a look at the Hansard afterwards.

—Mr Chairman, if I may, the point of order I was speaking to was that there was an implication by Senator Collins that the basis of my objection to this legislation is that I am opposed to Aboriginal people having justice and equity. I am fully in favour of justice and equity for Aboriginal people. His slight upon me was that I am opposed to them on racial grounds. That is wrong. I said my objection to this legislation is that South Africa is getting rid of apartheid today and we are creating it. That is a perfectly legitimate point, and I will not have that slur on my name.
—Order! I have ruled on the point of order. If you wish to seek to make a personal explanation at a later point, you may. But it is as it is.

—I will continue and just make two points in response to that dreadfully tired and inaccurate comparison with laws in favour of Aboriginal people and apartheid. Nobody could have dealt with that nonsense better than Mr Justice Brennan did in a judgment that he made some years ago, prior to the Mabo legislation, when this same nonsense was being spread about. I have to say that it is an extraordinary argument to put for someone who does not assert that her concern is that this is something in favour of Aboriginal people. Mr Justice Brennan said very correctly, in a judgment he made some years ago when this was a very popular analogy to draw, that the difference between land rights for Aboriginal people and apartheid is the difference between a home and a prison. Nobody could have put it better than that.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on the final point by saying this: the power that Senator Bishop is referring to is unquestionably and unarguably in the province of the Commonwealth government because it was placed there by a democratic vote of the people of Australia in 1967 in what was the most overwhelming yes vote response—unusual in our constitutional victory—in this country's history. The people of Australia overwhelmingly provided the constitutional head of power for this legislation in a referendum in 1967.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are discussing the question of compensation here, would the minister be so kind as to tell us whether or not capital gains tax will be payable on the compensation paid, given the public ruling of the Taxation Commissioner that capital gains tax is payable on compensation paid when a right is surrendered which meets this criteria here?

—This is clearly a matter that will have to be looked at at some stage in the future, but I think the general principle will apply, that is, if this kind of taxation is payable by others then it will also be payable by native titleholders.

—It is on the record that some judges are taking the view that, because capital gains tax has been ruled by the Commissioner of Taxation—not by this Parliament, I will add—as payable on compensation paid when a legal right is surrendered, the amount of capital gains tax that has to be paid is added on to the amount of compensation that is ordered for the surrender of the right. Is there anything within the legislation that either permits such a judgment to be made or prevents such a judgment from being made?

—The answer to that question is no, there is not, one way or the other. What Senator Bishop has said I do not question. It simply reinforces what I said in answer to her previous question, that is, that if those arrangements are made by courts in respect of non-Aboriginal people, they will be applied in the same way to the holders of native title.

—The point is that the manner in which the courts are making these awards of extra payment to meet the capital gains tax are being done in an ad hoc fashion. Some individuals are being advantaged and others are not being advantaged, depending on who the judge is. We have this massive set of tribunals where we have competing jurisdictions, so there needs to be some rule, some guideline, as to the manner in which this is to be treated. It is not being dealt with adequately now. We have the opportunity to make provision for it. Will the government make some provision for guidelines on the question of capital gains tax?

—The question of the judgments that are being made on the tax act is not something on which I am an expert but I think it would be rather bizarre to make provision for it in this particular bill. If judges are making judgments in respect of the capital gains tax and its application that the Parliament disagrees with or finds uncomfortable—and I might add, as Senator Bishop would know, that that happens all the time with the law—then that is one reason why we get bills in Parliament. If courts are ruling in a way with which the Parliament does not agree the acts can be changed. I do not accept that because I do not know anything about it, but if there are problems with judgments being made in respect of capital gains tax, the appropriate legislation in which to correct those problems is the taxation act, not in the native title area.

—I have a simple question to the minister on tax because I am a little surprised by this provision for non-monetary compensation. I am not sure how many precedents there are. What happens to the transferred tax? The transfer of property certainly attracts tax at state level and sometimes at local level. How is the tax payable on such a transfer to be dealt with in relation to such a non-monetary compensation arrangement?

—I think I would have to refer the honourable senator to the answer I just gave. There is no question at all that there will be a number of complex administrative matters, and taxation in particular will be among them, that will have to be carefully reviewed in terms of the operation of this act. I assume that is the reason why a joint parliamentary committee was discussed during the proceedings of the Senate select committee, with five senators and five members of the House of Representatives to review the operation of the act.

PARA.TAB: What can be said is that, in a general sense, one would expect that the rules that apply in respect of these matters—non-compensatory matters—in terms of assessing a value for them that the courts would agree on, will be handled in the same way for native titleholders as they will be for anyone else. But there is no question that this matter, along with a number of others, will have to be carefully reviewed in terms of the operation of the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a brief comment on the issue Senator Collins raised. It is a quite fundamental issue and should not be skated over in the way it was. The question is whether this particular bill gives rights to one group of people that other Australians do not have. It is a very important issue because Australians like to see all people treated equally before the law of the land, with one law applying to all people. If we impinge on that basic Australian value, we do so at our peril. Indeed, the ability of this bill to receive widespread community acceptance depends on the ability of the government to convince the Australian people that they are not setting up special rights and privileges for a particular race.

PARA.TAB: The argument Senator Collins touched on was that, essentially, Mabo was based on the right of inheritance. That is an argument which has certainly been put; it is an argument I have heard, but the fact is that that particular right of inheritance can apply only to a particular racial group. That is an intellectual argument which I am not convinced by, but I understand the point the honourable senator is making.

There are a couple of other aspects which, I think, are clearly racial and clearly give special rights to a particular group, and that is where the bill enters into very dangerous territory. The appointment of Aboriginal assessors to the various courts on the basis of race, I think, clearly is—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on the basis of local knowledge.
—If it were on the basis of local knowledge, it would be someone who has the local knowledge and expertise.
—That is the Aboriginal community.

—The community could have accepted a stipulation that an anthropologist with certain experience, training and local knowledge should be appointed, but the government has said that only a person of a particular race is entitled to appear on that court.

PARA.TAB: Another issue for the community in the acceptance of this bill is the land compensation fund that is being established, which can apply to and assist only people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island background. Once again, an advantage is clearly being given on the basis of race, and that in itself is likely to be one of the most contentious areas of this bill.

The final point I make is that, as Senator Collins knows, the bill depends for its constitutional head of power on the race power in the bill, and I refer to clause 51(26). I understand why the honourable senator is sensitive about this and why the government is also sensitive, but I think there is, as Senator Bishop said, a growing feeling in the community that we are moving towards separate development. Senator Collins says that this clause can be justified on the basis that we are giving an advantage to a particular group and that therefore the South African experience cannot in any way be applied. It may be the case that an advantage is being given, but that is precisely the reason that this bill will risk not gaining widespread community acceptance. I put it to the honourable senator that the issue Senator Bishop raised cannot be simply brushed over in the way he attempted to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really am amused by the people who are talking about presumptions about people of a particular race. Tell me anything in this bill that could approach the unbelievable presumption of a gaggle of English boat people turning up at a tiny beach on this huge continent several hundred years ago, sticking a Union Jack in the sand on the beach and saying, `This is all ours now. Get out'. That is a fair sort of presumption. The facts are that there are no special provisions in this bill for taxation, so people can rest their minds on that particular point. If the point Senator Bishop has raised is correct and there are problems in the administration of capital gains tax, the appropriate legislation to address those concerns is the taxation acts, not the native title acts.

PARA.TAB: What the opposition is seeking to do here is to raise once again this non-existent magic bullet of a simple solution to the Mabo judgment of the High Court. There is no simple solution. There is another alternative to this bill, and there always has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many alternatives.

—Absolutely, there are. One can have the Western Australian alternative, which is to utterly extinguish any rights of Aboriginal people whatsoever. That is absolutely what that reprehensible piece of legislation does.
—That is an absolute lie.
—I would ask Senator Campbell to withdraw that word. He is a consistent user of it. I do not want it applied to me and I ask him to withdraw it. It is unparliamentary.
—Order! Senator Campbell, it is an unattractive word to be used in the chamber at any time, and I ask you to withdraw it.
—Unattractive, Mr Chairman?
—Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw it without qualification.
—I seek the call.
—Senator Collins is on his feet, Senator Campbell.
—He is sitting down now. Do you want to continue? I am sorry, I thought you may have finished.
—Just let me get it clear. You did withdraw, did you, Senator Campbell?
—Yes, but it was not the truth.

—That is fine. That is arguable. Mr Chairman, there is no simple solution. One of the other alternatives, which originally I think was proposed publicly and advocated, to my astonishment, by people within the mining industry, is not to have a bill but to allow the matter to be adjudicated by the courts; in other words, to have the High Court make this decision and then simply to have claims similar to the Mabo claim made in courts. I think it would be an horrendous result for Australia to have that situation. The result of that would be to have no rules at all except the rules imposed by the courts, to have the matter litigated for decades and, in the meantime, to have the entire land tenure of Australia placed under non-stop uncertainty.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental provisions of this legislation provide overwhelmingly for the validation of title. That is, for all of those people in Australia under our land management system that have title in both freehold and leasehold land, this validates their title and puts it beyond dispute so that everybody can get on with their business. At the same time, this bill provides for a fair go for Australia's Aboriginal people. That is the substantive difference between this bill and the Western Australian approach. I agree with Senator Campbell that the Western Australian approach is much simpler than this approach—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—Many of Senator Campbell's colleagues have. It is a simpler approach. It is simpler because it extinguishes any rights that Aboriginal people might have at all. It gives them a right of traditional usage, a right that the bill makes absolutely clear is subservient to any other right in the land. At the end of the division that provides for it, it provides an administrative—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The Western Australian legislation is not here for discussion today. The minister is off the point, and I believe the minister should be drawn to order and made to debate the point.
—Mr Chairman, I was responding to the point that Senator Bishop—
—Senator Collins, are you responding on the point of order?
—No.
—I will rule on the point of order first. There has been considerable flexibility in terms of what is germane to each clause. Perhaps conscious of that, Senator Collins might move on.

—Mr Chairman, I was—and I will conclude on this point—responding to Senator Bishop's correct interjection that there are many options available for handling this. I was indicating two predominant options, that is, the Western Australian legislative approach and the doing nothing approach, which I find unacceptable.
—There are other alternatives.
—Of course there are; there are endless solutions.
—You start on that matter on this part of the bill and we will keep you here until the New Year. Get back onto the legislation.
—Mr Chairman, with respect, this is directly addressing the debate in the chamber.
—It is not. We have been on the debate the whole time Senator Gareth Evans has been here. Get back to the substance.
—I will conclude—
—You're filibustering, not us. You are wasting our time. This is absolute rhetorical rubbish.
—I will conclude by reassuring both honourable senators—
—We do not want your second reading speech all over again. Let's get back to the substance.
—Order! Senator Campbell, I have asked you to desist. Please do so.
—This guy is just wasting time.
—Senator Campbell, when I ask you to desist, I expect you to do so.
—When he sits down, I will get up and take a point of order or speak.
—Senator Campbell should go and get a bit of professional help.

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman, yesterday we had points of order raised when Senator Gareth Evans said that other people needed psychiatric help. If Senator Collins wants to help the procedures of this chamber he should not make personal reflections by telling people to get professional help.
—I would desist if the honourable senator would desist from screaming at me for 10 minutes straight.
—Order! Senator Campbell, you did not—
—I will sit quietly here, and then I will respond to this rhetoric the minute this bloke sits down.

—Order! Could we have some civility in the chamber this morning, notwithstanding the hours we have all been sitting. Senator Collins, Senator Campbell will know that there has been wide ranging debate throughout the course of this committee stage. However, Senator Collins will also know that it was thoroughly unhelpful to make that suggestion. If Senator Campbell had asked me to ask you to withdraw it, I would have done so. However, he has not done so. I ask Senator Collins to assist the chair by talking on the subject.

—Mr Chairman, I have been trying to do so. I will conclude by reassuring the two honourable senators who have raised this point that there are no special provisions in this bill in respect of any special arrangements for taxation for Aboriginal people.

—Over the last two, three or four days, Senator Gareth Evans has been in the chamber responding point by point on technicalities and issues of substance. In the last half hour we have witnessed the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) before the chair—
—What has this got to do with the bill?

—We are seeking to move through clause by clause and to make progress. We want to pick up the technical and practical aspects of this bill. In the last half hour we have witnessed an absolute waste of the committee's time. Provocative statements have come from the minister, and they have provoked me. I genuinely apologise to the chamber for getting angry, but the minister has reflected on the motives of the Western Australian government. He said that the Western Australian government's legislation wipes out all the rights of Aboriginal people. That is gross misrepresentation of the fact. In fact what the Western Australian government has tried to do is to respond to the High Court's Mabo decision in a way which maintains certainty and which maintains that all Western Australians, regardless of race, have equal rights before the law.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian government goes even further than that. It does what the federal government says it seeks to do, and that is to ensure that where there is disadvantage it is approached in a manner that looks after those people suffering the disadvantage and seeks to overcome that disadvantage. There is no doubt that there is a requirement in a just society for some special measures. There is absolutely no doubt that in this bill there is a whole range of special measures, but certain of these special measures we believe may be contrary to the Racial Discrimination Act.

If we are to proceed in a sensible manner with the consideration of this bill, we should stick to the points. When Senator Bishop said that there are a number of ways of approaching this problem, I am sure she meant—I will not try to read her mind, although better people than me have tried to do so—that when we raise the question in the federal parliament about the approaches to Mabo 2, there are certainly a range of approaches the federal parliament and our federal government can take in relation to the High Court's second Mabo decision.

As Senator Ellison said in his point of order, it does not help the debate, particularly when Senator Collins knows that it will inflame the Western Australians, to keep talking about the Western Australian traditional usage legislation. If Senator Collins wants to keep saying, `Our legislation is right and just and caring of Aborigines, and Richard Court's legislation is a nasty, horrible piece of legislation', we will spend the whole day having a fight over that. It will not get the committee very far. I suggest that if honourable senators want to have that debate, we will be here for a long time. None of us wants to be here forever. What we want is to go through this bill, and we have been trying very hard to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get on with it?
—Let me assure Senator Murphy that I will, but I want to make my point because the minister has spent the last half hour—
—You have just spent the last seven minutes doing exactly the same.
—If Senator Murphy would stop interjecting, I would get on with it.
—Ask the question.
—Why does not Senator Murphy just stick a sock in it?
—This guy has the shortest fuse I have ever seen.
—I am finished, Mr Chairman. I have tried to be helpful but I cannot be with idiots like this on the other side.

—I would like to make some brief comments. The first point is that we are not here to debate the Western Australian legislation. I appeal to Senator Collins, if he is going to raise it, at least to be honest and tell the truth about it. The minister totally misled this parliament in what he said. The Western Australian legislation does not wipe out all indigenous people's rights. In fact, it gives rights that this legislation does not give and the High Court decision did not give. So if we are going to refer to it, we must be accurate in what we say about it. That is the first point I would make.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that if people want to adopt a provocative approach to handling these things, there are plenty of us over here who could respond consistently all day and all night.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 50.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 50, page 29, subclause (1), at the end of the subclause add the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(e)none of paragraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d) applies and the Federal Court decides, on application by any person, that it would be just and equitable in all the circumstances to pay the negotiated compensation to that person or another person.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 50, page 30, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:
"(7) In a paragraph (1)(e) case, the trustee must pay the negotiated compensation in accordance with the decision of the Federal Court mentioned in that paragraph.".

Clause 50 deals with how compensation paid into trust under the right to negotiate procedures is to be dealt with in circumstances set out in subclause (1). The proposed amendment, which would insert a new paragraph (e) into subclause (1), provides for how the money paid into the trust is to be dealt with if none of the other conditions is satisfied and is thus a catch-all provision. It would permit the Federal Court, on application by any person, to pay the negotiated compensation to that person or another person where it considers it to be just and equitable in the circumstances. This is not a matter of any major policy change, Mr Chairman; it is simply a tidying-up provision for the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I know the running sheet says that we have clause 50 and then clause 53, but I think it would help debate if we combine those two headings because they bring in the question of corporate bodies and the trustee aspect. There are some points which I would make on clause 50 which are also tied up with clause 53, payments to corporate bodies. I ask that we do it in that way. The minister might have some other comments in relation to amendments to clause 53; I am not sure whether there are any. I wonder whether we can roll it together as a cognate debate, deal with the amendments, and then deal with clauses 50 to 53.

—Senator Ellison, let me express my understanding of what is before us. If I am wrong, you can correct me. We have government amendments under clause 50 and we also have Democrat amendments under clause 50. The clause 50 amendments by the government relate to compensation by trustees and the amendments by the Democrats refer to the body corporate. There are no amendments on clauses 51 and 52.
—I want clause 53 as well so that I do not have to rehash the debate when we get to the next lot. I ask for a cognate debate on the whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Ellison's suggestion. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25)Clause 53A, page 32, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Protection of native title from debt recovery processes etc.

PARA.TAB: "(5) Subject to subsection (6), native title rights and interests held by the body corporate are not able to be:

TAB.TAB: (a)assigned, restrained, garnisheed, seized or sold; or
(b)made subject to any charge or interest; or
(c)otherwise affected;

PARA.TAB: as a result of:

TAB.TAB: (d)the incurring, creation or enforcement of any debt or other liability of the body corporate (including a debt or liability owed to the Crown in any capacity or to any statutory authority); or
(e)any act done by the body corporate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subsection (5) not applicable to dealings authorised by regulations

PARA.TAB: "(6) Subsection (5) does not apply if the incurring of the debt, creation of the liability or doing of the act was in connection with a dealing with the native title rights and interests authorised by regulations for the purposes of paragraph (4)(c).".

SPEECH.PARA: I would take it one step further: I have been advised that government amendment schedule 75 applies to the question of bodies corporate. It would be possible, with the agreement of the chamber, to deal with that entire amendment schedule together because it deals with a single issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it only fair that Senator Ellison get an opportunity to look at that proposition.
—You can restrict it to the last three clauses.
—Is schedule 75 a recent amendment?
—No, it is three days old.

—Why do we not just do 50 through to 53? During that debate, if Senator Ellison has an opportunity to look at the additional amendments, he can perhaps agree. Is it the wish of the committee that we deal with clauses 50 to 53 inclusive? There being no objection, it is so ordered. Senator Collins has moved his amendments 23, 24 and 25. The further amendments I have before me are from the Democrats.

—The Australian Democrats are withdrawing their amendments to the body corporate clauses in the bill. We have made a careful examination of the government amendments, which are circulated as No. 75, and actually extend beyond 50 and 53 into a number of other clauses, including 55, 59, 87, 153, 185, 207, 209, 223 and 238. If Senator Ellison agrees, I believe that is a package, and it would be appropriate to deal with them as such. The Australian Democrats were concerned that the provisions in the original bill, in the amendments of the government, seemed to impose a particular structure on native title holders. The point had been raised as to whether this could be construed as being contrary to the Racial Discrimination Act provisions.

PARA.TAB: We therefore welcome this structure the government has put forward in its amendment package No. 75. It does provide flexibility to native title holders, but it also, through the tribunal, enables consideration of the advantages of a trust or corporate structure which are appropriate for the particular situation native titleholders find themselves in. I believe that the structure as it is before us now offers flexibility. It recommends and enables the establishment of an administrative structure which will ensure that decisions in the native titleholder's community can be made efficiently and responsibly and the money can, if necessary, be held on trust, to ensure that the native titleholders are not disadvantaged. The Australian Democrats support the government's package 75 of amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, in moving the amendments on schedule 75—
—I think it reasonable that, for the time being, we restrict ourselves to amendments up to and including your amendment 25, until Senator Ellison has had an opportunity to look at amendment 75.
—Mr Chairman, the substantial amendment we are dealing with is to clause 53.
—I have no problem with that.
—Fine, thank you. I therefore move government amendment schedule 75:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 4, page 5, table containing outline of Act, lines 16 and 17, entry in column headed "Coverage" in relation to Part 2, omit paragraph (e), substitute the following:

TAB.TAB: "(e)Division 6 provides for prescribed bodies corporate to perform functions in relation to native title, which may include holding the native title on trust.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 28, page 18, paragraph (2)(a), line 3, omit "holder", substitute "body corporate".
(3)Clause 29, page 18, lines 23 to 26, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "29.Each of the following is also a `native title party':

TAB.TAB: (a)any person who, within the period of 2 months starting when the notice is given, becomes a registered native title claimant in relation to any of the land or waters that will be affected by the act;
(b)any body corporate that, within that period of 2 months, becomes a registered native title body corporate in relation to any of the land or waters that will be affected by the act.".

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 41, page 24, paragraph (2)(a), line 26, omit "holders", substitute "bodies corporate".
(5)Clause 41, page 24, paragraph (2)(d), line 31, omit "holders", substitute "bodies corporate".
(6)Clause 50, page 29, subparagraph (1)(c)(i), line 15, omit "by a body corporate", substitute "in trust".
(7)Clause 50, page 29, subparagraph (1)(c)(ii), line 18, omit "body corporate holding the native title under Division 6", substitute "registered native title body corporate".
(8)Clause 50, page 29, subparagraph (1)(c)(ii), line 20, omit "it", substitute "the native title holders".
(9)Division 6, page 31 (line 18) to page 33 (line 22), omit the Division, substitute the following Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "Division 6—Native title functions of prescribed bodies corporate and holding of native title in trust

TAB.EMPHASIS: Determinations by NNTT and Federal Court

TAB.TAB: (a)the NNTT or the Federal Court proposes to make an approved determination of native title; and
(b)the determination is that native title exists at the time of making the determination;

SPEECH.PARA: the NNTT or the Federal Court must, at the same time as it makes the determination, make the determinations in section 53A (which deals with holding the native title on trust) and 53B (which deals with non-trust functions of prescribed bodies corporate).

TAB.EMPHASIS: Determination whether native title to be held in trust

PARA.TAB: "53A.(1) One of the determinations that the NNTT or the Federal Court must make is whether the native title is to be held in trust, and, if so, by whom.
"(2) The NNTT or the Federal Court is to take the following steps in making the determination:

TAB.TAB: (a)first, it must request a representative of the persons it proposes to include in the determination of native title as the native title holders (the `common law holders') to indicate whether the common law holders intend to have the native title held in trust by:
(i)nominating, in writing given to the NNTT or the Federal Court within a specified period, a prescribed body corporate to be trustee of the native title; and
(ii)including with the nomination the written consent of the body corporate; and

(b)secondly, if the common law holders give the nomination within the period, the NNTT or the Federal Court must determine that the prescribed body corporate is to hold the rights and interests from time to time comprising the native title in trust for the common law holders; and

(c)thirdly, if the common law holders do not give the nomination within the period, the NNTT or the Federal Court must determine that the rights and interests are to be held by the common law holders.

Explanatory note government amendment 75
Prescribed bodies corporate

The High Court held that one of the central features of native title rights is that they are rights held by a group and that that group changes over time. To provide for dealings with native title holders and native title rights the government believes that there is a need for a corporate body to be the contact point for dealings in native title.

The present provisions relating to these bodies in the bill require that the native title rights be held on behalf of the common law native title holders by a prescribed body corporate. The proposed amendments to these provisions will still require that there be a body corporate to present native title holders but that the common law native title holders will be able to choose whether or not the native title rights will be held on trust by that body or not.

These amendments still achieve the government's objective that there be a body corporate which can represent native title holders without persons wishing to deal with those native title holders having to deal with each individual native title holder.

The holding of the native title rights on trust is the most flexible mechanism to deal with the position of changing native title holders over time and also ensures that they always remain the beneficial owner.

The government is of the view that the original provisions would not have been in breach of any of the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act in particular section 10 (3) of that act. However, these amendments will make the position even clearer. Native title holders will have the choice of whether or not the native title rights will be held by a body corporate or not and even if they do so decide then under the new paragraph 53A(4)(e) the native title holders can terminate that arrangement and hold the rights themselves.

The government will prescribe by regulation what kind of bodies will be able to hold the title and what functions they will have. There are also other matters which will be prescribed and all these matters will be the subject of further consultation with indigenous representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I would like to take this opportunity to refer to government amendment No. 25, which deals specifically with clause 53, which I understand we are now taking together with the preceding clauses. This amendment would make meaningless the sensible provision of all state and territory laws of general application that could apply to native title land, if they could apply to freehold land. Often the way of enforcing these provisions is to allow a penalty to be a charge on the land. TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that the nature of native title is that it is inalienable title. PARA.TAB: This clause does not have that effect. It simply preserves the inalienable nature of the title but it does not prevent the native titleholders from being sued, from having removed from them any other possessions they might have. Again, this is not a unique situation, particularly following the events of the 1980s, as they are referred to, in that they would not really be in any different situation in this respect from, for example, a bankrupt in attempting to recover something from someone who had no assets. What this does is simply recognise the inalienable nature of the title itself.

In terms of garnisheeing and so on, it would be a very foolish person who would provide for a situation where there was a charge on the land, for example, in respect of inalienable native title; it would be impossible to recover that because the land is inalienable. The point has been made at length in previous debates in this chamber and elsewhere that the right of conversion to native title equivalent may well not be exercised. Aboriginal people may not choose to exercise it because of the greater economic flexibility which non-native title provides. Native titleholders will still be able to receive grants and so on from bodies such as ATSIC but the land cannot be used as security, as Senator Tambling has pointed out, for the loan. The same thing applies here. Charges cannot be made on the land but the native titleholders can be sued if they transgress any land management issues and are charged with such an offence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer, but it does not really allay my concerns that this is again an example of the fact that there are inconsistencies in the law. —In the way local authority laws operate, certainly in Queensland and I assume right around Australia, very often rates are owing on a property and the only recourse a local authority has is by taking the land.
