Do honourable senators also remember what this minister, Senator Evans, said about the Western Australian government when it applied the guillotine on the native title bill a few weeks ago? He attacked Mr Court in this place, saying what a terrible thing it was that the Western Australian parliament was applying a guillotine to such critically important legislation. Mr Keating in the other place said likewise, `What a shocking thing it is for the Western Australian parliament to apply a guillotine'. But when it comes to this parliament and the interests of government senators, there are double standards. A different standard applies: it is legitimate to cut down the process of the Senate and thwart the proper practice of this place.

The role of the Australian Democrats we must contemplate again. It was the party that came in here to keep the bastards honest; it was the party that would never accept the guillotine. The other day in the corridor Senator Spindler said to me, `Don't you think you will wear us down on this one, because you won't. We will be here in the new year; we are not going to guillotine this bill'. But as soon as Senator Evans comes along, hands out a few morsels and says, `Come on friends, it's time that we embrace again; it's time that we become part of the family and separate ourselves, the party of the Left, from the real opposition', they said, `Okay Senator Evans, okay Mr Keating; we are just part of your whole'. Senator Kernot said, `You can have this bill even without giving us the detail'.

What a disgrace. There is only one alternative to this government in this chamber and in Australia, and that is the coalition parties. We would be prepared to stay here and do the job properly—New Year's Day, next year—or however long it takes.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all knew this guillotine would fall sooner or later, because we knew the Greens and the Australian Democrats would totally contradict statements they have been making day after day. Only yesterday Senator Spindler said, `You have picked the wrong bill because we will stay here until next year'. Senator Spindler said that yesterday and—as with what all of his colleagues in the Democrats say—what he said yesterday is not worth two pinches of salt.

PARA.TAB: Whenever Senator Spindler opens his mouth and makes a statement to the media or to the chamber, he will have to ask himself whether we should ever believe him again. Similarly with the Greens; they have a strong commitment to this legislation and to the Aboriginal people. One would think that, of anyone, those Green senators would dedicate themselves to ensuring that this legislation was considered properly.

The days we have spent here have been a farce. It is absolutely crazy to have 76 senators and hundreds of staff here day in and day out for absolutely ludicrous hours—hours that take their toll of everybody's health. We said that when we wanted to set up a Senate select committee. The Senate has a very workable, worldwide respected committee system. The most appropriate body to deal with a bill with 238 clauses and in excess of 250 amendments is a Senate select committee or some other committee. In that way we could go through the detail of the administration, the constitutional aspects, the legal aspects and the practical aspects of what everyone has described, as Senator Evans described yesterday, as a highly complex piece of legislation.

On clause after clause, the minister has not been able to answer detailed questions on the practicalities or the administrative ramifications of this legislation. He has admitted that we will have to rely on reams and reams of regulation to ensure that this is enacted. We have to rely, for example, on the states amending a whole series of pieces of legislation in relation to compulsory acquisition acts. This bill cannot work unless state governments right around this country amend compulsory acquisition acts and ensure that those amendments take place.

The urgency of this matter is a joke; it is simply not true. We know that all of these regulations need to be drafted. Senator Evans has assured us that somewhere in Canberra some bureaucrats and legal people are off drafting the regulations. I wonder who those people are, because most of the experts on this bill are sitting in the advisers boxes over there. We know that, under the normal arrangements, if things are done properly, it will take at least nine months to ensure those regulations are enacted. This bill cannot even be implemented until then and probably cannot be up and running until September or October next year.

I suggest that the Greens and the Democrats have been mischievously misled by this government saying that this bill needs to be in place before Christmas so it can be up and running in the new year. Senator Evans knows, and his advisers know, that this bill cannot be operative before the states pass legislation which complies with this rapacious piece of legislation; legislation which takes so many powers away from state governments. We know that the matter of urgency is just a joke. The urgency is that this government built this legislation on what is a very fragile consensus of Aboriginal groups who, to my mind, are not representative of the Aboriginal communities and industry groups, which, one at a time, have now peeled away from the government. Even Mr Rick Farley from the National Farmers Federation, who was one of the strongest supporters of the initial piece of legislation, has pulled his support away from this bill.

The sad thing is that every senator in this place knows, for different reasons, that this is an extremely important piece of legislation. It is important to those who have a deep and abiding interest in ensuring that Aboriginals' rights are respected and that Aboriginal welfare is looked after, that this matter be debated and that the legislation comes out in the correct form. It is a matter of serious concern for those of us who have a deep respect for ensuring that decision making is kept close to the people of Australia and that decisions in relation to land management are kept close to the people within the state parliaments, so that if state governments make a mistake they are answerable to their electorates.

This Senate should be standing up for the rights of those people in the states; it is not. As Senator Hill said, the Democrats are here to keep the bastards honest; they are here to ensure that we are a House of review; they are here to ensure that we deal with legislation in great detail, because it does not happen in the House of Representatives. But, when we have—on the admission of the minister—the most complex piece of legislation that has come before the chamber for years and years, what do the Democrats do? No select committee, no chance for the community of Australia to have its view, they just gag the debate again. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Campbell—I think it was yesterday; it might have been Friday—introduced the notion of the permissible rave into this parliament. We are indebted to Hansard forever to have that acknowledgment on the record. Today he gave us another sample of the genre, and I think we are rapidly developing a set of accepted precedents in that respect. That was a rave.

PARA.TAB: Let me just state a couple of things for the record. In 1989, the ATSIC bill was passed in this place. Debate on the ATSIC bill took 39 hours and five minutes. That was a record in the history of the Senate. As of now, the Native Title Bill committee stage has taken 41 hours and 15 minutes. We have beaten the record already by two hours and 10 minutes. No bill in the history of this parliament has taken so long in committee stage as this bill has taken.

When we get to the next resolution it is proposed that there be another seven hours debate on the committee stage. The truth of the matter is that, by the end of this committee stage, when the final vote is taken—that is not including the time for divisions, and that is going to take some time as well—at least 48 hours and 15 minutes will have been devoted to the committee stage consideration of this bill. No bill in the history of the parliament has taken this long.

It is a complex bill. Legislative debate was appropriate under the circumstances. But it is not appropriate on this scale and it is not appropriate on any view for one question yesterday to occupy us for 8 1/4 hours. For 8 1/4 hours yesterday we debated one question and one amendment and that was a filibuster if ever I have heard of a filibuster in my entire life.

Those opposite have wasted time, they have misused the practice of this place, they have approached this bill in a way that has been contemptible and despicable from the outset. They have not been willing to improve the bill, they have not been willing to act constructively and they have made total fools of themselves in the way in which they have responded to crucial amendments that their own industry groups have wanted. They have approached this bill in a spirit of absolute contempt for Aboriginal people, absolute contempt for the principles of social justice which lie behind this bill.

For those opposite to come in here and have the hypocrisy to weep the crocodile tears that they are now weeping about the demise of democracy because we are giving them only 48 hours and 15 minutes to debate this bill is the most grotesque act of hypocrisy, the most grotesque outpouring of crocodile tears, the greatest dam full of crocodile tears I have ever seen in the whole 15 years I have been in this place. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. Already we have taken far more time in debating this legislation than all four of the state parliaments which have passed or had this legislation before them have taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good point. What about Western Australia?

—They have taken more time than the Western Australian parliament, plus the Queensland parliament, plus the Victorian parliament, plus the amount of time that the New South Wales parliament has so far devoted to its particular legislation. Those opposite have had more time already than all those state parliaments put together in their committee stage.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite have the hide, they have the indecency, to come in here—after the performance they put up yesterday, after the filibuster, after the grotesque procedural interruptions, delays, hindrances and obstructions that they have perpetrated over the last week—and claim that their rights are being reduced by this particular legislation. They are getting far more respect for their debating rights than they deserve. They ought to hang their heads in shame, accept the reality of that provision and let this particular guillotine go through, as it should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At lunchtime today we will have spent 46 hours and 40 minutes on this bill.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. Is it not the convention that you call from one side and then the other? Senator Gareth Evans spoke last, and I would have thought it was the turn for someone from this side.
—Senator Faulkner sought the call earlier but I did not see him. I called two speakers from the opposition side and nobody from the government side, so I am just squaring up the numbers.

—Mr Chairman, on the point of order: I realise the reason you have given the call twice in a row to the government. Having listened to the beginning of Senator Faulkner, he will be repetitious. We have heard all of that from Senator Evans. Would you give him the call conditional upon his not being repetitious? If he has something new to say, then we will listen.
—I think that it is early to make a judgment.

—Included in that period of time were 10 hours and 10 minutes in debate on the second reading and the balance in the committee stage. There has been more time spent on this bill than any other bill in the history of this chamber since a limitation applied to debate at the second reading stage. That is more time than the 40 hours spent on the appropriation bills in 1992. That is more time than the 39 hours spent on the ATSIC package. That is more time than the 32 hours spent on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. That is more time than the 30 hours spent on the National Health Bill 1970. Most of the debate has been time wasting, filibustering and obstruction from the opposition. That is what it has been about. We have had enough time to debate this bill by any measure. What this guillotine proposes—
—Your measure, because you want to go home.
—Senator Hill should not talk about wanting to go home. I have had all of the opposition senators crawling up to me on their knees saying, `When can we go home, please? When can we go home, please?'
—Order! That description is inappropriate in the chamber. I ask you to withdraw it.

—I withdraw it. It would be irresponsible for the government not to move this motion. It would be irresponsible to let the opposition continue these tactics. Every senator in this chamber, everyone in the public galleries and all the staff know that all the opposition senators, with the exception of about three of them, want to go home now. Frankly, the government is more than happy to oblige.

PARA.TAB: It is true we have been reluctant to use the guillotine, but senators need to face the fact that the government now has no choice. The opposition refuses to be positive. It refuses to be constructive. It refuses to make any worthwhile contribution. Until the cows come home, it will continue to frustrate; to filibuster; to waste time; to call quorums; and, to ask mindless, inane, repetitious and endless questions all day. This is all nonsense. The opposition will continue to do that until the cows come home—or the two or three opposition senators who want to sit here get tired.

It is responsible for the government to move this resolution. It is responsible to have a guillotine. A guillotine is responsible when an opposition behaves in the perverse way that this opposition has behaved over the debate on this bill. This is an eminently reasonable proposal that will allow ample time for debate on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Keating yesterday—we will be here on Boxing Day?
—Senator Hill wants to go home like the rest of the opposition. He wants to go home and we all know it. This will allow ample time for debate on this bill.

—This is perhaps the most important bill to come before this parliament in a decade. It is one that requires sober and considered debate. Senator Evans and his colleagues have conceded that in the last three days this has not been a filibuster. Senator Evans acknowledged absolutely that the debate being conducted by my colleagues was fair and sensible and one which went to the root of this very complex bill.

PARA.TAB: Sure, a hell of a lot of time has been spent on this bill, but it is one of the most complex and important bills ever to come here. To hear Senator Faulkner and Senator Gareth Evans go on with their absolutely hypocritical diatribe and insults just shows the absolute contempt in which they hold this parliament.

I suspect—I do not think it needs much suspicion—that the Australian Democrats will roll over on this bill. It absolutely disgusts me the way that Senator Evans and Senator Faulkner have been heavying the Greens since this started. Every two minutes they are standing over the Greens and exerting what pressure they can on them to try to get them to curtail the debate on this most important bill.

But one would not expect any better from the Democrats. In the last 10 years, they have voted for the guillotine on so many occasions. One example is the Sex Discrimination Bill in 1983. In 1984, they voted to have 14 bills guillotined. In 1987, 27 bills were guillotined. In 1987, another 27 bills were guillotined. It went on until 1988, when the Democrats said, `We will not agree to such tactics ever again'.

What will happen? There can only be two answers: the Democrats should not agree to it or they should move into the caucus and take away the pretence of being a democratic and independent party. They should simply move into the caucus and agree with the government right from the start. The Democrats said, `We will never do this again'. Yet what are we going to see now? They will cross the floor and curtail debate on the most important piece of legislation that any of them have ever seen.

Many important aspects still have to be dealt with. Those that have been considered have been dealt with properly by my colleagues. Senator Evans had the absolute hypocrisy to say that the bill has been filibustered when only yesterday he conceded that this debate was going properly and that the questions being asked were relevant. At no stage have you ever suggested, you hypocrite—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ian Macdonald, I ask you to withdraw in the same way that I asked Senator Faulkner to withdraw.

—I withdraw. Senator Evans should give me a description of this conduct. Yesterday he said, `I acknowledge that this debate is being conducted properly. I acknowledge that the questions are fair. I acknowledge that the opposition wants to understand how these things are working. I acknowledge the absolute complexity of this bill. I acknowledge that the opposition needs to know these things. I acknowledge that there are over 100 amendments from the Greens and the Democrats that need proper debate'. Today he has the—
—And then you had 8 1/4 hours on one question.

—He has—give me the word—whatever it is that can make him change his words in one day. He is now saying that there was a filibuster to try to get some public support for this outrageous action in curtailing debate on one of the most important pieces of legislation that has ever come here.

PARA.TAB: It need not happen. I hope that the Greens have not succumbed to the pressure and standover thuggery that has been put on them all through this debate by Senator Evans and Senator Faulkner. I hope that they will not succumb to it. I know that the Democrats, in spite of their commitment and promise to this parliament, will never again agree to the guillotine being applied. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, the moral outrage! The opposition has expressed its surprise at this stage taking so long to reach, while secretly it wishes that it had happened yesterday. We were relying on the goodwill of the coalition to move this debate along just a little, but so far they have shown none. We spent 8 1/2 hours yesterday debating one clause. Senator Ian Macdonald pretends that all of the questions were important. Some of them were—there is no doubt about that—but they were sprinkled with the typical filibustering tactics we have come to expect from this opposition, still spoiling after losing the last election.

PARA.TAB: As the statistics quoted by others have shown, we are approaching the record for time spent in debate. As has been pointed out, the last bill on which we spent so much time was the ATSIC bill—another bill about the rights of indigenous people. What has the opposition got against the rights of indigenous Australians that it will go to any lengths to prevent a vote being taken on a bill concerning those rights. Have the members of the opposition seen the Petty cartoon in today's Age? It is very instructive, and I suggest that those opposite look at it.

We have now recorded some 44 hours of parliamentary debate on this bill. The opposition said it wanted debate, yet yesterday those opposite sought to suspend standing orders so that we could debate the press conference given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That is how important the detail of this bill is to those opposite—we were supposed to have an open ended debate on what the Prime Minister said in his press conference. That was considered by the opposition to be more important than this bill. We have asked the coalition to extend a little goodwill and to apply a little self-discipline. Since the coalition has shown that it is unwilling to do that, we have reached the stage where some discipline has to be imposed.

Before those opposite misrepresent what is happening, let me say that this is a managed guillotine. There are many hours left for debate. We have at least three hours to debate the remaining important definitions, and that should be sufficient time. Senator Ian Macdonald has displayed his usual Democrat fixation. If ever Senator Macdonald's side wins government, he will have to be sent off to some sort of charm school to work out how to negotiate with people because he has forgotten what it is all about.

Senator Hill said that the situation we were facing was not an emergency. What did require emergency action were the views of the staff who came to see us last night. They have rights in this matter and I am willing to consider their views. When the people of Australia see the moral outrage of those opposite on television tonight, I want them to know that so many of them have privately approached us and said, `Come on, when are you going to put the guillotine on? We want to go home.' That is the truth. No amount of filibustering will take away from the fact that this bill is historic, that it is just and that the majority of honourable senators will take the time to vote on it. They will not necessarily pass it but they will take the time to vote on it because that is what the majority has decided to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of this motion has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That this bill be considered an urgent bill.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the time allotted for consideration of the remainder of the bill in committee be as follows:
Clauses 50 to 54 (including deferred new clause 6A):—30 minutes
Clauses 55 to 72:—60 minutes
Clauses 73 to 191:—60 minutes
Clauses 192 to 206 (including deferred clause 11):—90 minutes
Clauses 207 to 238 (including the title and deferred clause 14):—180 minutes

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, this is probably the most generous guillotine in the history of this parliament. If there are any more cries of wounded outrage from the other side, they should be dismissed as the crocodile tears which again they are. This guillotine has been carefully crafted and designed to enable reasonable debate on any remaining substantive issues that have not already been canvassed.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 50 to 54, in relation to which another 30 minutes is now to be allowed, have of course been debated for the last hour and a half or so before we commenced this particular guillotine process this morning. There are important issues there about the body corporate and the Racial Discrimination Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —You told me we would have plenty of time. You can't tell the truth.

—There will be time for even Senator Macdonald to fulminate and make whatever points he wants to make on this particular subject. Thirty minutes is plenty of time in the way in which guillotines are run in this parliament, old son, and the way in which your lot used to run them when they had half the chance. Thirty minutes to deal with four or five clauses is generous indeed—and far more generous than Senator Macdonald deserves, in particular.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 55 to 72 deal essentially with procedural issues of no great moment, but there are some issues undoubtedly that those opposite will want to raise and to which we are perfectly happy to give answers. Sixty minutes will be ample time for that to occur.

Clauses 73 to 191—although, on the face of it, that is a very large number of clauses to be dealt with in just 60 minutes—overwhelmingly are uncontroversial machinery, procedural and administrative provisions, which do not give—

TALK.START.PARA: —Says you.

—Yes, says me. Senator Macdonald is right. I know a lot more about this bill than Senator Macdonald. He demonstrates that every time he gets to his feet; every time he opens his mouth. He is just a posturing ignoramus when it comes to the detail of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 192 to 206, including deferred clause 11, are given 90 minutes for debate—one and a half hours for debate. It is not unreasonable that there should be a generous time allotment for this. It is a generous time allotment, and it needs to be because there are some important issues there, such as Senator Vanstone's obsession about clause 11 and the constitutionality of it, which we will be happy to revisit in the generous 90 minutes that are available to us.

There is the question of the proposed new 196A and the question of the application of general state laws to particular situations involving the exercise of native title, and we are very happy to debate that. So we have an hour and a half for debate—far more time than any of those opposite deserve. But it is a demonstration of our commitment to legitimate process, to democracy and to all the values which all or, at least, some of us hold dear.

Then we have the definitional clauses 207 to 238. We have visited and revisited these definitional clauses about 85 times during the debate so far. I do not think there is a single phrase in those clauses 207 to 238 that has not been lifted up, dusted off, subjected to scrutiny and made the subject of a very considerable working over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Would you point out to the minister that that is 2 1/2 minutes per clause?
—There is no point of order.

—That is about two minutes and 29 seconds more than those opposite deserve, given the way that they have been conducting this debate. They are lucky to get more than one second per clause, given the way in which those clauses have been the subject of discussion already.

PARA.TAB: To be serious for half a moment, the way this bill is constructed is to depend significantly on the way in which those definitions are written. Those opposite cannot understand many of those earlier clauses that we have been debating for 41 hours without reference to those definitions. A number of those opposite have made it perfectly clear that, even with reference to the definitions, they still cannot understand it. But it is perfectly true that it is relevant to discuss a number of these definitions. We have discussed the definitions—we have discussed them ad nauseam. Nonetheless, we are allowing those opposite 180 minutes, three hours, to pursue further issues that relate to these particular clauses.

Mr Chairman, let me just say again: the way the debate will be run will essentially be to follow the running sheet that has been set out. That means that, when we get to each one of these groups of clauses, there are other amendments, some of them triggered by these clauses but not strictly relating to them, which will be debated at that time in exactly the same way in which we have been going through the running sheet for the 41 3/4 hours that we have been debating that so far.

At the conclusion of each of these blocks of time the various amendments will then be put and the committee will divide as necessary in order to enable the majority will of the committee to be expressed upon them. The intention is that at the end of each block of time the government amendments will be put and the remaining Green and Democrat amendments will equally be put at the end of that period. So there needs to be anticipated some division time in addition to these particular blocks of time that are here set out.

It is proposed that at the conclusion of the committee stage, when the bill has been hopefully approved, the finished bill will be reported to the Senate for the third reading. We would anticipate, of course, that the third reading debate would not need to be a protracted one at this stage of the process. The third reading is not presently the subject of this particular urgency motion but it will be dealt with on the basis that a reasonable time will be allowed for basic expressions of final position to be articulated, but that will be it. With a bit of luck—again I say with a bit of luck and a bit of assistance from those of us who do want to debate this in as orderly and measured way as appropriate—it is my hope and expectation that we will complete this debate no later than midnight tonight and hopefully rather earlier than that.

Under the circumstances, I repeat: this is a remarkably generous allotment of time. Already this bill has been debated in committee uphill and down dale. The whole subject matter of the bill from beginning to end has been debated in committee for 41 hours and 45 minutes. It is proposed to allow another seven hours of substantive debate on this, however much additional time is required on top of that for divisions. This will be by a very considerable margin the most scrutinised, most discussed, most worked over bill in the history of this parliament.

If those opposite are unhappy about any provision that is in the bill or any omission from it, they have nobody else to blame but themselves because they have had ample opportunity to join with the government or to advance other amendments that would helpfully improve the bills in various ways. They have had ample opportunity to do that, but they have declined to do that.

They have been negative, destructive, whingeing and carping. They have utterly failed to understand the spirit in which this legislation has been brought forward—a spirit of resolving one of the great unresolved injustices in the history of this country—the capacity of Aboriginal people to enjoy the land rights that they were dispossessed of by white occupancy of this country. We understand that; the Democrats understand that; the Greens understand that; the community understands that. The only people who do not understand that are those opposite.

They have shown themselves in their true colours. They have shown themselves as being totally indifferent, totally hostile to the values that underlie this legislation. They have shown themselves as being totally unwilling to improve the legislation in a constructive way even when they have been invited to do so. They have been whingeing hypocrites throughout the process of this debate. They have lost any residual credibility they might have had. They have lost any residual claim to respect they might have had in the community, and they have certainly lost any possible basis on which they could be applauded for their sensitivity and respect for the Aboriginal people of this country.

It has been a disgraceful legislative exercise on the opposition's part. Those opposite have made fools of themselves in the way they have handled it tactically. They will end up with nothing as a result of this except egg on their faces and they deserve to be wiping it off from now until the end of this particular parliament—a disgraceful performance. They have been given a far greater go on this than they deserve. This is the most generous guillotine provision that I can ever recall in my 15 years in this parliament. They have got better than they deserve so they should shut up, stop whingeing and get on with the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was just a tantrum from a schoolboy.
—We have just seen, as one of my colleagues said, a tantrum from a schoolboy. Democracy is always troublesome for a dictator.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, do you think you could call for a little quiet? We on this side have a few more pearls to cast before swine. Democracy has always been troublesome for dictators. Yesterday we saw King Paul I go on television to intervene in the debate in the Senate and to put the pressure on the Greens and the Democrats, telling them that the government was prepared to stay here for the duration and that if they wanted to go home, they had better agree to the guillotine. That was the purpose of that intervention.

PARA.TAB: We now need a standing order to prevent bullying in the chamber. Senator Evans has twice reduced Senator Chamarette to tears. She was in here last night weeping her heart out. She was in the chamber this morning weeping again. Senator Evans was over there putting the heavy word on Senator Margetts. At every point in time the heavy was being put on the Greens to agree to the guillotine. Yesterday I asked the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats to disclose what deals had been done because they work as a coalition. On this side of the chamber we disclose the terms of our coalition. It is about time we saw the deal. As for Senator `Noelene', the senator from Sylvania Waters, she is not only a look-alike but she can get the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman: I understand that Senator Bishop has not referred to an honourable senator by her correct name. Could you please bring her to order.
—Order! Senator Bishop, I ask you to refer to whomever you are referring to by their proper name.

—Just in case anybody missed it, it was Senator Kernot. As I was saying, we have got to the position where Senator Evans wants to put a time limit on democracy. We have heard again and again that the job that we are sent here to do is to debate legislation so that the people of Australia know what is in that legislation. The task of the legislation was meant to put an end to the uncertainty created by the High Court in the Mabo No. 2 decision. This bill fails that test. The opposition has demonstrated that quite clearly so that clause by clause we have seen error after error shown by ministers in responding to questions. There is a great list of errors that Senator Evans has made in responding. We have seen again and again the complexity and the question that Senator Vanstone, I and others have pursued concerning clause 11. The key point of constitutionality of this bill will be ramrodded through.

PARA.TAB: I said earlier today that, on the very day that South Africa is getting rid of apartheid, this bill is creating it in this country. We are creating a division in this country. We are concerned on this side of the chamber that we make laws for all Australians and that all Australians are entitled to freedom under the laws of Australia. That means justice and equity for all Australians, including the Aboriginal people.

This bill is not a fair bill; it is not a bill that brings about equity for all Australians. It heightens the uncertainty. It does not cure the problem of sovereign risk. It is a bill which will now be guillotined because the Greens and the Democrats have the pressure put upon them by the intervention of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday to agree to the guillotine. We are entitled in this chamber to know precisely what the deal struck was and we are entitled to properly debate, clause by clause, every point in this bill.

Even as we are debating the guillotine, there is yet another amendment from the Greens. How many more will we get? To say that this can be adequately dealt with in the remaining eight hours is a nonsense. It is not democracy. Yesterday the intervention of King Paul I showed him to be the un-Australian Prime Minister that he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome in the chamber those senseless sheep from the Labor Party who have kept out of this debate. They come into the chamber when they think something is on that might let them go home. I call them senseless sheep because when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said, `We'll stay here as long as it takes'—joining the chorus of the Democrats—the Labor Party was prepared to say, `We'll debate this fully. We'll stay until Christmas Eve, we'll come back on Boxing Day—we'll do whatever needs to be done to give this sensible consideration'. Not one of us is saying that we will not do that. Those opposite are all nodding away in agreement, like the chickens at the pellet trough, saying, `The Prime Minister said this, we'll all agree'. Yesterday the Prime Minister decided to click his fingers and say all of sudden, `This is a filibuster'. So what do we have? We have all the senseless sheep coming down and saying, `This is a filibuster and we are not having anything to do with it'. It is amazing that, whatever the Prime Minister says, these people simply follow.

PARA.TAB: Despite Senator Gareth Evans's humungous ego at the best of times, he really took the cake this morning. He went past the award that we could ever possibly imagine giving someone for an ego. He said, `You don't understand the spirit with which this bill is put forward: the spirit of resolving one of the greatest injustices put on the Aboriginal community'. He thinks this bill is going to solve that. This bill is not going to solve that injustice; the High Court has already done that through Mabo No. 2.

If those opposite want to think that their good words and their good efforts have divined that injustice and done something about it, they should think again. Mabo No. 2 gives Aboriginals native title or gets rid of the notion of terra nullius. It is not what those opposite are doing at all. But he is trying to hog all the glory and says, `We're going to redress this injustice'. It is the High Court that has done that. What we are arguing about here is the best way to handle that decision. So let us not pretend with any moral outrage that those opposite have some divine insight into how to solve this problem or that they have any greater compassion for the Aboriginal community than us, simply because we may think that there is another way of responding to this debate.

The argument put forward as to why we should have this guillotine is that we have spent more time than ever before, as though time alone is the judge of whether or not a debate has been conducted properly. Plenty of people on this side would argue that this is one of the most important—perhaps the most important—bill to go through this place, and it deserves proper consideration. It is no surprise to us that the committee stage of this bill has taken longer than the committee stage of any other bill. By Senator Gareth Evans's own omission, it is a complex bill. Obviously we are going to spend more time on that than on any other bill.

As Senator Tambling's interjection indicated, what we have been left with in this managed guillotine—that Senator Kernot says is such a good thing and that Senator Evans says we should be grateful to have—is two to three minutes a clause. Mr Chairman, if you look back to some of the answers that Senator Gareth Evans has given, you will see that he has taken more than six or seven minutes to answer one question with respect to a clause, and even then some of us have judged that it has not been an answer. But now we are being allowed two to three minutes a clause.

Then we have the Democrats. Senator Spindler was out there with his shield against the community saying, `We'll be here until New Year's Day; they have picked the wrong people; we will never give in'. It reminds me of a poem: `Poor old Siddy got a bit giddy and made a promise he could not keep; if he had any pride, his face he would hide, and smile like a senseless sheep'. That is perfectly applicable to Senator Spindler. He was in here promising that he would be here forever and a day. Poor old Siddy got a bit giddy—that is what happened to him. The Democrats are here supporting a guillotine—a managed guillotine, they say.

The next point that has been raised is that we have no right to debate this bill. The senseless sheep on the other side said, `Hear, hear!' when that point was made. We have no right to debate this bill—that is what people on the other side have agreed to. How outrageous is that? Just because we do not agree with their version and move particular amendments to the bill, somehow these people say that we are deprived of our right to debate this bill clause by clause.
Senator McKiernan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequence—if Senator McKiernan can button up and listen for a minute—if we follow the methodology that has been put forward or suggested, is that we will meet outside this chamber. This chamber will not be a debating or legislative chamber any more. We will meet outside in little groups in the phone boxes that those opposite meet in. We will say, `Hey, listen. Pssst! Do you agree with this bill? Okay, you can come in and say something'. If the answer to `Pssst, do you agree with this bill?' is, `No, I think there is a better way to go', then those opposite will say, `Bad luck about you. We are cutting down your debating rights. We do not even want to hear what you have to say. We are not remotely interested'. In those circumstances debate in the chamber becomes useless because the deal has already been struck; the debating chamber is shifted out into a back room where the deals are done. That is the consequence of proceeding in this way.

PARA.TAB: We are told by Senator Evans that the Christmas time frame has to be kept; in other words, we can say what we like until then, but when the time comes that the government wants its bill passed then the guillotine has to apply. The executive party, with all the sheep that follow their bosses because they are angling for a position, and the Democrats and the Greens—the family as we like to call them—get together and decide that this bill is going through. As a token, magnanimous gesture, some debate is allowed. But the bottom line is that no more debate is allowed than those opposite want because they have already made up their minds outside the chamber on what form the bill will take and when it will be passed.

Senator Kernot has said that the staff have approached the Democrats saying that we should have a guillotine and get out of this place. She asked why we on this side did not think of the staff. I wonder what Senator Kernot was thinking last night when she voted to keep the Senate going all night. I wonder whether any staff said to her then, `Pssst, can we please go home to our families?' and whether she paid any attention to that. The hypocrisy in this place! Those opposite have accused us of hypocrisy and somehow pretend that the mountains of baggage of hypocrisy that they carry around go unnoticed. I do not know how stupid they think everybody else is to try such a stupid line.

As to this debate, it is true that yesterday afternoon from 2 p.m. until 6.30 p.m. we dealt with half a clause, and nobody would deny that. Let us put it in perspective. On Friday we made very good progress. On Saturday we made very good progress. Yesterday morning we made quite good progress because we had a couple of procedural motions to deal with. Last night we made much better progress, so it is not true to say that this entire debate has been a filibuster. I acknowledge that some honourable senators opposite do have some genuine interest in this bill—not many—and would have been listening in their rooms. They would have heard Senator Evans say time and time again, `I acknowledge you have a valid point to raise here'—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was just trying to be nice to you, Senator.

—Senator Collins interjects that Senator Evans was just trying to be nice. That notion, coupled with Senator Evans, is a non sequitur. Let us not stretch the truth too far. Clause 11, which is one of the constitutional clauses, has been raised and postponed. It is acknowledged that it has to be looked at and more work needs to be done. More work has had to be done on whether the corporate structures conflict with the RDA; and that has been postponed. With the states, there is the question of whether, if they get agreement to proceed on a particular matter and then for some reason do not want to go ahead, but a month or so later do want to go ahead, they have to go through the whole process again.

PARA.TAB: There is a long list of these things that Senator Evans has acknowledged are sensible points that need to be raised and that he has tried to respond to. He has not been able to respond to most of them immediately. This is understandable since no-one else opposite has the capacity to share the load of the conduct of this bill. He has been left in this chamber on his own nearly all the time. No-one else opposite has got the capacity to do it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. During the delivery of Senator Kernot's speech, she mentioned that Parliament House staff approached her regarding their hours. As the parliamentary staff are employed by the parliament and not by the Democrats, I was wondering whether she was reflecting on the parliamentary staff in approaching a minor party to influence the conduct of the parliament. Mr Chairman, could you look into this matter and report back to the Senate and, if necessary, ask her to withdraw that reflection?
—Order! Senator Panizza, that is not a point of order but if there is a matter of concern to you, you should put it in writing to the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address the remarks that Senator Vanstone made about the reluctance of opposition senators to have a little bit of discipline put into this debate—not to have the debate curtailed but to at least have the debate concentrate on the bill, which would be a refreshing change. The guillotine has that effect.

PARA.TAB: As rarely as guillotines are applied in this chamber—and they are rare—we on this side of the House know that all of them, particularly this one, have something in common, and that is, that the happiest little vegemites in this chamber are the opposition senators across the road, because they have been praying for a guillotine for the last 24 hours. That is a fact. That is what they all wanted for Christmas, and that is what Santa Claus has brought them. They have got a guillotine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. You ruled previously on an allegation from the other side that we were anxious to go home. We made it quite clear that we were prepared to sit right through new year. Speaking for myself, absolutely the same thing applies. Would you ask Senator Collins to withdraw that imputation?
—Senator Bishop, there is no point of order.

—Everybody in this chamber knows the truth of that statement. We have debated this bill for over 40 hours so far. There is a sense of deja vu in this debate, with the recollection of a previous debate that went for almost this long. What was the other debate that came closest to it? I recall it very well. I followed that debate as carefully as I have followed this one. It was the debate establishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that also went for more than 30 hours—almost 40 hours. Why? Because the opposition did not want the legislation to pass. It was as simple as that.
—That's rubbish! Read the Hansard.

—That is right. The opposition talked it out and talked it out. Is the fact that both of these measures were designed to benefit Aboriginal people just a coincidence? I do not think so. In respect of exposing the truth of that, I return to what Senator Bishop said in the debate a few moments ago. She repeated that appalling statement that she made during the committee stage this morning when she talked about apartheid being taken out of South Africa and being introduced into Australia with this bill. How can people object and be sensitive about racial issues being brought into a debate when they make outrageous statements like that?

PARA.TAB: I repeat what I repeated this morning: no person has laid that nonsense to rest in a more effective way than Mr Justice Brennan of the High Court—the same judge who wrote the chief judgment on Mabo. In a case before the High Court years ago when the apartheid cry was on everyone's lips—it was the favourite analogy used by people who did not want to see Aboriginal people get a thing in this country—Mr Justice Brennan said in his judgment that the difference between land rights for Aboriginal people and apartheid is the difference between a home and a prison. Nobody has said it better than that.
Yesterday I attempted to read out a letter to the editor of a newspaper and was prevented from doing so because Senator Macdonald got very upset about the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ran out of time.

—No, have a look at the Hansard; it was ruled out of order on the grounds of irrelevance. That is why I was not able to complete it. I will read it now in response to what Senator Bishop said. As I said yesterday, everybody is aware—all Catholics in Australia would be—of Mother Mary Mackillop who, at an appropriate time, is about to become Australia's first saint.
—And a lot of non-Catholics.
—That is correct. A lot of people do not realise that she had a Northern Territory connection, but I am aware of it. Her brother, an equally distinguished Australian, Father Mackillop—
—You told us all this yesterday.

—No, I did not, but I will now. Her brother was a Jesuit missionary at the Daly River Mission in the Northern Territory, a man absolutely devoted to the cause of Aboriginal people and horrified by the prospects they then faced. Interestingly, this letter was written in 1892. It is a moving letter but it is still relevant today. In 1892, Father MacKillop wrote to the Sydney Morning Herald.
—You read it all out yesterday.
—I did not; but I will do so now. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, as such, does not recognise the right of the blackman to live. She marches onward, truly, but not perhaps the fair maiden we paint her. The blackfellow sees blood on that noble forehead, callous cruelty in her heart; her heel is of iron and his helpless countrymen beneath her feet. But we are strong and the blacks are weak; we have rifles, they but spears; we love British fairplay, and having got hold of this continent we must have every square foot. Little Tasmania is our model, and I fear, will be, until the great papers of Australia will chronicle, `with regret', the death of the last blackfellow. There is a feeling abroad too, which might be worded thus—it is in God's providence that the native races here, as elsewhere, must disappear before the British people. This, of course, I do not admit. The laws of nature, not God's providence, require that in given circumstances an inferior race will disappear before a superior, but so do they require that death will follow starvation, or be the consequence of poisoning.

Once again, this debate has amply and regrettably demonstrated something that was eloquently expressed to me yesterday by a prominent Aboriginal person who has been following the debate from the gallery: although 100 years have passed since that letter was written, and the face of Australia and its people have changed significantly, Aboriginal Australians are still far from achieving a secure and equal place in their own land. As occurred 10 minutes ago, analogies can still be drawn between measures such as this, to provide some measure of justice for Aboriginal people, and apartheid. It exposes the utter hypocrisy of the debate. It exposes the philosophical position the opposition has taken on this, which history will record very badly for the opposition when it is written in years to come.

PARA.TAB: A few moments ago, Senator Macdonald said, `This bill is the most important bill that has come before the parliament'. One could be forgiven for not believing that, having regard to the way the opposition has treated it. This most important bill to come before this parliament was not the subject of a single, solitary opposition amendment—not one! A bill with over 200 clauses—on the word of Senator Macdonald, the most important piece of legislation brought into this parliament—and not a single amendment moved. Why? What was the responsible position of this alternative government to this piece of legislation for the people of Australia?

Not only did the opposition determine that it would block the bill but, sight unseen, it took a policy decision in its party room to oppose every single, solitary amendment that the government moved. And the opposition proceeded to do so in the debate, sight unseen of the amendments, even when those same amendments unambiguously assist industry and were brought in at the request of industry. The Northern Territory fishing industry made representations to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in Darwin for amendments to be made to the bill. The very amendments that the Northern Territory fishing industry asked for were introduced into this chamber by the government and voted down by Senator Tambling and his colleagues.

The only members of the coalition that still have some shred of support for the bush that they are supposed to represent and the industries that they are supposed to represent are three National Party of Australia senators who had the intelligence, the principle and the morality to cross this chamber and vote for their constituency. It would have been immoral to do otherwise because it was said to me afterwards—do you know why, Mr Chairman, the opposition members voted against those amendments that would favour industry?—when members were crossing the floor, that they voted for it deliberately to make it bad law from their point of view. Deliberately!

I spent 10 years in opposition, five of them as leader. Oppositions have a role to play: to expose the government, to test the government and to make the government accountable. Also, as members of parliament, oppositions should assist to ensure that Australia gets the best laws it can have. The only way to do that is by amending laws it disagrees with. How irresponsible and immoral can it be—it is the height of irresponsibility and immorality in terms of service to the Australian parliament—when an opposition votes deliberately against a measure to make a bill worse from its perspective, to make it unworkable and to make it bad law.

After the vote it was said to me, `That is the reason we voted this way: we voted against the fishing industry, we voted against the pastoral industry and we voted against the mining industry in order to make this bill from our point of view worse law than it was'. That is the height of irresponsibility and hypocrisy from those opposite. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are voting against this bill because it is bad law. That is the reason we are voting against this bill. We are voting against this bill because we are interested in justice for all Australians. Mr Chairman, I wonder whether I could test your memory. I ask whether you know who said just 24 hours ago:

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating, in a measured fashion and I think reasonably sensible fashion, the substantive issues that are involved. We have been debating them for some 19 hours already, and we are—
I stress—

perfectly prepared to go on debating them until the debate is concluded. We will do so—and it is entirely appropriate that we should do so—because of the significance and importance of this legislation.

It was exactly the same man, Senator Gareth Evans, who came in here just half an hour ago and said that the debate on this bill had been destructive and negative. What happened? This was a debate which was constructive, measured and sussing out the problems with this bill before the parliament. What in fact happened in the last 24 hours? Senator Spindler assured people on this side of the chamber with these words: `This debate will take as long as we need; we will stay here'. So what happened?

TALK.START.PARA: —What for? Just to waste time.

—Senator Evans, whom I quote as my source, said just 24 hours ago that the debate was a very measured and sensible debate. I put it to Senator Spindler that something dramatic has happened. Just 24 hours ago Mr Keating said, `This debate will go on for as long as needed, until Boxing Day if necessary'. Today we have an attempt, which will be successful, to gag the debate on this vitally important bill before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The one thing I agree with Senator Collins on is that this is a very important bill. It affects the rights not only of Aboriginal people but of all Australians. It is perfectly appropriate that the parliament does its job. It is perfectly appropriate that the parliament goes through this bill clause by clause and examines the implications for all Australians. It was entirely predictable, given the contempt of Senator Evans and his colleagues for the parliamentary process in the Senate, that they would act in the way that they did. No-one would argue that it was anything other than entirely predictable. It is a great pity, I think, that the two minor parties, the Greens and the Democrats, have chosen to accommodate the government on this issue.

This bill was brought on after the official end of the parliamentary sittings. The government deliberately brought on this bill to cram it between the official end of the parliamentary sittings and Christmas, knowing full well that in the end enormous pressure would be put on the Greens and the Democrats. I have to say, as Senator Spindler is in the chamber, that it was no surprise on this side that the Democrats conspired with the government in this act. Unfortunately, the record of the Democrats over the last 12 months has been not to play the role of a constructive opposition but to give aid and comfort to the government to impose bill after bill for which it has no mandate.

It is a great pity that the Greens have also chosen to succumb. When we looked across this chamber we could see that the Greens had a genuine problem, and they agonised over it. There was an enormous pressure applied on them by Senator Gareth Evans, and I suspect the Democrats, to join with them in saying that the debate on this bill could be attenuated before Christmas. I do not care. In my view, this bill is of such importance that I would be very comfortable with sitting through. I think the people in this country want their parliaments to act in a way which will scrutinise carefully the legislation which comes before them to make sure that it is properly debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you had done it!

—I am telling Senator Spindler that Senator Evans, just 24 hours ago, said to us that we are debating this bill in a constructive and sensible fashion. I did not say that; Senator Gareth Evans over there said that. At the same time as Senator Evans said that, Senator Spindler was conspiring with him to gag this debate. That is the cross that he and his colleagues must wear.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems in this debate is that, every time we come to grips with this very difficult issue of people's rights and the balancing of them, anyone who suggests that maybe we should be thinking also about the rights of and justice to all Australians, that maybe we should be thinking along those lines, suddenly gets attacked by the Senator Evanses and the Senator Collinses of this world who say that we are being racist—the great attempt to bully the parliament and to bully the people. Apparently we cannot have a genuine debate on this bill.

I put it to Senator Evans that a lot of people out there—I count myself amongst them—are genuinely worried that this bill will set this nation on a course of not of one people with one destiny, as I said, but on a course of two people with two destinies. It is a genuine worry because the government is giving special rights and privileges in this bill. One clause which is coming up—clause 192—speaks about a national land fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to speak about it?

—I hope to speak about it but I will be gagged by those opposite. Thanks to Senator Spindler and his colleagues, I will be gagged. But here we are, setting up a special fund which will apply to only a particular race of people. I put it to those opposite that that raises genuine concerns and will raise very grave concerns amongst Labor Party supporters.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Bell quite finished? He can get up and have his say and explain to the people why he and his colleagues agree to attempt to cut off debate. It is bad enough that, when I get up to speak, Senator Bell carries on chipping away like this.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be order on both sides of the chamber, please.

—What in fact has happened in this great historic bill which has come before this parliament and about which there must be genuine debate is that Senator Bell, Senator Spindler and Senator Kernot want to get home for Christmas. We are not even postponing the bill so it can be debated next February. What we are doing is ramming it through this parliament. It is quite appropriate that we should have careful debate on clause after clause so that we can see the implications for all Australian people.
—We've had 60 hours' debate. You've just been filibustering.

—There is no doubt that you are acutely sensitive about this bill because, when you go out to speak to your traditional Labor supporters, they say, `Why are you giving other people rights to which we are not entitled?'. That is what Labor supporters are saying to you.
—Order! I remind Senator Kemp to address his remarks through the chair.
—It is a little difficult when one is being so seriously provoked by the Senator Schachts of this world.
—Perhaps Senator Schacht might interject less.
—Major issues of rights are involved in this bill which concern all Australians. We, at our peril, ignore those particular rights. It is important that we bring our people with us.

PARA.TAB: Our nation has moved forward by bringing our people with us. We are setting in train an exceedingly divisive bill which will not help relations between the Aboriginal people and the wider Australian community. It has the great potential to harm those relations. That is why it is important that this parliament debate it. That is why it is important that every clause be carefully considered. That is why I believe history will treat very savagely those people who conspired with the government to ram this bill through.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is a farce. It is amazing that Senator Kemp and his colleagues can ask for more time today when they spent eight hours debating just one clause yesterday. How can they justify that? In any case, the debate is not being cut off. They are getting another seven hours, to make a total of 48 hours.

PARA.TAB: We should look at some facts. We should look at the fact that members of the coalition came into this chamber having said prior to coming here that they would oppose every clause in the bill. They could not have made it clearer that they did not want justice for Aboriginal people. They wanted to protect their preconceived notions of fairness.

Where is fairness if Aboriginal people have been deprived of their birthright for 200 years and we are now trying to achieve a measure of justice—a basis for them to achieve equality in our community from here on in—yet coalition senators have said that they will oppose every clause of the bill? They have made that promise come true. They have opposed every clause in the bill, including those clauses, like clause 24, which would have helped some of their constituents—some of the miners and the pastoralist

I am indebted to Senator Vanstone for the doggerel she offered me. However, I would have been much more pleased if Senator Vanstone had produced an amendment—just one constructive amendment. We have had over 40 hours of debate, yet the coalition parties have not produced one constructive amendment to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even any sort of amendment.

—Not even any amendment, let alone a constructive one. There is another aspect to this process. Just as we have been debating in this chamber to find solutions to admittedly difficult and complex issues, we have also discussed these issues with Aboriginal people. We were discussing them with the negotiators from the A team, with the negotiators from the B team and with the legal advisers of those teams. We were discussing them with the government, we were discussing them with Senator Harradine, we were discussing them with the Greens. Where, at any of those discussions, were members of the coalition? Did they participate for just one moment? No. It is no wonder that they cannot contribute anything of content to this debate. Sure, I did say that, if necessary, we will sit until New Year's Eve. It was a genuine offer, but was this offer taken up?
—Yes, it was; it was taken up by me.

—The offer was not taken up. Has Senator Bishop produced one amendment? Yesterday we had quorums called over eight hours when there were two people on this side of the chamber and eight or nine people in the rest of the chamber. The opposition called quorum after quorum when it had two people on this side of the chamber. If that is not a waste of taxpayers' money, I do not know what is.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The coalition called one quorum yesterday at the express desire of Senator Evans. Could you ask Senator Spindler to tell us the truth when he is speaking if he cannot do anything else?
—Order! That is not a point of order.
—Quorums were called throughout the debate.
—It was yesterday.

—Whether it was yesterday or the day before is immaterial. The opposition called quorums while there were two people in here. The opposition wanted to watch a film outside while there were more than a dozen people in the chamber. If that is not wasting the taxpayers' money, I do not know what is. What has the opposition got to show for it? Can it show us one constructive amendment? Can it show us one constructive contribution that it has made to the debate? We have had over 40 hours of debate. We will have another seven hours. I hope that in those seven hours the opposition will make some constructive contribution to this debate.

—I support the proposition as moved by Senator Evans. I wanted to deal with one or two of the canards raised by Senator Kemp. For a start, let us be absolutely and specifically clear: the Australian Labor movement is united in support of this legislation at a political level, at a parliamentary level and at an industrial and organisational level. We are united in support of a just outcome for Australian Aboriginal people. There is no division evident on this side of the chamber. Division is evident only on the other side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp also talked about contempt. The only people who have demonstrated contempt for this chamber and for the parliament, have been the coalition speakers who have endlessly raised inane points of order and the like over the previous days' debate. It has been an absolute abuse of process and procedure. The entire country is now aware of it, judging by the editorials and commentaries—even talkback radio—critical of the coalition's performance on this most important bill. The judgment of history will be very hard on the coalition for its performance over the past several days.

When this debate is examined at length and in detail some time in years to come, there will be a policy position evident on only one side of the chamber. Counted as those who, like us, have sought a just outcome will be the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine—people who have been prepared to entertain the legislation on its merits—but not the coalition, which announced prior to the commencement of the debate and deliberations that it would be voting against everything.

No matter what answer Senator Evans gave, there was no give from the coalition on any clause. Not only were there no constructive amendments, there were not even suggestions as to constructive amendments which might be entertained. There has been only one policy framework evident and that has been the government's legislation, as amended from time to time with contributions from the Democrats, the Greens and from Senator Harradine—not from those opposite.

As the Liberal Party enters its 50th year, the judgment of Australian history upon it for its performance on Mabo will be one of disgrace with a capital D. There is no question about that. This proposal is one of reason. It gives us a structured framework for a debate. Everyone in this chamber knows that when we have a structured framework for debate, it concentrates the mind wonderfully, the level of debate rises and the contributions are better, more pointed and more purposeful. There is no question of that not eventuating. We are talking in terms of a national agenda, not the agenda for Richard Court and the Western Australian Liberal Party that many in the opposition have been endeavouring to run.

Time is very important to the coalition at the moment. We recognise that. We acknowledge that. There are so many problems outside the chamber that the coalition needs to deal with. The leadership problems of the Liberal Party are on the front page of the newspapers every day. We now see the classic Bishop-Peacock ticket emerging: arsenic and old lace. The opposition needs a lot of time outside the chamber to deal with that.

As I said yesterday, the opposition is bankrupt of ideas on Mabo because of the utter failure of the national leadership within its own parliamentary party. In fact, the coalition has effectively been hoist with its own petard. It is said often that there are a number of people opposite not ready for government. In this debate, we have seen that there are a lot of people opposite not prepared to act responsibly in opposition. The opposition has been hoist with its own petard. The opposition resolved early and with utter rigidity, inflexibility and sterility not to contribute and not to participate.

For those opposite who now cry crocodile tears for a debate, let me say this: a debate requires two points of view. It requires an original position, which has been provided by the government; amendments, which have been provided by the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine; and an alternative. We will not accept for one moment Richard Court's legislation as a legitimate national alternative. It is not a legitimate national alternative, but it is the agenda that the federal Liberal Party has been running. Senator Campbell is aware of that; he is too clever not to be. The Court agenda is not an acceptable national alternative.

What did we see happen yesterday? I will put this on the record right now for my friend and colleague Senator Gareth Evans. Rarely in the history of the Australian parliament have we seen a more outstanding performance from an Australian minister in terms of having knowledge across the breadth and depth of legislation. It was an outstanding performance that was recognised not only by those on this side of the chamber and beyond but also privately by those on the other side of the chamber.

What happened yesterday? Some questions were legitimate and some were foolish. At one stage, one senator said that he was involved in a general rave. I do not think that was a legitimate comment. It is true that there were some legitimate questions, but there was also a lot of time wasting, frustration, delay and obstruction—not necessarily from people such as Senator Ellison but from many others.

Had we advanced by the end of the day? Virtually no progress had been made. Senator Vanstone said, `It is a bit of a shame that in 4 1/2 hours we only dealt with half a clause'. What do the Australian people think of that? If the Australian people knew in detail the model of the opposition's behaviour over the last two days, they would think that this chamber had been reduced to political bankruptcy.

We have produced a bill that is comprehensive and detailed. We have been prepared to be flexible, reasonable and entertain commonsense when people have alternative points of view to be raised. We have been prepared to accommodate Senator Harradine, the Democrats and the Greens whenever they have been reasonable. We have been prepared to be swayed by argument. But those opposite have not tried to do that. They have delayed, obstructed and frustrated.

This Mabo debate will be a real stain upon the opposition's history as a political organisation. In summary, as of midnight yesterday, all we did was a waste of time. We had not progressed or advanced. We had not gone any further. This chamber has been debauched often by the conservative parties in its history. Yesterday was a low point in the history of Australian parliamentary procedure. I say that with utter confidence now. That will be the judgment of Australian history.

Those opposite who are legitimately concerned with the impact of this legislation ought to take aside their colleagues, such as those who said, `I am embarked upon a general rave', which was absolutely and utterly appalling. Thank God for Hansard and its accuracy. Speeches are better when the guillotine is applied. This framework will be better for the debate and its structure. The allocation of time is a fair system and we know exactly the framework within which we have to operate.

At this point of Christmas 1993, and for the benefit of everyone in the chamber and beyond and everyone within the Australian electorate who is following this debate, I ask these open questions of the coalition: what is its policy? Where is it? To what principle is it committed? Senator Bishop said, `We are committed to a better way'. Where is the evidence of the better way? What is the alternative way to go? It has not been suggested in day after day of debate in the chamber or beyond. It has not been suggested at any level of the coalition—within neither the Liberal or National parties. I acknowledge, as other speakers on this side of the chamber have said, that three members of the National Party were prepared to stand up and vote on their conscience on one of the issues.

The opposition takes the easy path of opposition: `Vote it down, oppose, be obstructive and negative. Don't be creative; don't cause too much internal turmoil. The arsenic and old lace ticket might save us yet'. Its current position is arsenic and old lace. I wish it well with that. But on Mabo it is an absolute and utter disgrace.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I seek your clarification. There are a great deal of matters that we want to discuss. We could be prevented from doing this if the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens exercise a share of the limited time available that well exceeds their relevance to this chamber. —Oh come on!
—Or giving minor groups—

It would be easier if the Liberal Party and the National Party could make their own arrangements as to whom I call when I call the opposition. —On the point of order; a very large number of amendments are to be moved by the Greens in particular and also the Democrats relating to the last area that we will spend three hours debating. I think it is only fair that they should be given a sufficient number of calls to be able to move and explain those particular amendments. I am not talking about the discussion more generally. Mr Chairman, I hope that you will bear that in mind when we get to those parts of the debate.

—That includes Senator Harradine if he has an amendment to move. I am talking specifically about amendments which have been foreshadowed. I think honourable senators who have clearly foreshadowed an intention to move should be given the opportunity to explain them.
—On the point of order: they should have thought of that before they agreed to guillotine the bill.
—I propose to proceed as I have done previously and you can feel free to criticise me if I get it wrong. I am conscious of what has been said by both Senator Evans and Senator Ian Macdonald.
—I seek leave to ask the minister a question about these time allocations.
