TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the chair is that government amendments 23, 24 and 25, government sheet 75, and Green amendment 1A to clauses 50 to 53 inclusive be agreed to.

—When we were interrupted by Senator Gareth Evans, I was asking a question of the minister who was then involved. I am not quite sure who is involved now; Senator Collins obviously had little idea of what he was talking about. I hope that Senator Evans is back to deal with this matter. I was trying to raise the question of what impact the amendments, by addition of subclause (7) to clause 53, would have on local authorities around Australia. Senator Collins—who clearly demonstrated that he had no idea—was telling me that local authorities could not collect rate money by dealing with the land, as happens with every other Australian. Senator Collins was indicating that that would not have much effect anyway because there was not much money involved, again clearly demonstrating his ignorance of these matters.

PARA.TAB: I hope Senator Evans appreciates that being able to recover money will have a major impact on local authority finances. Very often owners abandon land, walk away and there are huge amounts of rates owing. The only way out is to deal with the land. I was trying to get a sensible comment from the minister on how this will affect local governments in their ability to recover moneys owing. I emphasise that very often rates are owing because local authorities have actually provided services to land and the only way they can recover the money is through rates. If people refuse to pay them, their only recourse is to deal with the land.

I wonder whether the minister could explain to me how this would happen. In the case of a body corporate, if the body corporate has no money and is sued, where does that leave the local authority? Do local authorities still have to provide services to those lands in the face of a refusal or an inability to pay the rates?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only restriction that is imposed by the legislation in this particular subclause, which is incorporated by way of amendment, is upon the sale of the land itself. It would be incompatible with the very concept of native title that land could be sold off for defaults of that kind. It is not true of native title equivalent, which might be given in the context of a pastoral lease conversion exercise, as we said yesterday. The pastoral lease in that situation would certainly be able to be sold and the native title equivalent holders would be left lamenting.

PARA.TAB: The remedy for the aggrieved local government authority, or whoever in this situation, would still be, for example, to have a forced sale of stock, farm machinery or other movable assets of that particular kind which were not the land itself but did represent a realisable asset. A sale of stock is the obvious way to get at someone who is defaulting on a debt in this kind of situation. Given the order of magnitude of the debts compared with the likely value of the stock in any pastoral exercise, that is probably a realistically available route to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —That presupposes that there is some stock there.
—True.

—There are vast tracts of land like this. I wish to clarify this situation. In the first two minutes I am, quite rightly, being urged by my colleagues that I have had my 2 1/2 minutes for this hour, so I have to sit down.
—Order! Pursuant to a resolution of the Senate, it is now 1 o'clock and the sitting of the Senate—
—Mr Chairman, I seek leave to finish this question, get Senator Evans's answer and the sitting could then be suspended.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can Senator Evans just confirm—and local government would be very interested in this—that if moneys are owing on land that is subject to native title, there is no way it can be taken back for payment of rents. They can take the stock and the machinery, but not the land. Is that correct?

—That is the clear effect of the proposed clause. It is related to the character of the title we are talking about here, which is different in kind, quality and nature from other forms of interest in land and justifies, in our judgment, that degree of discrimination. We do need to think in terms of the other alternative remedies that are available. Perhaps some further thought could be given to other possibilities in the situation where there is no easily realisable stock or machinery. It is a fair point that Senator Macdonald is making, but it is one that, hopefully, will not arise too often in practice.

—I refer to Greens amendment 1A, which has already been circulated and moved. It has also been debated already but was deferred to this point until the corporate body amendments were dealt with. The purpose of the amendment is simply to ensure that this bill does not have the unintended effect of denying Aboriginal and Islander people protection against existing discriminatory laws, either state or federal. Clause 6A ensures that the bill, like all other laws, will be interpreted as not affecting the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act and will thereby implement parliament's intention. Subclause (2) ensures that the validation of past acts by or in accordance with this act are not affected by the clause.

—I have a couple of questions which relate to clauses 52 and 53. In relation to clause 52, Senator Ellison earlier today asked about the moneys being a statutory appropriation and coming from the consolidated revenue fund. I would like the minister, when he gets the opportunity, to address why that is applicable and why it cannot be a matter of normal appropriations that are subject to parliamentary scrutiny. I am sure there are good reasons for it, but I think the chamber and the people of Australia deserve to know why this is a unique situation and why it should be a standing appropriation under that clause.

PARA.TAB: I also want to raise some points under clause 53, which returns us to the hoary chestnut that we have spent a couple of hours debating; that is, the use of the body corporates to be the trustees on behalf of the native titleholders. We have already debated whether or not section 10(3) of the Racial Discrimination Act could be jeopardised. The key point is, where the body corporate is acting on behalf of the common law holders and where an agreement made by a body corporate needs to be binding on the common law holders, what does the government envisage the mechanisms would be for dealing, for example, with minority interests?

If a group of native titleholders appointed a body corporate to act on its behalf under this clause, and a minority interest disagreed with the decision, representation or action of the body corporate, the situation may arise where there may be no consensus. Could the minister suggest to us whether or not the general provisions of company law and corporations as we know them would apply? If that is the case, are the normal roles of directors to apply to these body corporates?

The minister did indicate in earlier debate when this came up under another clause that these things would need to be subject to regulation and further decisions, but the minister also told us that these regulations were in an advanced state of drafting. If that is the case, the chamber needs to know how this problem is going to be resolved. Under the Mabo High Court decision and the Racial Discrimination Act, 10(3), there is quite a clear message that taking away the management of the land from the native titleholders would be contravening the RDA. I do not want to reopen that debate; we do not have the time to do that.

The crucial question comes down to the relationship between the native titleholders and the body corporate. Where a dispute arises between the native titleholders and the body corporate itself, clearly one can arrive at a situation where there are a number of native title parties. If such a dispute arose, they would have cause for action where it was clearly demonstrable that the body corporate was not acting in the interests of a native title party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question about Commonwealth compensation being payable from consolidated revenue under clause 52, I am advised that is a quite normal provision in any statutory environment where liability is established or determined by other provisions of the legislation. In this instance, the reference is to

SPEECH.PARA: . . . compensation payable by the Commonwealth in accordance with this Division—
and:
. . . amounts to be spent by the Commonwealth in acquiring property or providing goods or services—

in order to comply with a specific form of possible recommendation by the tribunal, set out in 49(6)(b). It is perfectly normal for legislation to contain an appropriation clause in order to give the statutory authority for the appropriation of moneys to meet those liabilities. Otherwise, we would have to have in the annual appropriations each year a specific authority to pay amounts of compensation determined in the preceding year or in anticipation of the subsequent year. There has to be statutory authority somewhere for the moneys to be actually taken out of consolidated revenue, and this is it—and it is a very common provision.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell's second query goes to decision making practices, so far as the body corporate is concerned in its relationship with the individual titleholders and perhaps a dissident minority and so on. Basically, these rules will be the subject of prescription under regulations. Under our amendment 75, clause 53A(4) says that the regulations may make provision, among other things, for the nature of any consultation with common law holders. Again, 53C(d) enables regulations with respect to consultation with and actions taken in accordance with the directions of the common law holders in performing any of their functions.

I would envisage, among other things, regulations under these particular clauses being of a similar character to the Northern Territory land rights legislation. In terms of dealing with this question of consents of traditional Aboriginal owners, there is, for example, a reference in section 77A of the 1976 act which says that regard must be had to traditional Aboriginal decision making processes. They are not necessarily majority-minority voting processes but rather consultative and consensual in character. It may be that evidence would need to be taken if there were any dispute as to respective minority versus majority interests as to the nature of those decision making processes.

What I am saying in short is that this is clearly an issue that has to be addressed in order that we get certainty in all the kinds of decisions that have to be made and subsequently implemented. A greater degree of certainty is expected to be invested by the regulations once they are promulgated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens if native title applicants, of which the minister has already admitted there could be a number, do nominate a number of bodies corporate to represent them? Clearly there would be a dispute that would certainly need to be resolved to overcome the RDA problems.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in subsection (4) the legislation alludes to the `prescribed bodies'. Does the minister envisage a whole range of new bodies being incorporated, formed or created; or is it safe to assume that, in the real world, the lands councils that exist already are most likely to take on those roles; and how far have the regulations got in the drafting of those?
I also refer to clause 54(2), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The body corporate must, in accordance with the regulation, also hold or deal with any other amount that may be paid to it as a result of any agreement in relation to the surrender—
which we have already dealt with. We know that it can be surrendered to the Commonwealth. But it also refers to:
transfer or other dealing with the native title rights and interests that may be authorised by the regulations . . .

I have not, in the entire arduous debate we have had on this subject, heard any reference to—and I cannot find any in the legislation—anything that can be done with the native title rights other than to surrender them to the Crown. Leases can obviously be issued, and so forth, but the word `transfer' certainly connotates a transfer of the native title right. If that is the case, we should be told by the government how that transfer is envisaged and between what parties some transfer could take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter question, it is the case that the only formal provision for alienation of the interest that the legislation deals with is the surrender to the Crown, but it needs to be remembered that the common law native title may itself be transferable, alienable, in accordance with the particular principles that govern that community as identified and determined by the courts. It may be that in a particular part of the country the notion of property transfer was in fact sufficiently well developed to enable that to be picked up and applied in a modern day context. That option is still open. But, apart from that, Senator Campbell is right; it is just the surrender situation.

PARA.TAB: In terms of who might be prescribed bodies, it is certainly not intended that the land councils be bodies for this purpose. What we are talking about is specifically established bodies corporate—no more than one for each native title situation. We are not envisaging a multiplicity of them. The whole point of the exercise is to have a clearly discernible legal entity which can be the vehicle through which the rest of the world can deal with the title situation. As we have said several times, whether or not the title itself is formally vested in the body corporate will now be a matter of option, but the body corporate must itself exist at least as the agent of the native titleholders in order that there is that capacity to effectively deal in a modern day context where people cannot be expected to go out in the bush and have traditional meetings in order to do basic transactions.

As to what kind of bodies may be prescribed bodies, I think the concepts that are broadly available are formal non-profit corporate entities under various corporations law statutes around the place or trust arrangements of one kind or another. I am also reminded that there is a Commonwealth Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act in existence which, through this creation of a kind of statutory corporate entity, creates another class of entities that would satisfy the kind of thing that this clause has in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arising out of the questioning of the minister by Senator Campbell in relation to the transfer of native title—it is not on that point but flows from it—I am concerned with the vesting of compensation in a prescribed corporate body. What happens to it after that? I take it that the legislation says, `As soon as it is paid to the corporate body, that is the end of it'. What I am looking at is where the community is made up of women, children, elders and infants—in other words, a wide range of people. Does the body corporate have to hold on to it for the benefit of the children or can it all be blown in one go? What is the story there?

—The distribution of funds in that situation would be entirely at the discretion of the native titleholders themselves. These bodies corporate are not intended to be independent exercisers of power or authority. They are merely meant to be a formal legal vehicle through which the majority or other will, however determined, of the community can prevail. I hesitate to use the word `majority' because communal practices of the Aboriginal titleholders might not operate on a majoritarian principle. It might be a consensual principle of the kind that we have talked about.

PARA.TAB: The concept clearly is that the body corporate has no independent decision making authority or no role to play otherwise than as a vehicle for the will to be exercised of the individual people who make up the native titleholders. How that works in practice will depend from situation to situation. That is why the legislation is fairly flexibly drafted in terms of the kinds of bodies that might have body corporate status. The relationship between the body corporate and the native titleholders is intended to be pretty clear. I think it is clear in the legislation.

"Note: The person mentioned in paragraph (1)(d) is the registered native title claimant. This is the person to whom notices, for example under paragraph 28(2)(b), are to be given.".

The purport of those amendments is in each case technical. They are related to tribunal and court procedures. I do not think that there is a single issue of policy sensitivity among them, but I am happy to answer any questions that might be asked in that respect.

PARA.TAB: For the sake of clarifying the record, the government will support amendment No. 23 of the Australian Democrats which has just been moved by Senator Kernot. We will also support amendment No. 22A of the Greens (WA). We will not support the Greens' amendment No. 24 to clause 58.

In anticipation of what may be now moved by the Democrats in relation to tribunal and court procedures, I indicate that we will accept the Democrats' proposed amendment No. 27, but we are unable to accept—if they are moved—amendments Nos 25 and 26 of the Democrats.
Amendments (by Senator Spindler) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: 25.Clause 67, page 40, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Applications not settled are to be referred to the Federal Court

SPEECH.PARA: "67(1)Upon application of any party, a claim for a declaration of native title currently pending but not yet at trial as at the date of commencement of this Act in any court must be transferred to the Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: "67(2)If an application is accepted under section 57 and the Tribunal does not make a determination under section 63, 64 or 66, the Registrar must lodge the application to the Federal Court for decision.".

SPEECH.PARA: 26.Clause 74, page 42, add the following subclause:

"(2)Upon application of any party, a claim for a declaration of native title currently pending but not yet at trial as at the date of commencement of this Act in any court must be transferred to the Federal Court.".
27.Clause 108, page 53, omit subclause (2).

TALK.START.PARA: —I should be very much obliged to know the effects of these amendments.
—We are coming back to that.

—It is very confusing. We are dealing sometimes with different aspects and different policy issues in some of these measures. What are we doing? Are we formally putting them on the table and then coming back separately to each one?

PARA.TAB: CHAIRMAN—We are going to have a cognate discussion. We are getting the amendments in front of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had in mind that there would be some explanation given at the time of moving as to what the amendments were about. I did not think it was necessary in my case to give a great explanation because there is a whole raft of amendments. The amendments are technical in character and are sufficiently explained in the explanatory memorandum. Perhaps in relation to the other amendments that are to be moved in future, where there is no explanatory memorandum on the table or previously circulated, it would be appropriate for some explanation to be given. That is what I had in mind, rather than a purely formal moving because, under the guillotine procedures, the mere fact that the amendments have been circulated would be enough to ensure that they are voted upon at the end of the process.

—I will deal with Democrat amendments Nos 25, 26 and 27. As I mentioned previously, amendment No. 23 is correcting a typographical error only and amendment No. 24 is withdrawn. Amendments 25 and 26 seek to enable native title applicants to choose a forum; we believe that this general principle which has been included in the bill should also be available to people who are in the early stages of a proceeding in a state court. These amendments therefore provide that, if people's applications are in the early stages, they should have the choice of removing their cases to the Federal Court.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 27 deals with the limitation that the government has put in the bill on the age of people serving on the tribunal—the presidential members. The age limit in the bill is 65. It is, however, very clear that in Aboriginal culture wisdom and accumulated knowledge increase and repose in people of advanced age. That should not be lost by preventing people of an age greater than 65 from serving on the tribunal. We are therefore seeking to remove that age limit and I understand the government is supporting that measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 22A and 24, as circulated, address the powers of the registrar on native title claimants. The Greens have requested that the registrar not be allowed to refuse an application if it conflicts with a later application. We believe that the appropriate role for the registrar is to record the applicants and make a determination only once at the appropriate time rather than have native title claimants put in a worse position of having to prove their case twice. We are grateful the government has agreed to this amendment and that the Democrats support it because it is important that the new procedure for registration be made as easy as possible for registration, followed by careful determination.

PARA.TAB: The government has indicated that it will not support amendment No. 24. The Greens took exception to the powers conferred on the registrar in clauses 147 to 151—for example, the power to take evidence and to make determinations. However, we have not gained support for this amendment and will not push it. We simply present it as something worthy of mention.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—Are you moving amendment No. 25?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. We are withdrawing amendment No. 25.

—I want to address some comments to the minister on government amendment No. 28 relating to clause 64, which has subsequent repercussions on clause 141. The amendment of subclause (d) would mean that native title claimants need no longer show the tribunal that they have a prima facie case. Provided that the parties have reached an agreement, the tribunal can determine native title to an area. In these circumstances there will no longer be an objective determination of the existence of native title.

PARA.TAB: This has implications in the mining area. For example, an unscrupulous mining company could make spurious use of the legislation through sham claimants, which could lead to considerable conflict. There could be consent determinations of native title to land that does not exist. Unscrupulous companies could use sham claimants to get an agreement on the use of land. The proposed tribunal process is a mockery of normal legal processes in Australia. I would like the minister to comment on the implications of this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling is completely understating the extent to which the tribunal would continue to exercise a role as a guardian of the integrity of the legislation. The tribunal has to be satisfied that a determination to endorse an agreement would be appropriate in the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tambling said, this is one of a group of similar amendments which remove the requirement that native titleholders establish a prima facie case in respect of applications for determination or variation of native title or compensation where that application is resolved by agreement between the parties. If there is agreement, it is thought not appropriate to put the applicants to the difficulties and the expense of establishing a prima facie case with the documentation and so on that would need to be associated with that.

But—and this is the important but—the tribunal instead will have to be satisfied that the agreed determination would be appropriate in the circumstances, and if there is any character of sham about the arrangement then the tribunal could be expected to identify that and deal with it appropriately. For completeness in explaining this amendment I should say that where an application is unopposed, a prima facie case would still have to be established in order to satisfy the tribunal and similar amendments are made to clauses 66 and 80. The requirement that the tribunal be satisfied about appropriateness is, I suppose, a slightly lower test than the prima facie case test, but it is still enough to demonstrate clearly that the tribunal has an obligation to satisfy itself that this is not a sham kind of transaction that is being entered into.

Another point that is worth making is that the parties in this determination process would include any objectors to the claim, and that could well be a state government. It is not a matter simply of the parties, for the purpose of the determination process and the endorsement process, being the native title claimants and the miner or whoever they have reached agreement with. It would also be perfectly competent for a state government to play that role, and it might be expected that a state government would be conscious of the need to maintain the integrity of the process.

There is one further point that is worth making. In most judicial proceedings, including those completely removed from this Aboriginal context, the court does not inquire at all into an agreement reached between parties. Life is too short for courts to be peering behind a particular result. Here, however, the tribunal is given that role because of a conscious decision on the Commonwealth government's part to introduce some such safety net, if you like, to guard against just the kind of concerns that Senator Tambling has expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that Senator Evans seems to be implying that the guardian in determining these cases will have to be the state or territory governments. That will always cast them in the role of the seeming opponent. I am certainly aware that whenever the Northern Territory government has had to take that particular role with regard to testing Aboriginal claims under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act it has always been painted into the picture, when it seeks to represent a community view or a community interest, as therefore being the ogre who is at all times seeking to oppose any Aboriginal claimant. I ask the minister what sort of guidelines and systems will be provided to the tribunal to ensure that all determinations will be objective, will in fact test the bona fides and will not result in unscrupulous or spurious claims being made.

—It needs to be remembered that the tribunal process is essentially an inquisitorial one with the tribunal having the capacity to subpoena and require evidence to be put before it as it thinks appropriate. It is not just a prisoner of the limited material that the immediate parties involved in the case might want to put before it. I would have thought it is the tribunal itself rather than the state or territory government that would be properly described as the guardian of the process. In fact, that is the description I used in that context. Still, if state governments are going to play their own part in preserving the integrity of these systems, on occasion they have to be prepared to take some unpopular action and to run the risk of perhaps misguided criticism. That is life.
—I will run through the comments and perhaps pepper questions throughout my address so that we can make—
—Don't pepper too many at once because it is a bit hard to keep track of them all.

—I will try to keep within the time constraints as well. Firstly, in relation to clause 55, as I see it, none of those applications would be able to be made until regulations are brought in setting up how those applications are to be made—providing for forms and things of that nature. I know the minister said that the regulations were in hand but could he confirm that those applications are dependent upon the regulations being drawn up, and whether there is any time frame as to when those regulations will be drawn up?

PARA.TAB: Also in relation to clause 55, how does the minister envisage dealing with the situation—I have actually come across it in the north-west of Australia—where a group of Aboriginal people belong to different clans? One applicant might purport to make an application on behalf of the people concerned. Another clan within the group may say, `We don't want to be a party to that application. We want to conduct our own because we have something different to say. Our clan used a different area and we want it for our own little group and not for the people as a whole'. In other words, there is fragmentation. How does the minister envisage dealing with that sort of situation in relation to clause 55 and the regulations as they might relate to those applications?

In relation to clause 56, I notice there has to be a declaration by an applicant. Does that require an Aboriginal in a remote area to make out a statutory declaration pursuant to the Evidence Act or the relevant evidence acts of the states, or is that simply a declaration of no legal punitive effect?

TALK.START.PARA: —Which clause are you referring to?
—Clause 56(1)(a).

—There are answers to all of those questions. As to Senator Ellison's first question, it is the case that regulations will be needed to more specifically prescribe the information that is required to be submitted with an application. It will not be left to just the rather broad language of clauses 56 and 57. Those regulations are being drafted at the moment and are expected to be ready for promulgation if not by 1 January then certainly quite soon thereafter.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Ellison asks about different clans wanting to make different sorts of claims. It is the case that multiple applications can be made and in some situations they are quite likely to be made. One of the reasons for the very broad notification provisions in the legislation is to ensure that all relevant interests including, possibly, competing interests, are picked up in the application and subsequent determination process.At the end of the day, it is for the tribunal to sort out who is entitled to what so far as native title status is concerned.

It needs to be appreciated—I do not think this point has been made before in the 40-odd hours we have been debating this bill, but I think it is quite a relevant one—that we could envisage a situation of multiple determinations of native title rights with respect to the same area of ground. One native title right vested in one particular claimant might be a kind of leasehold interest—to try to translate that into contemporary property law terminology. Another kind of native title interest that could perhaps exist simultaneously with that might be one that was confined to access rights, rights of entrance to visit a particular sacred site, or perhaps a hunting-foraging right of that kind—native title right expressed in rather more limited terms.

It is envisaged that the process of determining competing claims and of possibly resolving situations of overlapping claims will be, in some cases, a quite complex one, but I think the tribunal will have sufficient flexibility and authority to unravel it. Part of the consideration it will have in mind is the necessity of having the maximum possible clarity about the nature and extent of that title, particularly when it affects dealings with third parties, be it governments, mining companies, other pastoralists or whatever. They are the issues that will need to be sorted out by the tribunal.

As to the question of possibly less sophisticated native title applicants being required to swear formal affidavits and so on, that is not really what is contemplated by clause 56. Senator Ellison will notice that paragraph 56(1)(c) talks in terms of the name and address of the person who is to be taken to be the claimant. That is intended to confer a kind of representative status on one individual, perhaps on behalf of the other applicants in his group. There will need to be some identification of who all the applicants are, but, in terms of having declarations by applicants and so on, it is envisaged that one such declaration by one such individual, provided he or she is representative, will probably be sufficient for that purpose and that is the person who has to be named for the purposes of paragraph 56(1)(c).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has mentioned the giving of notice of the application and I want to take him up on that. I realise that the government has an amendment 26 to clause 59 which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any person who holds a proprietary interest in any of the area covered by the application, being an interest that is registered in a register of interests in relation to land or waters maintained by the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory;
Is the government acknowledging in that amendment that the registered proprietor of the property be given notice?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—This is the point that concerns me and I think it was raised at one stage during the Senate committee. What about giving notice to anyone else, such as local authorities, the local council, or perhaps even a person who has an interest in the property not by way of being a registered proprietor but, say, by having a mortgage on the property? That person is not to know that there is an application going on in relation to that land and that it is the subject of a claim. Has any thought been given to notifying someone in that position?

—Senator Ellison will notice that, in addition to the specific obligation to give notice to all persons whose interests may be affected, which we are making absolutely clear in a provision that we are adding so far as proprietary interest holders are concerned, there is a requirement in paragraph 59(2)(b) for public notification—gazettal or whatever the appropriate means is of notifying the public. That would be a catch-all provision that would, no doubt, ensure that finance companies that perhaps have some kind of charge over the property in question—maybe over stock or something on that property—would be notified about it. A more formal proprietary interest such as that possessed by a mortgagee, for example, would be registered in the land titles registry systems of every jurisdiction and that makes it a relatively easy matter for the registrar to identify and notify the relevant interest holders in the case that Senator Ellison has just put.
—So the registrar will do that; go and look at the title and do a search?

—It is his obligation to do so, if he is allowed to. Senator Ian Macdonald said yesterday, the day before or last week—I am losing track of time—that the Western Australian state government might be minded to ban access by Commonwealth authorities or institutional representatives to such public registers. I said then that that was a pretty extraordinary suggestion, and I say it again now.
—It's only the NFF we are banning.
—That ought to be put on the record.
—Yes. I think you can put that on the record; twice.
—Senator Campbell and Senator Panizza are demonstrating a less than magnificent obsession—a very odd obsession in the circumstances. The NFF is a fine body of men and women.
—Like the HIA.

—No. The HIA has a bit of distance to go to re-win its spurs. The NFF has done a fine job in the national interest. It ought to be recognised and accepted for the quality of its input into the public policy debate on this, which has been conspicuously more substantial and constructive than the kind of input we have had from those opposite in the last few days. Be that as it may, let us get back to the bill. Perhaps I can help Senator Ellison in some other respect.

—I have a question about the role of the registrar, who, as I see it, has the primary role of accepting applications. It seems that the presumption is that he or she accepts them unless they are frivolous or vexatious. Clause 71 states that the registrar can join with the applicants and assist with their applications. Can the minister reconcile this principle where a person who adjudicates on the application by saying whether it is frivolous or vexatious, could well have had a hand in putting it together? In a way, it is appealing from Caesar unto Caesar—the registrar helps the applicant puts together the application then, perhaps wearing a different hat, assesses whether it is frivolous or vexatious. Does the minister not see a problem with that?

—I think Senator Ellison has misread the provision. It makes it clear that, if the registrar is of the opinion that the application is frivolous or vexatious or that prima facie the claim cannot be made out, then pursuant to proposed new clause 57(2) he must refer the application to a presidential member. So if the registrar is of that opinion, it is the registrar's obligation to refer it to the presidential member and the presidential member makes the actual determination.
—Not must.

—Must. Clause 57(2) states that if the registrar is of the opinion mentioned in paragraphs 1(a) or 1(b)—that is, that the application is frivolous or vexatious or that prima facie the claim cannot be made out—the registrar must refer the application to a presidential member. It is then the obligation of the presidential member to make the determination accordingly.

—Nonetheless, a person in a judicial capacity will be assisting the applicant to draft an application and then have to do something as a result of the application—that is, make a determination one way or another whether it is frivolous or vexatious. In all other courts, judicial officers do not assist claimants, defendants or otherwise; that can be done by someone else. I am not saying they should not have the help—there is Legal Aid, other bodies and everybody else—I am saying that it cuts across a principle which flows throughout courts, be they local, supreme, district or whatever.

PARA.TAB: Court officers do not engage in providing legal advice and helping people fill out forms because that compromises their position to some extent. They can tell people what form to file and where to file it—all sorts of things like that—but they cannot go as far as this, where the registrar can actually help someone make out an application. I believe it is undesirable and I would like to hear the minister's comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case under clause 71 that the registrar can give such assistance as the registrar considers reasonable to help people prepare applications and so on. But it needs to be appreciated that the registrar is not, himself or herself, a judicial officer or even a quasi judicial officer. That function is reserved for the presidential members.

PARA.TAB: The registrar is not making a final determination about frivolity or vexatiousness or the absence of a prima facie case. The most that the registrar is doing is operating, in the first instance, as a vehicle for the presiding member making that decision if the registrar thinks there are grounds on which that might be an appropriate decision. So there is a separation of functions. The registrar who does play this kind of more active assistance role is not the person who actually decides, under the revised language in front of us, that the application ought to be struck from the register. That is for someone else who has not been as close to the circumstances of it to decide.

Moreover, there is a later provision in the legislation regarding objectors. It is not a matter of an objector, once the claim has survived the first process, then going directly to a presiding officer; it is a matter of an objector's application to strike out being made to the tribunal itself. That provision is contained in clause 140, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal may dismiss an application if, at any stage of an inquiry relating to the application, the Tribunal is satisfied that the application is frivolous or vexatious.

Again, clause 141 has the same provision, but this time in relation to inability to make out a prime facie case. The reference to any stage of the application or any stage of an inquiry relating to an application means that at a very early stage, right at the threshold, in fact, of the inquiry being embarked upon, such an application can be made. I think that again offers something of an arms-length way of dealing with these sorts of situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one final point—and as we are short of time, I do not want to belabour this. The registrar does have some decision making role. The registrar could decide, conceivably, to accept an application which might be frivolous or vexatious. The minister might say that further down the track the tribunal may throw it out. Of course, being in the front line, the registrar is the first point of contact. The registrar could assist the claimant, accept the claim and then the claim could be processed further.

PARA.TAB: But we have to bear in mind that there might be multiple claims. A rival group could make a claim and then get knocked back. That group would see that the registrar helped this other group, whose claim was accepted, while its application was knocked back and sent off to a presidential member. What I am talking about is the danger of perceptions of some sort of bias. It is essential that this does not exist in any judicial system or quasi judicial system.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say about that is that if there is any real bias, or if there is any evidence of the registrar acting on an improper basis or employing irrelevant criteria and so on, then ordinary administrative law principles would apply and appropriate action could be taken by the aggrieved party which felt that it had been treated in a different way without the justification for that to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, then, is the point of clause 57? It provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Registrar must accept the application unless the Registrar considers that . . . the application is frivolous or vexatious.

Surely that is putting the registrar in that invidious position that Senator Ellison talks about and the minister's only answer is that at some later stage the tribunal can come in and knock it out. Why does the government put the registrar in the position where he is facilitating an application which, of course, he would never then knock out as frivolous or vexatious?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston is reading from the old clause 57 in the bill, rather than clause 57 as amended. Both clauses 56 and 57 have been amended so that some of the provisions that were previously in clause 57 spelling out what have to be put into the application, have now been folded back into clause 56. Clause 57, as now proposed to be amended by Green amendment 22A, which is the relevant provision that has been accepted by the government, sets out the role of the registrar in a rather different way. I will repeat what it states for the benefit of Senator Alston. Amended clause 57(1) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If the requirements of section 56 are complied with in relation to the application—
and they are essentially the formal requirements of particular information, declarations, certain initial evidence and so on—
the Registrar must accept it, unless he or she is of the opinion:
(a) that the application is frivolous or vexatious; or
(b) that prima facie the claim cannot be made out.

If the registrar is of that opinion, that is not the end of the matter. The registrar then passes it on to the presiding officer for the presiding officer to make the judgment that it is frivolous or fails to make a prima facie case.

PARA.TAB: The registrar is, if you like, not much more than the gatekeeper in this respect. His basic obligation is just to ensure that the applications are in proper order, to keep track of what is going on, to make the appropriate notifications and all those things. But if he is of the view that there is something so insubstantial about an application that it satisfies either of these descriptions, then he is the one who can trigger the action by the presiding officer without the need to go through the business of objections from other competing interest holders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonetheless, I thought I heard the minister say when he read out Green amendment 22A, which I cannot find, that there is still a discretion in the registrar to reject an application on the grounds that it is frivolous or vexatious.

—No. I will repeat it again. He must accept it, unless he is of the opinion that it is frivolous or vexatious, in which case he passes it on to the presiding officer to make a determination as to whether it is, in fact, frivolous or vexatious. He does not make that judgment himself. It is a matter for judgment by someone else. That is what it says and it is carefully thought out. It is not too bizarre.
—If he decides it is not frivolous, is the minister saying that then every other—

—Senator Alston is just not listening. If the registrar thinks it is frivolous, then he passes it on. If he decides it is not frivolous, he then registers it. Then it moves to the next stage of the process. If he decides it is not frivolous, it is a matter for someone coming in sideways at the determination process—an objector of one kind or another raising the issue, or, presumably, the tribunal itself.

—That is precisely the position that pertained under the old clause 57. There is that conflict of interest where he assists in the drafting of an application which he is then required to judge as to whether it is frivolous or vexatious. Clearly, he will not. All the minister can say is, `That's all right, but the tribunal could do it later'. What is the point of giving him that discretion at that stage when he will clearly be in a position of conflict?

—I do not know whether Senator Alston is just being obtuse or whether he is being obstreperous. There is no conflict of interest because the registrar has no final say to determine whether an application is frivolous or vexatious. If he had a final say to rub something out on that basis, there might be a problem because of the conflict of interest or whatever that Senator Alston identifies, given his role in the assistance.
—He should not have any initial responsibility.

—He has nothing more to do than to draw the matter to the attention of the presiding officer. If the presiding officer says, `No, I do not agree with you that it is frivolous or vexatious', the claim goes ahead and gets registered and moves on to the next stage. I do not know why Senator Alston is getting so uptight about this.

—We are not concerned that the registrar might say that it is frivolous and vexatious; we are concerned he will say it is not, because he has helped draft it. Therefore, it would not get referred to the other officer; it would be a matter of the tribunal having to be wheeled in at greater expense at a later point in time. The whole purpose of the exercise is that if he has that obligation in the first instance to make an impartial assessment as to whether it is frivolous or vexatious, he is hardly likely to carry that out impartially if he has helped draft it. If the minister cannot see that, he has a bigger problem than I thought.

—I do not see any particular problem here. It is a question of how many powers Senator Alston wants to vest in the registrar. The role we envisage for the registrar is essentially just an administrative role to ensure that appropriate notifications are made, that a proper register is maintained of competing applications and that all relevant information is gathered. It is the tribunal that is the basic determining body. However, there is a fast-track process here provided in the no doubt exceptional case where the application is so insubstantial that the registrar himself believes that he ought not to be in the business of going ahead and putting it on the register. Under those circumstances, he can fast-track the process of knocking it off by giving it to a presiding officer if he cannot do the job himself. The usual working assumption is that the registrar is not a decision making judicial type of officer. The registrar is just an administrative officer whose basic job is to run a proper registry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 62 relates to the determination as to the parties. I appreciate that clause 61 provides for the sorting out of who is a party. Clause 62(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: If it is necessary . . . to decide whether the interests of a person may be affected by a determination, that matter is to be decided by the Tribunal and, if the Tribunal decides that the interests of a person may be affected, the decision of the Tribunal is conclusive.

The term `conclusive' interested me because I wondered whether that ruled out any review. If the tribunal said to an aggrieved party, `You haven't got any interests sufficient to be included in this action' and the aggrieved party was cheesed off about that and said, `Yes, I most definitely have', does the word `conclusive' thereby end the matter and mean that the aggrieved party has no further redress?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is probably a fair point because `conclusive' does not mean conclusive. As I understand it—I am not sure how much administrative law I understand these days because it is a while since I practised it—we cannot purport to rule out consideration of these issues by the courts on a judicial review basis if there is legitimate ground for doing so as a matter of administrative law. I will try to find out why the word `conclusive' was used under those circumstances. I am advised that it is conclusive because there is an appeal right provided from this decision in clause 161. I had thought that the reference to `conclusive' and `appeal rights' was to indicate that this was not something for which an appeal right was provided as a right but which, nonetheless, would still allow one to go to administrative law of redress, even in the absence of an appeal, but that does not seem to be it.

PARA.TAB: I do not think this is something that is of gigantic significance. We had better ask the Parliamentary Counsel to have another look at this in the process of reviewing operation of the legislation generally. I do not think it will affect anyone's rights and entitlements. Clearly, there is an appeal right but it may be inappropriate terminology under the circumstances. There are two reasons why the word `conclusive' seems inappropriate: first, because there is an appeal right expressly provided for in 161; secondly, because the word `conclusive' cannot, as I understand the law, exclude the possibility of an ADJR-type application to the courts anyway under the judicial review principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one question in relation to clause 58. I genuinely apologise if it has been canvassed while I was out of the chamber for a few minutes. It is to do with the implementation of it and the powers of the registrar. Is it envisaged that these powers could be or will be exercised by deputy registrars? I presume at the moment the registrar will be one person and he or she will have to make a lot of decisions. Would it be envisaged that there will be deputy registrars in the states; if so, would they be able to exercise the power of the registrar as his delegate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant provision is clause 92 at the top of page 47 of the bill which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Registrar may by signed instrument delegate to one or more of the Deputy Registrars or of the members of the staff of the Tribunal all or any of the Registrars powers under this Act.
Presumably there is a provision somewhere else identifying the number of deputy registrars that may be appointed. Maybe that is left to regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the deputy registrars have the same sorts of qualifications as the registrar? One of the concerns will be that they will be obviously exercising a range of quasi judicial powers. My understanding is that they certainly will not need legal qualifications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reasonable assumption. They have got to be qualified competent administrators, but it is not proposed that they be exercising really anything in the nature of judicial functions. I think that answer speaks for itself. To finish off that answer, I refer Senator Campbell to clause 123 which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the Registrar, there are to be such Deputy Registrars and staff of the Tribunal as are necessary.
So it is nicely open ended. That completes the reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is the wish of the committee, I will proceed to put Senator Chamarette's amendment 24 and Senator Spindler's amendments 25 and 26. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now put Senator Spindler's amendment 23, Senator Chamarette's amendment 22A, government amendments 26 to 39 and Senator Spindler's amendment 27. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that clauses 55 to 72 inclusive, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses 73 to 191.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, clause 75(1)—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I understood that, in order to expedite matters, amendments would be put at the beginning of each section. I rose to my feet to gain the call but, because of the movement in the house, you did not see me. Would it be possible for me to introduce my amendments?

—Senator Chamarette, you are absolutely right. I think the sensible thing to do, which was a matter resolved in my absence, is for those concerned to move amendments at the beginning so that we have them before us to debate, if that is the continuing wish of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 26.Clause 163, page 73, line 24, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 20 penalty units".
27.Clause 164, page 73, line 32, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 20 penalty units".
28.Clause 165, page 73, line 36, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 40 penalty units".
29.Clause 166, page 74, line 5, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 20 penalty units.".
30.Clause 167, page 74, line 20, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 40 penalty units".
31.Clause 168, page 74, line 24, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 40 penalty units.".
32.Clause 169, page 74, line 32, omit "Penalty: Imprisonment for 3 months", substitute "Maximum Penalty: 40 penalty units.".

These amendments which I have introduced have been circulated previously. In moving these amendments to clauses 163 to 169, the Greens are making it clear that they oppose the possibility of gaol terms for offences under this act. The offences listed under the act relate to the conduct of the tribunal hearings, including refusal to be sworn to answer questions, failure of a witness to attend and the giving of false or misleading statements. It is our contention that gaol terms for such offences are wholly inappropriate.

PARA.TAB: Under clause 102 the tribunal is to take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders and is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence. These are important aspects that impact directly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. You had called Senator Alston, as is correct because, as we pointed out before, we should be given the major say on these things. I thought you then agreed to allow Senator Chamarette simply to move her amendments. However, it now seems that she is embarking upon a speech. I might be wrong, but I understood your ruling to be that she could introduce the amendments and then speak to them at the appropriate time.

—On the point of order, Senator Ian Macdonald was not in the chamber at the time, but we had an exchange about this matter. Senator Harradine said, I think on behalf of every senator here, that he thought it was a slightly bizarre process to simply introduce an amendment. In fact, it is not even strictly necessary because, under standing order 142 governing guillotines, one does not formally have to move an amendment. Provided it has been circulated, it will be put at the conclusion of the debate anyway.

PARA.TAB: We wanted to have an explanation of the amendments given at the earliest possible stage in each block of time. They can be formally moved, but an explanation of them given so that all honourable senators can have at least a rough idea of what the amendments are in the block in question before we then proceed to a more discursive debate about other things.

Senator Macdonald is cutting across the very discussion that we had earlier and the very direction that was given from the Chair at an earlier stage when Senator Macdonald was out of the chamber. I suggest that to allow Senator Chamarette to explain what her amendments are about is an entirely rational way to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that it was an agreement entered into by all parties, including the opposition. I was following the precedent which had been set before I came in. I asked again whether it was the continuing wish of the committee, and Senator Alston nodded approvingly.
—I apologise for that. I was not in the chamber. If the agreement was made, I regret delaying the committee for those few minutes.

—The amendments, which are supported by the government, parallel similar penalty structures imposed by the Queensland government in its Native Title Act 1993. The provision of monetary penalties rather than custodial ones also picks up comments in the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

PARA.TAB: The Greens are committed to a process that uses imprisonment as a penalty of last resort. We feel that Aboriginal people, to their great tragedy, have suffered enough at the hands of our legal system. This bill would be utterly inappropriate to include prison penalties. I commend this amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move amendment 28A:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 130, page 62, insert the following new clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reports by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner

SPEECH.PARA: Yearly report

PARA.TAB: "130A.(1) As soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner (appointed under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986) must prepare and submit to the Commonwealth Minister a report on:
(a)the operation of this Act; and
(b)the effect of this Act on the exercise and enjoyment of human rights of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.
"(2) The Commonwealth Minister may at any time, by written notice, direct the Commissioner to report to the Commonwealth Minister on any matter covered by paragraph (1)(a) or (b).".

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Democrat amendment No. 28A introduces a new clause, 130A, which deals with the requirement for a report by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. Such a report is required by the new section every year.

PARA.TAB: While the commissioner certainly has the power to examine and report to the Attorney-General on the human rights implications of any Commonwealth act, it is the intention of this particular amendment to ensure that the monitoring and reporting on the implications of this act be complemented by this particular report to ensure that this report happens on a yearly basis. The aim is to enable people to assess the functioning of the report on the basis of the human rights implications for Aboriginal people that arise out of the operation of that act. It is complementary to the previous amendment which has introduced a select committee to monitor the operations of the act in general terms, but this amendment has a specific and desirable focus. I commend it to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate, for the convenience of the committee, the government's position on these amendments. We support the Green amendments, as moved by Senator Chamarette. We also support amendment No. 28A, as moved by Senator Spindler.

PARA.TAB: There is just one small qualification so far as amendment 28A is concerned. The proposed new clause is numbered 130A as its proposed location from Senator Spindler. Might I make a request to Senator Spindler that he contemplate relocating the clause as proposed new clause 195A. I ask that because the Office of Parliamentary Counsel had a small frisson when they saw that particular location. They regarded it as quite inappropriate; it was somehow linked with the special inquiries provision so far as the tribunal itself was concerned. It did not quite fit; it was more in the nature of a miscellaneous provision. That is the kind of chairman's amendment which can be fixed up without formal endorsement by the committee, but I think it would be a help if Senator Spindler were prepared to relocate it. I ask him to amend his amendment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 28A and renumber the proposed new clause from 130A to 195A.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am on my feet, I withdraw Australian Democrats' amendment No. 29, which has become unnecessary since government amendment 44A addresses the same issue.
—You are just not required to move it.

—On the question of the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, I draw attention to clause 85(1) and clause 147 of the bill. These clauses provide that, firstly, the Federal Court and, secondly, the tribunal may order that any evidence given to either the court or the tribunal respectively must not be disclosed; in other words, the evidence will be secret. Clause 168 provides any person who is in breach of that order by disclosing that evidence goes to gaol for three months. The Democrats have argued that they do not want a prison sentence for the penalty.
—That was the Greens amendment.
—Or the Greens.
—Virtually synonymous.
—They are almost synonymous, quite right.
—Not quite.

—One could be pardoned for thinking they are. The amendment as moved is argued on the basis that it is not appropriate to send an Aboriginal person to gaol, but this provision covers both Aboriginal and other Australians. Consistent with what I say all the time—that we make laws for all Australians, that I want the law to be equal and treat people in an equal manner, that I do not want one group of laws for people on the basis of race and another group of laws for different people—I ask the minister whether or not it is his intention to amend clause 168, which requires a penalty of three months imprisonment for publishing evidence which the court or the tribunal has ordered shall not be published. I will deal with the question of whether I think secret evidence is a good idea at a later time.
—I am not quite clear on Senator Bishop's question, because clause 168 is itself amended, by Green amendment No. 31, to have a monetary penalty substituted.
—So the amendment is covering both?

—Green amendment No. 31 substitutes a monetary penalty for that. As I understood the Green amendments, they extended to substituting a monetary penalty for an imprisonment for every penalty provided for in this legislation, without exception and without discrimination on the ground of race or the nature of the process that is concerned.

—I thank the minister for that answer. Listening to the rhetoric that was being put in support of the amendment as moved, one could be pardoned for thinking that it was dealing with that part where only Aboriginal people were subject to the penalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Bishop raised a point in relation to clause 85, she did not continue on and read the full clause, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . except in such manner, and to such persons, as the Court specifies.
So it is within the discretion of the court to permit that.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, that makes it worse, not better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the minister to clause 75 which provides that:

PARA.TAB: The Federal Court must pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of determination that is fair, just, economical, informal and prompt.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is this provision in place any more so in this bill than in any other? Surely this is really just another way of, by one means or another, whittling away the normal, entrenched rights of due process for the sake of somehow coming up with a just outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why Senator Alston thinks this involves some necessary whittling away of due process. That is a rather bizarre interpretation, lest his concept of due process is a high degree of formality and pomposity. Given the way he usually behaves in this place, I can assume that that might be the case. But fair, just, economical, informal and prompt seem to be highly salutary criteria for any exercise of the judicial process. I must admit that I was a bit intrigued to see this terminology here in the bill. I cannot recollect having seen it elsewhere. But everything has to be done for the first time and, if we are setting a precedent for the way in which these things are to be expressed in the future, so be it; it is a good precedent. More power to the draftsman's arm.

—Does that mean that the minister would want to see that put into all legislation so that all courts and tribunals should have that as their mission statement? I suppose when one adds to that clause 75(3) where the court is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence, I would have thought that we were looking at a very different creature from ordinary tribunals and courts.

—The only criterion that might be thought to be a little bit different from the judicial norm, I guess, would be the reference to informality. The reference to the mechanism being fair, just, economical and prompt seems to me to be entirely applicable and appropriate to any court at any level, any tribunal at any level, in any jurisdiction in the country. The requirement of informality might be thought to be not always appropriate. If one were of the cringe before the majesty of the law school, High Court architecture and so on across the road, one would be distressed at the thought of any suggestion of informality.

PARA.TAB: The Family Court is one jurisdiction in which the case for informality was stressed and embodied in the original 1975 legislation. This is another context in which informality would be manifestly entirely appropriate. The particular reference in clause 75(3) to the court, in conducting proceedings, not being bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence is a not unusual one in the context of determinations of this kind. There are precedents that I can recall seeing in various other contexts—

TALK.START.PARA: —In lesser tribunals, not in courts.

—That may be so. The context that we are talking of here and the nature of the applicants and the applications in question are such as to suggest to the government that a degree of less formality and less strictness in the operation of rules of evidence and so on might be entirely appropriate. These are matters of judgment, and that is our judgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 79 provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Federal Court may, in its discretion:
(a) receive into evidence the transcript of evidence in any other proceedings before:

PARA.TAB: (v) any other person or body;

SPEECH.PARA: and draw any conclusions of fact from that transcript that it thinks proper;

I suppose the minister will say to me that the reason why the government did not say `draw any proper conclusions' is that that is in fact the approach that will be taken by any review court. Why is it not expressed in that form in the first instance rather than allowing the court to do anything that it thinks proper? In the same way, under paragraph (a), the court can receive into evidence the transcript of evidence. More importantly, what is meant by paragraph (a)(v) `any other person or body'? Is this really encouraging the court to take into account absolutely anything that anyone might think is conceivably relevant? Given that one is not bound by legal forms or rules of evidence, presumably we can have hearsay upon hearsay, opinions instead of fact, and virtually anything that an applicant might think is helpful to the case. What is meant by `any other person or body'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston knows, as I do, that these words mean what they say. The phrase `any other person or body' means that it is entirely within the discretion of the Federal Court as to whose evidence it will receive. It is entirely within its own judgment as to the weight that it chooses to give to that evidence, whatever its form or, as Senator Alston said, its hearsay status or other character. It is in the nature of the discretion that is here vested in the Federal Court and in the nature of the context in which it is deciding that that discretion has deliberately been made very wide.

PARA.TAB: These decisions are all appealable. Again, if it were believed by a disappointed applicant or objector that the court was not operating in accordance with proper principles, that it was taking into account manifestly irrelevant points or giving improper weight to evidentiary material that simply could not sustain that weight, that person would have grounds for appeal to higher courts. That is as it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me suggest to the minister how it should be. In the first instance one should seek to encourage, wherever possible, the right decision. The government is seeking to encourage the court in this instance to do whatever it thinks is fair, reasonable and just. The unsuccessful litigant is then put to the time, trouble and expense of going to appeal. I would have thought that is entirely the wrong way to proceed.

PARA.TAB: I will just give an example of what I think is offensive about clause 79(a)(v). When subparagraphs (i) to (v) state

SPEECH.PARA: (i) the Court; or
(ii) another court; or
(iii) the NNTT; or
(iv) a recognised State/Territory body; or
(v) any other person or body
that effectively covers the field. But if one referred to `any proceedings before any person or body', I bet everyone else would have said, `That is outrageous because it is cast far too wide'.

PARA.TAB: The government has tried to give this a veneer of respectability by nominating all the formal courts and tribunals. Under the line, in effect, it has then come up with this catch-all phrase which the minister is unable to indicate is designed to facilitate access to any particular person or body; it is just an omnibus clause. That is one classic example. It encourages the court to draw conclusions of fact that it thinks proper, not which are proper or which might objectively be regarded as proper. It is effectively encouraging it to do anything it likes.

Paragraph (c) uses the words `adopt any recommendation, finding, decision or judgment'. Again, that involves not just fact; it can involve opinion or anything one likes that one might want to call in aid. I suggest to the minister that the end result of it is that the government is loading the decision in favour of those who do not want to have regard to the formalities and rules of evidence to the point where it is much more likely an incorrect decision will be made.

An unsuccessful litigant cannot afford to go on in every case. I suggest that the government is weighting the scales of justice very unfairly in one direction. If that is the case, I would like the minister to at least have the courage to say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —When dealing with Senator Alston one always has a sense that one cannot win. If we had not provided for any appeal from the Federal Court proceedings as set out, he would be fulminating about the extraordinary degree of responsibility vested in a body without any discipline and without anyone sitting on its shoulder. When one makes it clear that normal appeal rights apply, one is accused of creating further hassles for disappointed litigants, giving them another step in the process to go through and so on.

PARA.TAB: If one spells out with some precision, as we have here, what the intentions are so far as other bodies from whom transcripts of evidence can be taken and brought into evidence, that is one kind of argument. If one does not spell it out and leaves it completely to the discretion of the court, one gets another kind of argument.

It really is nitpicking and grumpiness of the highest order, and as such, it is not be taken very seriously. But taking it seriously, as I am obliged to do for the sake of this debate, I would say that while a discretion is pretty close to absolute, I guess, in terms of the literal way in which the section is draw, if one wants to apply some ejusdem generis principle to subparagraphs (i) to (v), one would see that what is being referred to here are the hearings or proceedings of other reasonably formal bodies that exist around the place, or which have existed, and which have taken evidence in relation to relevant matters: for example, the land commissioners under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory; for example, the Queensland Aboriginal Land Tribunal, which has conducted proceedings of this kind for some time now; for example, the Seimen commission in Western Australia some years ago which conducted a major examination and investigation of a number of entirely relevant issues in the context of these sorts of inquiries and determinations.

There are certainly plenty of instances around of formally constituted inquiries of one kind or another that might be regarded as being of the same general character or class as those particular bodies or institutions specifically referred to in subparagraphs (i) to (iv). If a court was minded to want to limit the scope of its own capacity to take this kind of evidence and wanted to read down subparagraph (v), there would be ample credible basis on which to do so by reference to the kind of other bodies that I have mentioned. If it wanted to give those words their maximum possible range and effect, I still believe it would be entitled to do so provided the kind of evidence that was taken was manifestly relevant and bore upon the proceedings. If it was not relevant and if it was taken into account and given undue or improper weigh, then, as I said at the outset, there would be ground for appeal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said you are encouraging that.

—Well, I do not believe that this is encouraging. I think it is value neutral so far as encouragement is concerned. If Senator Alston listens to the argument, there are plenty of other bodies that are of the same broad class—namely, formally constituted institutions or inquiries that could be covered by subparagraph (v). So I do not think it is any kind of encouragement to open-ended fishing expeditions and irresponsibility of the kind that Senator Alston is seeking to imply. It is just an entirely legitimate drafting devise to point the court in the right general direction but without seeking to unduly limit its capacity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak again to clause 75. I particularly want to deal with the concept which the minister espouses all the time, that the basis of this legislation is that native title shall be dealt with in the same way as fee simple or freehold title.
—That's not what we have said at any stage.
—The minister has said all along that the government wants to be able to do with native title what can be done with freehold title. That has been the government's basic concept.
—That's completely different.

—I am not asking the minister; that is what he has said. The fact of the matter is that the government has set out in clause 75 that there is to be a different standard, a different set and a different way in which a court of the Australian legal system shall operate for native title and no other sort of title. In other words, when it concerns native title the court, under clause 75(3), in conducting proceedings, shall not be bound by technicalities, legal forms or the rules of evidence. Australians who are not Aboriginals will be bound by the rules of evidence if they appear before the Federal Court. The point I am making is that, within clause 75, we have a provision that the court is to behave in a certain way in respect of Aboriginal Australians—in a way that it will not behave in respect of any other Australian.

PARA.TAB: Clause 76 requires that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court is to appoint an assessor in relation to each proceeding. He is to direct an assessor to assist the Federal Court. We have already pointed out in earlier debate that an assessor may only be a person of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander race. So we have two provisions now which are discriminating. If this legislation is to be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act, presumably these provisions will be struck down because they are quite clearly discriminatory and they do not meet the temporary provisions as reflected in section 8. Clause 75(2) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court, in conducting proceedings, must take account of the cultural and customary concerns . . .

What does that mean? When dealing with the question of not being bound by technicalities, does that include privilege between a lawyer and his or her client? Does that mean that a lawyer can be compelled to come before the court and give evidence as to what has occurred between that lawyer and his or her client?

PARA.TAB: We will deal with those two questions first. Why does this bill make a distinction between the way Aboriginal Australians are treated when they come before the Federal Court and the way all other Australians are treated when they come before the Federal Court? Does the way that the bill is drafted mean that a lawyer can be compelled to come and give evidence before that court about the relationship and matters that have been dealt with between the solicitor and client or the barrister and client on the basis that privilege can also be avoided?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say at the outset that Senator Bishop began, as she so often does, with a grand, simple misstatement by saying that native title was required to be dealt with by this legislation in the same way as freehold title.
