That, Senator Bishop, is simply not true. Senator Bishop has not understood the freehold test, which does recur in a number of different contexts in the bill. It is not a test which says that it has to be dealt with in the same way as freehold title; it says, rather, that, for the purpose of determining whether or not what are described by the legislation as future acts can take place with respect to native title, the test to apply is whether or not those same acts can take place with respect to ordinary owners of freehold title. That is a very different thing from saying that native title is to be treated in the same way as freehold title. In all sorts of ways, native title is not to be treated in the same way as freehold title. It is not amenable in the same way and so on. There are a whole heap of other differences.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, the content of native title will vary enormously, depending on the particular context. In some cases it may involve exclusive occupancy and other characteristics that make it, for all practical purposes, indistinguishable from freehold. Other kinds of native title may involve much less of a proprietary right than that. It is very important to understand that kind of distinction and not to misstate it in the way that Senator Bishop did, if she is going to make that the foundation of any kind of argument.

As to the provisions in clause 75 about relative informality and not being bound by legal forms or rules of evidence, these are, of course, very familiar provisions in tribunal proceedings of various kinds—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a different matter.

—I am just making the first part of the sentence; wait until the end of the sentence. There are many examples of such tribunals—the Migration Appeals Tribunal and the Australian Broadcasting Authority are the two that spring immediately to mind.
—This is not a tribunal; it's a federal court.

—I am indebted to Senator Bishop for that piece of forensic brilliance. That is what I was coming to in the second part of my sentence. The court is not a tribunal; it is not an administrative body. It is a judicial body and it has to behave judicially as a result. There is no doubt about that. It is breaking some new ground, I believe, although there may be some advice to the contrary about that—it seems to be breaking rather new ground—in vesting these tribunal-like characteristics in the court when it comes to the hearing and determination of these matters.
—I didn't ask you about tribunals; I asked you about the federal court.

—Before Senator Bishop moves into her death watch mode and her judicial black cap forensic style, let me say, obviously, why the policy decision has been made to treat these sorts of cases in this way. The decision has been made to treat them in this way and allow the Federal Court to behave and adjudicate on a relativity more relaxed basis than might otherwise be the case simply because of the nature of the issues that are being heard and determined. We are talking about the ascertaining, essentially, of the nature and extent of common law rights that are being recognised to exist for the first time in over 200 years of this country's history.

PARA.TAB: The reason for those rights being recognised, as I cannot expect Senator Bishop to begin to acknowledge, is because indigenous Australians, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, occupy for most of the rest of us—notwithstanding Senator Bishop's inability to even contemplate this—a rather special place in the hearts and minds of Australians. We are the expropriators from the ancestors of these people. For over 200 years we have engaged in a conspicuous form of injustice to those people and their successors. We as a nation owe something to these people. We as a nation have an obligation to try to get this right. We as a nation and we as legislators have an obligation to demonstrate just a little greater degree of sensitivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman.
—If Senator Bishop is about to make yet another spurious point of order—she is incapable of doing otherwise—I will seek the permission of the Chairman to respond accordingly.

—I rise on a point of order as to relevance. I asked the minister to explain why this particular bill is designed to treat Aboriginal Australians differently—or requires the court to treat Aboriginal Australians differently—from ordinary Australians. I did not ask for his own version of his own personal rationale for his internal thinking. I asked for a specific reason as to why the Federal Court of Australia is now obliged to have one set of rules for Aboriginal Australians and treat every other Australian in a different way. This is separate development. It is what I said this morning—there is one set of rules for one group of Australians and another set for another.

—Order! Senator Bishop, you are now straying from the point of order. Senator Evans was justifiably responding to a generous number of interjections and putting a point of view. There is no point of order.
—I am indebted to you, Mr Chairman. Senator Bishop should have been put down a little earlier. I recommend that course to you in future when she barks upon a spurious point of order of that kind.
—Point of order, Mr Chairman: I am not going to wear that sort of nonsense.

—I express complete confidence in your chairmanship, Mr Chairman, and I understand the difficulties you have when you are dealing with people like this. Mercifully, we will be relieved of that difficulty, I hope, in the very near future.
—I asked him to withdraw.
—I am not going to withdraw anything I said.

—Senator Bishop, I have been listening very carefully for the better part of today and I did not hear anything. I am happy to get the transcript but, as Senator Evans suggests, I was slow to draw your attention to the fact that you were departing from the point of order. He was not suggesting that you be put down in the way that I think you might be ascribing to him.
—On the contrary, Mr Chairman. I interpret his comment bearing in mind that he has already on one occasion threatened to garrotte me, and I said he needed psychiatric help. I stand by that comment.
—Senator Bishop and Senator Evans, this personal exchange across the chamber neither enhances the quality of the debate nor the impression the poor unsuspecting public have of it.

—You have rather spoilt my stride, Mr Chairman. I was making the point that we do regard this as very special legislation. We do regard it as being based on a very special sense of obligation—whether all of us feel that sense of obligation or not. We do regard it as a matter that requires to be approached with a very special kind of sensitivity and a very special kind of understanding. We do regard the particular subject matter as being of a character, demanding as it does not just evidence to be determined about physical location and movement and relativities of particular people and genealogies and so on, but requiring as it does evidence to be taken and weighed about spiritual life of communities and cultural norms with which we in this community are unfamiliar—issues which are not normally the provenance of the courts of this land.

PARA.TAB: Because these issues will come into play and be relevant in the determination of a great many issues that will arise about the nature and extent of the native title that is enjoyed, because the very nature of native title, as it is described by the court, is highly variable in content, depending on the particular circumstances, there is a situation that cries out for the exercise of flexibility by the tribunals that are making these initial determinations and by the courts that are dealing with issues that arise out of those determinations or other processes. It cries out for a different kind of approach from that which has traditionally been associated with court procedure. It cries out for a good deal of the flexibility that has more traditionally been associated with tribunal procedure.

There is no suggestion in any of this that the courts will be tearing up the rule book entirely. There is no ground for any suggestion that they would be using this as an opportunity to cut a swath through the familiar rules of legal professional privilege and other foundations of the law of evidence and associated jurisprudence. However, I do remind Senator Bishop, since she likes to think of herself as a lawyer on these occasions—whatever the evidence may be to the contrary—that there is plenty of legal authority for a court to be a court and to be regarded as such and to still retain its judicial character, notwithstanding it is created or given a jurisdiction on a more flexible basis.

Might I remind Senator Bishop—I use the legal politeness of `remind'; no doubt she is hearing of it for the first time—of the case of Peacock vs. Newtown Marrickville and General Co-Operative Building Society No. 4 Limited (1943) volume 67 of the Commonwealth Law Reports at page 25. In that case the court held that a body may be a court although it is directed to act `without regard to technicalities or legal forms, is not bound by the rules of evidence and is empowered to inform its mind on any matter in such manner as it thinks fit'. In that case it was said:

SPEECH.PARA: Technicalities and legal forms and rules of evidence may be varied indefinitely without depriving a tribunal of a judicial character.

That is at page 36 of that report. A body that was exonerated from all rules of law and equity would not however be a judicial body. I draw that to Senator Bishop's attention. Whether she takes any notice of it or not is always a good question in these cases; no doubt we will get some simplistic burst in response, with the black hat back on and the teeth bared. But the point is there is ample precedent, at least in the theory of the law as has been articulated by the High Court, for allowing degrees of flexibility of the kind that are clearly contemplated in this legislation while still maintaining the character of the body in question as a court and the character of the proceeding as a judicial proceeding.

PARA.TAB: So there is a technical response—I do not know whether that is of any use to parties or whether they are persuaded by it. There is also a policy response about why things are because of the particular unique nature of the issues with which we are dealing. A little bit of sensitivity on both counts would help Senator Bishop a great deal in understanding why this legislation is as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no precedent, and the minister knows it very well—no precedent at all that says that one Australian can be preferred or receive different treatment in a court on the basis of race. It is a brand new principle and it is offensive. There is no basis for it in the Mabo decision. It derives from the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) decided that he was going to mix up the problems that flowed from Mabo No. 2 and the need for certainty with the very valid question of reconciliation, which need to be two entirely separate issues.

PARA.TAB: By trying to merge the issues, we get this sort of disgraceful principle being placed into our legal system. The idea that a court is entitled to differentiate in its treatment of individuals on the basis of race to me is abhorrent. My view of Australia is that every Australian shall be treated the same, that we are a single nation, the best country in the world. I want all Australian to have the opportunity to reach their maximum potential. That means Aboriginal Australians; it means Italian Australians; it means Malaysian Australians. It means whatever sort of Australians—because they are Australians first.

I said this morning that we are seeing separate development with this legislation, and a nation split and divided. This is a prime example. I asked the minister for the reason, and the reason he gave me is not satisfactory. The second question I asked the minister related to privilege. He has not addressed that. I will give him a third question to answer relating to hearsay evidence. For the minister to simply say that it not a problem to allow hearsay evidence to be admitted is, simply, again, a misunderstanding of how that affects the rights of individuals. It, in fact, impairs the right of appeal, because it limits the number of grounds for appeal that can be established.

Will the minister address the question of privilege and the question of hearsay evidence, and inform us of the basis upon which he thinks people are advantaged by having their right of appeal limited by that.

TALK.START.PARA: —All that initial rhetoric might go down a treat with the MacKellar elderly citizens club, but it does not butter too many parsnips with me. It completely misses the point about the nature of the special issues involved in this particular legislation and the special responsibilities we, as legislators, have to get this right and to create institutional machinery which will guarantee that it stays right in the future.

PARA.TAB: This morning we broke the record for the longest committee stage of legislation in the history of the Australian Senate when we got up to 41 hours and 15 minutes before we had the guillotine motion. It is no accident that the second longest committee stage of a bill in the history of the Australian Senate was when we were debating another piece of Aboriginal legislation—the ATSIC legislation of 1989.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite just cannot contain themselves. Whenever any issue comes up about the treatment of Aboriginal Australians, their true colours emerge. They simply cannot contain themselves. They are incapable of a sensitive thought or response, and the evidence starkly shrieks out to us.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I was dealing with the basis of the reason why we are opposing the legislation. I did not ask Senator Gareth Evans for personal abuse nor did I ask for his appraisal of the ATSIC legislation, which Senator Peter Baume had charge of for this side and moved volumes of amendments to. That was a totally different circumstance. I am talking about this bill and the fact that the government has chosen to mix the problems posed by the Mabo No. 2 decision and the question of reconciliation, which I support 100 per cent. I do not need his personal abuse to try to cover the fact that in this legislation the government is making different laws for different Australians on the basis of race, which I find highly offensive.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The prospect of Senator Bishop playing a role in reconciling anybody with anything is so wildly implausible that I have difficulty in swallowing that particular assertion. The only substantive point she made was that she asserted I had not responded to her on the question of privilege. I clearly did and she will find that response in the Hansard if she ever gets around to re-reading these things. I suppose she does re-read her own contributions every night and finely hones these miraculously impressive engagements.

PARA.TAB: The particular issue of hearsay is worth a separate and distinct comment. Hearsay evidence is one of the classic areas of the law of evidence. Over the years, there has been a great deal of discussion and argument as to whether the rigours of that rule ought to be modified or subject to even more qualifications and exceptions than exist in the law at the moment.

In the context of Aboriginal land rights, native title rights, we are talking about identifying oral traditions—cultural norms that are not written down but that are passed on from one generation to another and from one family group to another. Evidence is not to be found in a tangible form but, rather, in the way in which communities pass down this kind of information from mouth to mouth, obviously not based on direct experience in many cases, but on the received oral history wisdom of the group.

In those circumstances to rule out something in the nature of hearsay evidence, technically and strictly speaking, would obviously be to deny the tribunals, and in this case the courts, access to what will often perhaps be the only evidence, but certainly will often be the most crucial evidence in a court or a tribunal making up its mind on just what kinds of rights it is appropriate to acknowledge and ascertain.

The notion that there is some sort of injustice being worked to non-Aboriginal Australians by these kinds of more sensitive and flexible procedures being built into the particular jurisdiction or context that we are here talking about is to so comprehensively miss the point that one wonders which particular planet Senator Alston, and those who think like him, have been on over the past few years during a period in which we, as a nation, have been coming to grips with the real needs of giving justice to those of our fellows Australians who have been so conspicuously denied it for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the minister's attention to the conference provisions, which I note from section 79 then allow for any evidence taken in conference to be regarded as evidence before the court. First, the conference provisions indicate that a conference must be presided over by an assessor. The assessor then has power, virtually unlimited, to conduct a private conference, which only requires him to have due regard for the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders—in other words, that is not the only criterion. Clearly an assessor is at large in deciding whether there ought to be a private conference. The Federal Court may prohibit disclosure of evidence, so there could be secret evidence not disclosed to certain persons. Then there can be serious and unprecedented limitations on the right to examine and cross-examine witnesses. I note from 85(5) that a person appearing as a witness before the assessor may only be cross-examined or re-examined with the leave of the assessor.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to the minister that all those provisions are totally new in any context. I ask him, first, what justification is there for this, apart from wanting to tilt the playing field in one obvious direction; and, secondly, has he obtained any advice which he can make available to the committee in relation to the boilermakers case. Further, can he tell us that what he is doing here is not blurring the distinction of the role of the assessor—who is elsewhere expressed not to be carrying out a judicial function—by enabling the court, through the backdoor, to take account of all that the assessor might have obtained by the most extraordinarily novel legal methods?

In those circumstances, I suggest that if the minister wants this to be seen as anything more than a fairly blatant attempt to ensure that the ordinary rules of evidence are the last thing that are to determine the way in which these proceedings are conducted, he ought to be able to make available to us evidence that suggests that the boilermakers principles are still intact as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Detailed provisions about assessors are set out in clause 203. The more immediately relevant provision, in terms of the point that Senator Alston seeks to make, is clause 76 where it says very clearly that, while:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Chief Judge is to direct an assessor to assist the Federal Court in relation to each proceedings . . .
(2) The assessor is, in relation to those proceedings, subject to the control and direction of the Court . . .

SPEECH.PARA: and:
In assisting the Court, the assessor is not to exercise any judicial power of the Court.

I think that the last subclause is the answer to the boilermakers issue that Senator Alston raises in the sense that there is a very clear legislative direction that no shred of the judicial authority of the court is to be exercised by the non-judicial component that is here added to the court.

PARA.TAB: I am advised—I will not say I am reminded—that in the UK, the court of appeal and the House of Lords may sit with assessors. That is the subject of various authorities and precedents, mainly of a maritime character, by appearances of the cases there referred to. I acknowledge that they are not constrained by constitutional technicalities about non-mixing and judicial and non-judicial power. But I think care has been taken to make clear the limits of the assessor's role in this instance.

Obviously the whole point about creating this role of assessors is to ensure that Federal Court judges, who cannot be assumed to have had much experience in any of the issues that they will be confronted with in dealing with these sorts of cases, will at least have another source of advice and assistance open to them in the conduct of proceedings which may amount to some extra help in wending their way through these minefields.

The point is made that the traditional context in which assessors have been used, those maritime ones I have mentioned, have involved collisions between ships at sea. The sorts of issues that one has embarked upon resolving here to do with government native title, by their very character, are infinitely more complex than the sorts of issues that traditionally have been regarded by a common law Anglo-Saxon legal system as justifying assessors. I think that in those circumstances this is another innovation that should be applauded rather than being greeted with the kind of angst that it seems to generate in the tory breast on these occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister knows full well that the traditional role of an assessor is to assist. In most instances an assessor has no vote; in other words, an assessor does not profess to express an opinion because he or she is clearly not intended to exercise any judicial function. An assessor simply advises the decision maker, usually on technical matters. Those matters are not confined to maritime matters; engineers are quite commonly employed in that capacity.

PARA.TAB: This is an entirely different situation. In this case the judicial decision maker is vacating the field. He is allowing the conference to be presided over by the assessor who, to all intents and purposes, conducts the proceedings. That assessor then proceeds without any limitations to be in a position to deny rights of cross-examination and re-examination; to decide that certain conferences shall be held in private; and in a whole range of ways to make decisions and exercise functions that are clearly judicial.

I therefore ask the minister again: what opinion has he obtained in relation to the boilermakers case? He and I well know that no court will be fooled by 76(3). If we look at the reality of the matter and not the forms, the court will clearly have to make a judgment about whether, in fact, assessors are exercising judicial functions. I would have thought anyone who presides over proceedings to the exclusion of a judge and makes decisions about the rules of evidence and the way in which evidence is to be taken is clearly exercising a judicial function. If the minister has advice to the contrary, I think he ought to produce it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of judicial contexts in which provision is made for evidence to be taken in various ways by non-judicial persons in order to assist the court in getting at the truth of the matter. Persons who are given commissions of various kinds for that purpose are quite familiar in our legal system, whether it is a matter of taking evidence overseas or in some other context.
—They are usually judicial officers, lawyers.

—Not invariably at all. It would have to be invariable practice in order to begin to make a case of the kind Senator Alston seeks to do; any exception from the universality of that clause undermines his argument.
—You have not given one example.

—In this particular context I imagine Senator Alston is talking about situations arising where assessors would take evidence—for example, in remote parts of Australia at the request and direction and under the control of the court. It would be perhaps entirely appropriate that that be so. The rules governing conferences and so on in which they are involved are obviously intended, among other things, to deal with that kind of situation.

PARA.TAB: The terms of clause 76 remain clear. The power of the assessor or the responsibility of the assessor extends only to the exercise of non-judicial powers and functions and the person remains absolutely subject to the control of the court. I do not disagree with what Senator Alston says about needing to look behind that statutory veil and to look at the way in which it works in practice. But I am sure that the sort of thought police that Senator Alston has in mind to monitor and scrutinise the way in which this process works will ensure that this is an issue that is kept under close monitoring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked whether you could provide any advice on this important constitutional issue.

—Again, the same principle applies as I mentioned earlier. There is a whole heap of extremely competent lawyers in the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of Parliamentary Counsel who are well versed in the niceties of constitutional provisions.
—They are infallible, are they?

—No, but they are not the sort of people who need to be researching these issues and writing little formal advices to each other about very basic issues, such as the boilermakers principle, the mix of judicial and non-judicial power or lots of the other things that we have talked about in this case. When one knows these things and internalises them, they are a part of one's whole approach to drafting.
—This is unique. What experience is there to fall back on?

—We do not need to go down that particular path. Senator Alston might need a collection of crutches and other forms of advisory assistance whenever he is making a judgment about anything in the conduct of his particular shadow ministerial responsibilities; I can well understand that. But the professionals that we are talking about do not need to be writing little notes to each other every day of the week about matters of basic legal principle with which they are entirely familiar.

—I just want to make a point about clause 75 (1). I guess most Australians would probably think it was fairly acceptable to instruct a court to be fair, just, economical and prompt. But I think a very serious issue is raised by the parliament instructing the Federal Court to be `informal'. I am not sure how the court is going to interpret that. I guess that is left to the court's own devices.

PARA.TAB: I think it raises a very serious issue of the authority of the Federal Court and the respect for the law. I think it is a fundamental responsibility of the parliament to ensure the maintenance of the authority of the law and respect for the law. When the Family Court was set up there was this approach of informality, which I think was somewhat naive.

Some assert that this approach of informality has caused the problems in the Family Court. When judges are sitting there deciding property, custody and other massive issues that affect people's lives, the element of informality has been a significant problem. It may well have contributed to some of the tragic and awful attacks on Family Court judges and others in the sense that participants in the process have had their authority and respect for the law depleted and diminished by the very informality of the process. I wonder whether the government is conscious of this potential and significant issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had an exchange about that aspect, and Senator Minchin must have been out of the chamber at the time. I have indicated an understanding of the sort of point that Senator Minchin is making and I acknowledged that it is perhaps unusual to have this sort of provision so far as a court is concerned. I specifically referred to the Family Court experience.

PARA.TAB: I think this is a special case because of the nature of the rights and interests and the kinds of personalities that are going to be caught up in this process. It is quite appropriate, as a matter of policy judgment, to go down this path. Maybe that is something the proposed parliamentary committee that we are setting up to monitor the course of this legislation might want to look at over time.

Again, I think this instinctive reflex reaction that one gets from Senator Minchin's side of politics, that the greater degree of formality and pomposity the better, is not an instinctive attitude that we would have as we approach these issues. I understand the argument that Senator Minchin is putting, and maybe it is something that could do with the kind of close monitoring over time that was indeed appropriate in the family law context.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the consideration of these clauses has expired. The question is that the committee agree to amendment 28A of the Democrats and amendments 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31 and 32 of the Greens.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that clauses 73 to 191, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 192 to 206 and clause 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting some time

SPEECH.PARA: to come back to clause 11. It was postponed on Saturday because the government at that stage decided not to proceed with its proposed amendment. I suspect that the government withdrew that amendment because it found that it did not constitutionally provide what it wanted it to provide. At that time the government indicated that the Greens' amendment to clause 196, proposed clause 196A dealing with preservation of right to carry on activities, would, in fact, take its place. The proposed Greens amendment was an attempt to cover for the government what it was attempting to achieve by virtue of the amendment to clause 11 that it had withdrawn. As I understand it, there has been no change in those matters.

PARA.TAB: The situation that the coalition wanted to draw attention to in this respect is that mistakes have been made before with the application of section 109 of the constitution when we have legislation, both federal and state, operating at the same time. In the earlier debate I drew attention to the fact that the government had once before implemented a piece of legislation—it was the Racial Discrimination Act—the consequence of which was that the New South Wales Racial Discrimination Act was held to be invalid. The reason it was held to be invalid is because section 109 of the constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: When a law of a State is inconsistent with a law of the Commonwealth, the latter shall prevail, and the former shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, be invalid.

The point that was made in the earlier debate was that in clause 11 of the Native Title Bill the government specifically uses the phrase `a law of the Commonwealth' which comes from section 109 of the constitution. The government is clearly trying to say that, by virtue of a variety of powers, it has the capacity to put through this bill and that the Commonwealth bill will take supremacy over any state laws.

PARA.TAB: The consequence of that may well be that state laws in that area are invalid. But the government did not want that to happen. However, the constitution says that if the federal parliament has the power to cover a particular field, the way to resolve a dispute between the federal government and the state governments is to say, `The state laws drop off to the extent that they are inconsistent'. That is what the constitution says.

As we all know by this country's record of dismal failure in trying to amend the constitution, we cannot amend the constitution simply by an act of Parliament. It has to be amended by a referendum. We cannot just say at any particular time, `Look, this constitution doesn't suit us. We know it says that but we don't want it to work out that way. This time, even though we might doing something the constitution says will have this effect, we'll try to put it in the legislation a clause which says, "No, it doesn't"'. That is the simple point that needs to be made. The government cannot, by virtue of writing in a clause, announce that its bill does not have the effect that it wants it to have. That is what we say the government was trying to do with the original amendment that was proposed to clause 11. The government now wants to rephrase that clause in some way and preserve rights that might otherwise exist by virtue of proposed clause 196A.

In this debate, the minister raised a number of examples to indicate that we were off the track. These constitutional things get a bit one way or the other. I note that even the High Court does not reach unanimous judgments on these things all the time. None of us is saying that it is 100 per cent certain that the government is wrong. What we are saying is that there is a good case to make out on the other side and it deserves more than cursory treatment.

I do not mean by that that the minister has tried to give it cursory treatment. In fact, he has been good enough to get some legal opinion for us on the matter. We have gone through the examples that the minister offered. He said that it is not uncommon for the federal government to be taking up a common law in its statutes in some sort of general wording. The minister used as an example section 80 of the Judiciary Act and quoted from that. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: That is a general lifting up of that applicable body of common law and making it part of the law of the Commonwealth so far as the exercise of federal jurisdiction by these Commonwealth courts being created by this proposed act is concerned.
Of course, that is true. He then went on to mention the Crimes Act 1914, as subsequently amended, and said:
We could hardly find a much more general provision than that lifting up a whole body of common law—
and that may be true—
and giving it the force and effect of Commonwealth statute law.

That is just not the sort of example that we wanted the government to find. We wanted to see if it could find one example, but it cannot find one. I will try to reword this because I can see that the adviser looks confused. It is late in the day and maybe everyone is not as articulate as they otherwise might be. I will try to put it as plainly and simply as I can. What we are pretty sure that the government is not able to find is an example whereby, in a couple of lines in a statute, the government has purported to use a variety of powers to take up a new legislative area and has done so using the wording in section 109 of the constitution to explicitly make it clear—which is what the government wants to do—that it wants to override the states.

PARA.TAB: The Judiciary Act does not try to do that. The Crimes Act does not try to do that. All we want is some sort of precedent for taking up a body of common law. The government has given us that, but more than that; it is only the first limb of it. It is taking up a body of common law and applying it as a law of the Commonwealth, with the force of Commonwealth law, using the words of section 109. This is a clear indication that the federal government has now decided that this is an area where, to the extent of inconsistency, the states are to be squashed out. The government has not given us such an example. We say that that is a problem.

Despite the examples that the minister has given—presumably he can understand what I am saying—he has not given such an example. This is a very novel extension. One might argue that it is a novel extension of Commonwealth power, and no doubt that will be argued in the courts. But it is also a novel use of section 109. To the best of our knowledge, it has never been done before. All we asked for was an example. The minister has not come up with one. Has he since then been able to find one?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In the excitement of calling on you, Senator Vanstone, I overlooked allowing a prior opportunity for Senator Evans, the Democrats and the Greens to formally move their amendments. Perhaps they will do so now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to you, Mr Chairman. Perhaps before I move my amendments, I can make some response to Senator Vanstone. It seems that one of the most strong, universal and long-lasting forces to beat in the Tory breast is the urge for precedent—the urge to find something that has been done before one does it again. This distaste for doing anything for the first time, this distaste for looking beyond the precedent to the principle and recognising that the particular principle may be absolutely—
—You can save your breath if you want to be patronising.

—I am not being patronising. I am being descriptive of the urge for authority, the urge for the ancients to have laid the ground rules before the coalition as a modern, does anything about advancing a particular cause. It is inherent in the conservative character. It is what it is all about. The coalition does not do anything for the first time; that is why it is usually left lamenting as the world moves on. Having made that sort of general point, by way of just touching up a little, I now turn to the technical issues—
—I am no more a conservative than you are a communist. It is just so stupidly inane and repetitive to make those kinds of remarks.

—Okay. That is fair enough. But there still is a certain instinct at work in the coalition that wants to find a precedent for everything before it does anything. The point at issue here is not whether there is a particular precedent for this precise form of words, but whether there is authority for words having the effect of these particular words in statutes, or in other ways that have been recognised by the High Court. The truth of the matter is that there is ample such authority. I will quote from the opinion of the Acting Solicitor-General of Australia, Dennis Rose QC, which I sought yesterday in response to a request from Senator Vanstone and which I tabled last night. Paragraph 15 states:

SPEECH.PARA: If it were objected against clause 11 that it provides for the common law to have the `force of law' rather than providing that, for example, the rules of the common law `shall apply . . . . . . ' . . . the objection would entirely lack merit. The High Court is familiar with the concept of statutes giving the force of law to the provisions of an agreement—ie. of creating statutory rights and obligations over and above common law contractual obligations (eg. Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1 at 31, 89). Section 11 would be accorded an exactly similar effect in giving the force of law to the provisions of the common law in respect of native title.

Other aspects of this opinion deal with the suggestion of Senator Vanstone yesterday that this section might be void for uncertainty. Another paragraph of the opinion deals with the expression in the case of Jackson v. Gambol about the `law of the Commonwealth', being an expression `not appropriate to describe a rule or principle of the common law'. That is explained and put in context and, clearly, it does not determine the matter in issue here.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular issues that have been raised by Senator Vanstone, I do not want to go on at nauseous length about the issues here. I suppose it is always going to be a matter of competing legal judgments. We will not know the answer to this question until it is tested. On the particular issues that Senator Vanstone has raised, the Commonwealth is completely confident of its position and a summary expression of that confidence is contained in the Rose advice. It might be helpful for those who might ever be minded to look back at these proceedings if the text of that advice were to be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave accordingly.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: NATIVE TITLE BILL 1993, CLAUSE 11
OPINION
I have been asked whether clause 11 of the Native Title Bill 1993, if enacted in the terms set out below, would be valid.
2. In my opinion, the answer is clearly `Yes'. The High Court would regard the contrary argument as wholly misconceived.
3. Clause 11 reads as follows:
"11. Subject to this Act, the common law of Australia in respect of native title has, after 30 June 1993, the force of a law of the Commonwealth."

4. This provision, when read with clause 208(1) and other provisions of the Bill, would be a valid exercise of the power of the Commonwealth Parliament under section 51(xxvi) of the Constitution to make laws with respect to `the persons of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws'.

5. The effect of section 11 would be to give Commonwealth statutory force to the provisions of the common law of Australia in respect of native title. Section 11 would be a `law of the Commonwealth' within the meaning of section 109 of the Constitution, and therefore any State legislation inconsistent with the relevant common law rights would be invalid to the extent of the inconsistency. Issues as to the existence or content of native title in particular cases, in so far as native title would have Commonwealth statutory force, would be matters `arising under [a law] made by the Parliament `(ie. under section 11) within the meaning of section 76(ii) of the Constitution, and so federal jurisdiction could be validly conferred on the High Court and the Federal Court in such matters.

6. I have been asked to comment specifically on suggestions that section 11 might be `void for uncertainty' on the ground that the common law is not set out anywhere in any `definitive verbal formulation'. It is true that it is not set out anywhere in definitive terms: it is `developed' by the courts (eg. Dietrich v The Queen (1992) 176 CLR 292, at 318-321). In the event of inconsistencies between the decisions of courts other than the High Court, the issues can ultimately be resolved in that court, though of course the High Court can overrule its own decisions. However, the fact that the common law may be uncertain is not a ground for saying that it cannot be given Commonwealth statutory force. After all, there has never been any doubt concerning the ability of the Parliament to `pick up' the provisions of State legislation even though those provisions may be vague and court decisions may vary and fluctuate concerning their correct interpretation.
7. The High Court has never expressed any doubts concerning previous instances of Commonwealth legislation `picking up' the common law.
8. Examples include section 4 of the Crimes Act 1914 which provides that
`the principles of the common law with respect to criminal liability shall, subject to this Act, apply in relation to offences against this Act.'
9.Similarly, section 80 of the Judiciary Act 1903 provides as follows:

`So far as the laws of the Commonwealth are not applicable or so far as their provisions are insufficient to carry them into effect, or to provide adequate remedies or punishment, the common law in Australia as modified by the Constitution and by the statute law in force in the State or Territory in which the Court in which the jurisdiction is exercised is held shall, so far as it is applicable and not inconsistent with the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth, govern all Courts exercising federal jurisdiction in the exercise of their jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters.'
10. Other examples are section 103(1) of the Cheques and Payment Orders Act 1986 and section 4 of the Marine Insurance Act 1909.

11. Yet another example is section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903 which, from the earliest years of the century, has been understood as applying the common law (as well as statute law) to the Commonwealth (Baume v The Queen (1906) 4 CLR 97; also The Commonwealth v Evans Deakin Industries Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 254).

12. A further example is found in the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970 which applies in, and in relation to, `Commonwealth places' in a State the provisions of `the laws of [the] State', defined in section 3 to include `unwritten' law—ie. the common law.

13. Provisions such as these have been applied by the High Court without any suggestion that they are defective by reason of the `indeterminate' nature of the common law (see, for example, Pedersen v Young (1964) 110 CLR 162; Hooper v Hooper (1975) 91 CLR 529; also Lane, The Australian Federal System 2nd ed. 1976, at 691). I have no doubt that the High Court would take the same approach to the proposed section 11.

14. I have been specifically asked to comment on the statement in Jackson v Gamble (1983) VR 552 at 559 by Young CJ that the expression `law of the Commonwealth' in section 109 is `not appropriate to describe a rule or principle of the common law'. With respect, that may well be so. But it clearly does not follow from that statement that, where a rule or principle of the common law is given the force of law by a Commonwealth Act, the latter is not a `law of the Commonwealth' within the meaning of section 109.

15. If it were objected against clause 11 that it provides for the common law to have the `force of law' rather than providing that, for example, the rules of the common law `shall apply . . . . . . ' (cf. examples in paragraphs 8-12 above), the objection would entirely lack merit. The High Court is familiar with the concept of statutes giving the force of law to the provisions of an agreement—ie. of creating statutory rights and obligations over and above common law contractual obligations (eg. Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1, at 31, 89). Section 11 would be accorded an exactly similar effect in giving the force of law to the provisions of the common law in respect of native title.
16. For these reasons I conclude that constitutional objections to section 11 would be wholly misconceived.
DENNIS ROSE QC
20 December 1993

(a)for the purpose of satisfying their personal, domestic or non-commercial communal funds; and
(b)in exercise or enjoyment of their native title rights and interests.
"(3) Each of the following is a separate `class of activity':
(a)hunting;
(b)fishing;
(c)gathering;

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 197, page 86, subclause (3), line 2, omit the subclause, substitute:

PARA.TAB: "(3) Any confirmation under this section does not extinguish or impair any native title rights and interests and does not affect any conferral of land or waters, or an interest in land or waters, under a law that confers benefit only on Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders.".

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 33B to insert the new clause 196A seeks to ensure that Aboriginal people are not prevented from exercising their inherent native title rights and interests in circumstances where state and Commonwealth laws allow others to engage in those activities. The amendment does not prevent a state or the Commonwealth from prohibiting a native title activity where it is necessary, for example, for genuine conservation reasons, but it does prevent them from doing so while allowing others to engage in that same activity. In other words, the amendment prevents laws from having a discriminatory operation on Aboriginal people whose rights to conduct certain activities can sometimes be traced back many thousands of years.

PARA.TAB: The clause is particularly important for those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who may already be largely dispossessed and whose native title rights are limited to particular activities or resources. Without it there could be a creeping process of dispossession as native title rights are regulated out of existence, one by one, while other people remain free to carry out those same activities.

The clause is critical in protecting Aboriginal rights to hunt, fish and gather where the impact of the activity is not such as to require its non-discriminatory prohibition. The clause is limited in its operation to native title rights in relation to hunting, fishing, gathering or cultural or spiritual activities where those activities are for personal, domestic or communal purposes. Other types of activities can also be prescribed if the need arises. A similar protection of native title rights exists in Canada and New Zealand.

Amendment No. 34A is simply an effective confirmation under clause 197(2). It is basically to prevent the impairment of interest where native title rights may already be present in relation to land or waters. I cite a letter from Dr Dermot Smyth, honorary research fellow at James Cook University, who was a consultant to the Resource Assessment Commission's coastal zone inquiry:

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the bill as it now stands will not allow native title fishing rights to be exercised in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia or Tasmania because laws in those states do not make any special provisions for Aboriginal fishing interests. In view of the current harassment, prosecution and occasional gaoling of Aboriginal fishers in southern states, it would be extremely unfortunate if the native title bill does not allow traditional fishing rights to coexist with statutory fishing laws.

It is really in response to that that the Greens present their two amendments. We also indicate that we are not willing to support government amendment No. 45. We have looked at the existing clause. We see that there is quite a clear confirmation of ownership of natural resources , access to beaches, et cetera, by the Crown. We believe that that is sufficient. We are therefore not prepared to change the wording from `fishing access' to `statutory fishing rights'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support amendment No. 33B, which relates to the new clause 196(A), in the form in which Senator Chamarette moved it. I also indicate that we will support amendment No. 34A.

PARA.TAB: This shows how sanctimonious and unctuous those opposite can be when they want to ram through a political point. I do not mean that. I am raising it because the government has a bit of a hide marching in here and waving around an opinion as if to say, `This is the truth and the light'—despite the fact that the minister's favourite prefix to any statement is `the truth of the matter is'.

PARA.TAB: The final answer in any of these matters is not always easy to discern. The government does itself some disservice in rubbishing a view put by others. Maybe that view later proves to be wrong, but so might its view. The government, when it has wanted to go without precedent—this is the risk it runs in this respect—does not mention that it runs a very serious risk. Last but not least, I have a remark to make about the Australian Democrats.

The clause was deferred on Friday or Saturday because the government or someone else wanted to deal with clause 196(a). It is now the subject of this guillotine. Plenty of people might want to put a range of more detailed views. Heaven knows, the government might even have some more intelligent pearls of wisdom to share with us, but time will not allow for that. The reason for that is that chamber debate is no longer seen as the way to effect improvements in a bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly not by your side.

—That is another one of the minister's gratuitous remarks designed simply to extend the debate. PARA.TAB: What we have seen this time is one of the minor parties, the Democrats, join with the Greens to make a deal outside this place.
