TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister a question about the amendment moved by the Greens (WA). I presume that this amendment has been accepted by the government. It is my understanding that Aboriginal people will have rights to hunting, fishing and gathering and that they will not need a licence to do so whereas other Australians will. Is that correct?
—Usually, yes, that is right.
—So Aboriginal Australians will be given the right to do something without a licence that other Australians need a licence to do?
—Yes.
—On what basis was that decision made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Simply because of the desire that the government has, and I think most Australians have, of giving recognition to the particular customs and practices of our indigenous inhabitants, to the extent that they retain them and to the extent that they form part of the bundle of rights that have been traditionally associated with native title or are properly described as native title in the particular context. The idea of amendment 33B is not to immunise native titleholders completely from the operation of state laws of general application that bear upon hunting, fishing, gathering and things of that kind, such that they can do anything at all. In particular, it is not the intention of this clause to authorise activity pursuant to a native title claim which would involve the destruction of an endangered species—animal, bird or plant.
—Where does it say that?
—We get there because of the requirement in clause 196A(1)(b), which says that subsection (2) applies if:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory prohibits or restricts persons from carrying on the class of activity other than in accordance with a licence, permit or other instrument granted or issued to them under the law;

Killing of endangered species is not the kind of activity which is permitted at all, whether by licence, permit or otherwise. The whole point of endangered species legislation around the country is to prohibit absolutely the activity in question. It is not to regulate it by prohibiting it absolutely except with a licence or a permit. Rather, it prohibits it absolutely.

PARA.TAB: So the kind of threshold hurdle that has to be satisfied before this legislative provision bites is that the activity in question be the kind of activity which is permitted to at least some people provided they have a permit or licence. What the clause does for Aboriginal people is enable them to engage in the activity in question without that permit or licence, provided that they have got a native title umbrella under which to exercise the right in question.

There were ways of spelling that out more directly. This is a bit indirect; it does need to be explained to be understood, but it is there. The way the clause is constructed, it is intended to be sensitive to that particular concern.

Might I say further about this whole business of exemptions from state laws of general application, as we discussed at a very early stage of this committee debate, a lot of things are going to have to be subject to review in terms of the way in which particular state laws operate, whether they are gun laws, licensing laws or things of that kind, just to get a slightly greater degree of clarity perhaps into a number of the areas in question.

I think Senator Chamarette might have mentioned the particular example of south coast New South Wales Aboriginal people who have traditionally engaged in abalone gathering or abalone fishing. There have been difficulties in the context of being prosecuted because there is an absolute prohibition on that activity unless it is done by way of licence by commercial fishermen. What this does is not confer an absolute open slather right to engage in abalone fishing. It confers, however, a right to do so by Aboriginal people who have a native title—and, of course, they have to establish that before they will be completely immunised from prosecution and so on under this clause. They have a right to carry on that activity where they do so—this is in subclause (2)(a) and (b)—for the purpose of satisfying their personal, domestic or non-commercial communal needs and they are doing it in the exercise or enjoyment of their native title rights and interests.

What this means is that individuals or small family groups or small community groups can engage in this activity provided it does not have any commercial character about it and provided it is carried on under the umbrella of the native title right, and can do so with immunity from the operation of the general law. But acknowledge and recognise again that this only applies in situations where the activity is not absolutely prohibited but is allowed to be carried on by some people, provided they have a permit or licence, whether it is for commercial purposes or otherwise.
I guess kangaroo shooting would be another good example. Licensed kangaroo shooters may need a licence—I do not know; it varies from state to state.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do, yes.

—Arguably, one would not need a licence to shoot kangaroo in the sort of situation that is contemplated here, provided all these other conditions apply. I think that is a pretty reasonable balance of interest that has been struck once those opposite understand the way the clause has been constructed. It is a fairly intricate and balanced clause. That is why we did not have it quite ready to wave around to honourable senators the other day. I just stated the intention rather than giving honourable senators the language. When one looks at the language, one will see that it does the job and ought not raise too many hackles.

—I understand what the minister is saying—that Aboriginals do not need a licence whereas other Australians do but that if a licence is prohibited then Aboriginals are also prohibited from engaging in such activity. I would like to ask the minister a question about wild turkeys. To my knowledge, Aborigines are allowed to take wild turkeys and we are not.
—The well-known bustard.

—There are few of those around not far from here. I suppose Senator Collins could jump up and claim that he is offended. Is there any recognition of bag limits. Is there any mention of management by fisheries? The fishing industry is mindful that the government has used licences and imposed limits in its management of the industry. Is there any recognition of that? Is there any recognition of closed seasons in respect of crayfish?

PARA.TAB: I have asked the minister a list of questions—and I hope he can remember them all—so that we do not have to jump up and down all the time. The minister has said that Aboriginals will be able to fish for abalone; but if I wanted to dive for abalone I would have to put up $1 million first. So it would be a big cost to me, but the Aboriginals could do it for nothing. I would like the minister to comment on that. I would also like to know whether the Aboriginals have to use traditional weapons. The minister mentioned firearms. People have to get licences for their rifles in order to shoot kangaroos; will the Aboriginals have to get firearms licences? I ask the minister to comment on traditional weapons, bag limits and closed seasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no specific reference to bag limits, but there is a reference, which I have read out to Senator Panizza, which limits it to `satisfying their personal, domestic or non-commercial communal needs'. What that will mean, in terms of the amount of the particular game, fish or whatever is taken, will obviously depend on the particular circumstance. But they are reasonably easily ascertainable limits and the sort of thing that courts, tribunals and so on are used to dealing with and applying. It is just on the balance of reasonable knowledge about how much is fair enough in terms of satisfying that sort of criteria.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, one would not have to engage in the same sorts of start-up costs that are involved for professional abalone fishing ventures. Normally a fishing operation of a certain kind—abalone is a very good example—can be done only on a commercial and licensed basis where everybody else is prohibited and if one is going to do it at all, one has to have a big start-up fee at the threshold to get into the game and so on. The whole point of this is to say that, notwithstanding all those normal restrictions, native titleholders can bypass them, provided that—and the proviso is very important—it is on a very small, intimate and personal scale and they are doing it pursuant to a genuinely held native title right.

It is not just any Aboriginal people who can henceforth descend upon the abalone fishing waters and go for their life. They are only able to justify the taking if it is part of the particular tradition associated with their communal group and they can establish a native title right accordingly. So there is still a long way to go and I would not advise people who might be tempted to take advantage of this clause to rush off and do so without considering their legal position very carefully indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't stopped some people before, not necessarily Aborigines.

—No, and some of them are subject to prosecution. There have been some interesting and well publicised cases of that kind, but there has been no defence available to anyone in the past. We believe—we agree with the Greens in this respect and I understand the Democrats also support this particular clause—that there is ample justification for extending it in this way. There is no requirement that the method of hunting, fishing or gathering be confined to traditional means. Life moves on, the world moves on, and with it techniques for doing these things. There is no intention to deny that right.

PARA.TAB: Whether or not the exemption that is set out here would extend to an exemption from obtaining the permit for the firearm in question is, I think, extremely doubtful. What is being referred to here is an exemption from the prohibition of carrying out some activity. It is not the possession of the firearm so much as the actual shooting of the firearm to take game or whatever. But I do not want to give yet another kerbside opinion—I have given a few hundred of them in the last few days—that would be a matter to be sorted out subsequently.

So far as fishing is concerned, I will make a general point. I think we will be in a bit of trouble with amendment 45 to clause 197 unless the opposition has a bit of a think about supporting this. The Greens have indicated opposition to it and we cannot carry it without the opposition's support. This is a very explicit industry provision. It is another one of a kind. Those opposite have already knocked three of them off by taking the stance that they have in relation to this legislation. I draw their attention to our amendment No. 45, which is intended to clarify the existing 197(1)(c). It presently reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . existing fishing access rights—
which would include both public and private rights—
prevail over any other public or private rights.

This amendment makes it clear that it is statutory fishing rights—not existing fishing access rights—which prevail over any other fishing rights. In other words, this clarifies that states and territories may act to confirm that statutory fishing rights prevail over any other kind of fishing rights, and that includes any native title rights that may exist. I think that is a pretty important principle from the point of view of the fishing industry and the certainty that it wants to inject. That would not cut across the debate we have just been having about our proposed new clause 196(a), because in that context there is a specific exemption provided for certain kinds of fishing activities in certain circumstances, as with other kinds of hunting activities. This is clearly a protective provision designed to clarify the law and to assist the industry to give it a degree of certainty.

PARA.TAB: It looks as though this provision will go down unless there is a willingness to support it on the opposition side. I know Senator Panizza has a close and intense interest in the fishing industry, which he demonstrated again in the contribution he has just made. Maybe as a last dying gesture on the bill, he would contemplate coming across and bringing a couple of his mates with him in order to make a hero of himself with the fishing industry in WA. If he does not, I guess this is another particular matter which we will need to look at in the new year as part of some reviewing legislation. But I do make that invitation. The opposition has already scored three ducks in terms of major industry clauses which it has been asked to support; this is a chance to avoid the fourth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the minister's attention to subclauses 192(1), (2) and (3). They proceed to set up by regulation the fund to be established, the payments to be made in and out of that fund, the circumstances in which such payments may be made, persons to operate the fund and so on. I would like to draw to the minister's attention the fact that the whole of that clause seems to me to be a quite extraordinary delegation of legislative power, in that all of the provisions are to be made by regulation.

PARA.TAB: I am a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and one of the frames of reference for that committee is the inappropriate delegation of legislative powers. There was no comment made on the bill at the time that the committee looked at it and I have endeavoured to make some further examination of it today, but at this late stage of the session it is obviously not possible to refer it to our legal adviser. I would be very interested in the minister's opinion as to why this has occurred. The regulations obviously leave a very wide power for the government to proceed in the way that it does. Why is there not sufficient detail? Was the drafter hassled by the time he got to this particular stage of the bill? These are very important questions with respect to the persons who are to operate the fund, the investment of money standing to the credit of the fund, the keeping of accounts, the reporting and so on. I would be interested in the minister's reply to those questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of the land fund is one of the central elements in the policy which lies behind the government's response here. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made that very clear in his second reading speech, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a first step, we are establishing a land fund. It will enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage and maintain it in a sustainable way in order to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations.

A number of other statements have spelt that out in much more detail. I wish to make two points. First, there is no need in embarking on a policy initiative of this kind and putting it into practice to create a legislative framework for it at all. We could do it as a matter of straightforward executive government program expenditure. There would need to be an appropriation provision in the annual budget or provided for in some other way to authorise the appropriation of money for the expenditure purpose in question. But we do not need any formal legislative authorisation for this kind of expenditure.

PARA.TAB: The framework here is just that—very skeletal in character and not spelling out the detail of it in terms of criteria and everything else. It is a reflection not only of the fact that these things have not been fully worked through yet and that we have to go through a more substantial consultative process, but also the reflection of the fact that there is no need for this sort of stuff to be in the legislation at all. We wanted to put it in the bill to make clear our commitment to this important part of the total strategy, just as the social justice package aspect of it is equally an important part of the strategy, although one is less amenable to legislative reference at all. That is the broad point I want to make.

The more specific and second point I want to make is in relation to these regulations that will need to be quite detailed to fill this out in a much more substantial way. They are disallowable instruments and there will be ample opportunity for the parliament to consider and respond to them when they are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his comment that those regulations are far too skeletal. I would still like to know why that has not been fleshed out. I would simply like to say that I will be bringing it to the attention of the committee for the scrutiny of bills. I am sure the Minister's comment about disallowance will come to the further attention of the chamber.

—I would like to refer to the two amendments proposed by the Greens. I wonder whether Senator Chamarette is interested in this debate; I notice she is in a special huddle at the back of the chamber. I am interested in pursuing a couple of comments with regard to her amendments that relate to inserting new clause 196A and also a substituted clause 197(3). I think the minister has indicated he is inclined to support these amendments. Therefore, it is important to get both a Green and a Labor response to these issues.

PARA.TAB: New clause 196A says that if a law of a state or territory prohibits or restricts a person with native title rights from hunting and fishing, except in accordance with a licence or a permit, then that law will be ineffective where the native titleholders are hunting, fishing, et cetera, for their own personal, domestic or non-commercial communal needs.

Some examples of this operation would be to preserve the numbers of a particular species of fish. A law of a state prohibits the catching of that species except to the holders of a limited number of licences. If there are people with native title rights in respect of these areas, they will be immune from this law and will be able to fish the species at will for communal needs. This is clearly undesirable. I would have thought that the Greens, from their environmental perspective, would have been very concerned about that form of control. This is the sort of activity that governments—necessarily state and territory governments—should be able to control.

The questions that I would pose about this proposed amendment are as follows. Is it intended to apply only to native title land and waters, or will its application be wider? For instance, does it extend to pastoral leases, other leases and freehold land? Probably from the minister's point of view with regard to this amendment, I would ask very plainly: is it within the constitutional power of the Commonwealth?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the amendment is only confined to native title areas—land and waters. For many years the Green movement has firmly believed that the care with which Australia was looked after for 40,000 years and the degree of environmental damage that the past 200 years has imposed on it clearly demonstrates that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples had the best interests and the stewardship of the land at heart and did a much better job than unfortunately we have been able to do. We therefore have no concerns regarding how they are likely to deal with land and waters that are under their native title claims. We understand that this amendment is actually in place simply to ensure that they are not discriminated against when we are allowing licences to be issued in the lands where they have traditionally hunted, fished and gathered their food and been part of their own cultural activities.

PARA.TAB: We see a failure to pass this amendment as a discriminatory activity. We see an inclusion of it as a simple recognition of the fact that Aboriginal people have a spiritual and profound connection with the land and a profound respect as to the way in which they deal with it in regard to any animals or vegetation that might be connected with that land.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of my question related to the constitutionality of this issue. Senator Chamarette expresses a very naive belief in the faith of Aboriginal culture. While I am not in any way intending to put Aboriginal culture or tradition down, I would point out that many of the claimants for such purposes of native title today are not the Aborigines of 200 or 300 years ago with established custom and tradition. Many of them today need and require the protection of the various state controls and regulations, whether they be environmental or anything else. There are many Aborigines today who do not use the same systems, traditions and cultures that the Greens obviously very naively believe in.

PARA.TAB: I direct the second part of my question on this clause to the minister. Is this amendment within the constitutional power of the Commonwealth?

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe it clearly is. Under the race power of the constitution—subsection 51(xxvi)—it is clearly designed to confer a benefit upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people pursuant to the native title rights that they hold in these situations. It is a very clear-cut application of that particular part of the constitution and I think on any view would clearly be sustainable were it ever to be challenged under section 109 of the constitution.

—My second issue arises out of clause 197, which reflects on the capacity of states and territories to confirm ownership and control of certain resources where they are said to be subject to the provisions of this bill. The minister acknowledged earlier that there were some very serious complications with the present clause that obviously will have to be addressed by the government in future. The minister has already acknowledged that he has discovered some points; I think it was in clause (3) or something like that.

PARA.TAB: I draw to his attention the expression in subclause 197(1)—`subject to this act'. Because those words appear, the confirmation by the government of the ownership of minerals, the control of waters and fishing rights may now need to go through the future acts regime in the bill and compensation may be payable. If these matters are not addressed and clear, there will be an endless loop of litigation along with the resulting costs and delays that will arise.

The Greens have addressed clause 197 with its amendment 34A, which the government has indicated it is inclined to support. It substitutes subclause 197(3). The existing subclause 197(1) allows states and territories to confirm the right of ownership of natural resources. Subclause 197(2) allows confirmation of public access to and enjoyment of things like beaches and the banks of rivers. The present subclause 197(3) says that subclause 197(2) does not extinguish any native title rights or affect any land that has already been granted to Aboriginal people.

Proposed clause 197(3) is said to apply to both 197(1) and 197(2) and not just 197(2), as is currently in the bill, and extends not just to extinguishment but is also said to prevent any impairment of native title rights and interests. It may be that state and territory laws confirming existing ownership of resources, control of waters or existing statutory fishing rights may impair native title rights. The Greens' amendment sets up internal inconsistencies between these subclauses. This will be fertile ground for these legal disputes. I therefore ask the minister, seeing he is inclined to accept this amendment: will the law confirming the crown control of waters prevail or will it be struck down because it impairs some native title interests? The amendment changes the whole meaning and purpose of clause 197 and should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was all a bit of a fly in and flourish from Senator Tambling, but I do not think it is justified by the material in front of him. The Greens' amendment number 34A which seeks to introduce a new subclause (3) to clause 197 is supported by the government because we believe that it represents a careful balancing of the rights of native titleholders and those in the wider community as may be asserted by states and territories.

PARA.TAB: The provision in issue here is one that is simply intended to clarify that the mere confirmation of existing statutory provisions will not, of itself, extinguish or impair native title. That is not at odds with the other subclauses here. It does not fight against them in any way. It does not confuse or complicate them. It is simply an additional clarifying provision which we believe is justified.

As to Senator Tambling's point about other aspects of clause 197, in particular 197(1), Senator Tambling made reference to the phrase `subject to this act'. Sometimes I think that does appear as a bit of legislative draftsman's twitch. It is not always justified; it does not always have any really substantive content. Here I think the clear intention, however, is to say that while the law of the Commonwealth, state or territory may confirm these various things, it cannot go further in so confirming those rights than this act allows.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't go into the endless litigation loop?

—I do not think that that follows from this. Confirming existing ownership of natural resources; confirming any existing right of the Crown in relation to water; confirming any existing fishing access rights as prevailing over other rights—
—Does not subject it to the negotiation?

—The third point in (c) is one, of course, that we want to amend. I do not see it as having that effect, Senator Tambling. I stand to be corrected if the course of events proves otherwise but the government does not have that fear.

PARA.TAB: I think the real need for amendment of clause 197 is in relation to the particular provision that I mentioned, and that is the government's own amendment to that clause, amendment 45, which would have the effect of making rather clearer than is the case at the moment that statutory fishing rights prevail over any others, subject to the act. That means in this instance subject, for example, to 196A. But that particular provision, as I said a few minutes ago to Senator Panizza, is one that I know the industry would very much welcome and Senator Tambling will have his chance to assist in this respect by supporting this particular amendment—and I hope he contemplates doing so, even though it would be breaking a duck in terms of his approach to this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to Senator Chamarette's amendment 33B which deals with the classes of activities involved in hunting, fishing, gathering, cultural and spiritual activities, et cetera. I am concerned, bearing in mind the reasons for the Greens being here and their considerable concern about the environment and endangered species, that amongst those activities there is or has been known to be the use of the deliberate lighting of fires. I am wondering just where this is covered and what would be the situation if fires were to be deliberately lit where there is a prohibition on the lighting of fires. Could people with native title claim that as a defence? There have been situations in the north-west of Western Australia where fires have been lit along a 200-mile front, which can cause tremendous damage to the environment and to species of animals.

PARA.TAB: I think perhaps my question really ought to be directed to Senator Chamarette first. Is it intended in the Greens' amendment that this is the sort of activity that would be allowed to continue, even though it will cause harm to the environment and to native animals?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson for his question. The environment movement has been very clear in its stance on these practices—and that includes all the environmental practices of Aboriginal people—and that is that the beneficial aspects of those practices far outweigh any negative effects. Certainly they far outweigh the negative impacts of our own practices. In Western Australia the Department of Conservation and Land Management actually uses the burning techniques that it ascribes to Aboriginal people. Those techniques actually arouse considerable concern every season as more and more of our old growth forests are burnt.

PARA.TAB: We do not have any evidence that suggests that the practices of Aboriginal people on their own native title land will be in any way a problem. I must add that, in this specific amendment, all we are doing is looking at removing a discriminatory feature of state law. The particular emphasis is on fishing and sea rights. I remind the committee that this amendment is in response to a consultant's report by a person who actually made a submission to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That person included an extract from the final report of the Resource Assessment Commission's coastal zone inquiry and also a copy of his final consultant's report to that inquiry. From this leading environmentalist we have quite clearly an understanding that it is in Australia's interests to give recognition to indigenous people and the kinds of environmental practices that they have managed to preserve over hundreds of years in an ecologically sustainable way. We have a lot to emulate.

In Queensland, for example, there has been a co-existence of the Wilderness Society and the Aboriginal people. They have formed management plans. The Greens believe that if we give Aboriginal people the recognition they deserve and then have some concerns regarding environmental practice, that will give us an opportunity to negotiate and share in management plans where they are actually able to assist us with the benefit of their years of acquired wisdom.
There is a discrepancy. Through you, Madam Chair, I ask Senator Ferguson whether he raised a concern about state laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in my question.

—I will spare Senator Ferguson and respond to Senator Tambling's question about the variation in state laws. There is considerable variation in state law in relation to all these environmental management matters and these laws could be made more appropriate and consistent.

—May I make a small supplementary contribution? In the case of bush fire control situations, there is no doubt that on a day of absolute fire ban there would be an absolute prohibition, not allowing anyone to light a fire for any purpose, whatever the quality of the track record and the traditional management of the particular area in question. That applies notwithstanding whatever permits for burning off particular classes of non-Aboriginal people might be able to obtain. If there is an absolute provision, as is the case on an absolute fire ban day, as there is for a good deal of the summer months in critical tinder areas of the country, there would be no grounds for an exemption.

PARA.TAB: The other point to make is that the kind of burning off case that people have in mind here would have to be carried out in order to satisfy the terms of this particular clause in the exercise or enjoyment of their native title rights and interests. Not just any Aboriginal person in any context whatsoever could wander around lighting up stretches of the bush and claiming that there was some justification for that. It would have to be very carefully and clearly associated with a native title interest. If there are any geographical boundaries to that interest, as one would normally expect there to be, then one would expect the practice to be confined in that way. If it were done in a way such as to put at risk neighbouring properties or things of that kind, then again there would be ample grounds for controlling the activity and not regarding it as exempt in this way.

I think this is one aspect of it. As with a lot of these things that are subject to exemptions from state laws, it does need further review and monitoring. We have said that from day one. But this is a complex area. The intention here was simply to map out, in a way that did seem capable of at least being crafted in the context of this legislation, one set of exemptions but to take on notice some of larger problems that are associated with this area and perhaps revisit this over the course of the next year or so. That would also involve monitoring the potential application of some of these existing provisions that are in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that contribution. I think it is easy to talk about total fire ban and prohibition days from metropolitan Melbourne or, in Senator Chamarette's case, from metropolitan Perth. However, there are vast tracts of Australia where fires are prohibited for periods of up to six months. There is total fire prohibition. It is not just a fire ban day; there is a total prohibition. That is six months of the year when we cannot light any fire of any description.

PARA.TAB: The other point I would make is that, if there is special consideration given to native titleholders with regard to the lighting of fires, Senator Chamarette needs to be reminded that, when fires are lit, they do not always stop at the boundary of a native title. I have known fires to burn through fences and then to burn on to destroy cattle on privately owned cattle stations and pastoral leases. So, if these sorts of activities are to be allowed to occur at all under the protection of native title, it puts at risk people who are not protected under native title and who have no other comeback.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who pays the damages?
—Who pays the bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that this amendment does not in any way affect the operation of total fire bans or any of the practices Senator Ferguson is concerned about; it simply prevents the removal of rights to traditional activities that are legitimate in areas that are subject to native title claims. Those areas that have been raised recently are not a concern. The area where there is a concern—which is the justification for this amendment—is the one which Senator Panizza mentioned earlier. I would like to respond to his concern that, in some way, co-existence of native title rights and commercial and recreational fishing would be a problem.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the grave concern that Dr Dermot Smyth raised with us about this Native Title Bill. He sent his report to me urgently in the light of the possibility that the Greens could make some changes to what he believes is retrograde legislation. There are states and territories where fishing rights are recognised, namely, in the northern part of Australia, and there are those states and territories where such rights are recognised to some extent, but in the south of Australia they are not. In his report Dr Smyth states:

SPEECH.PARA: State and territory laws fail to adequately protect subsistence fishing resources and marine sacred sites, and in much of southern Australia the current laws lead to harassment, prosecution and even imprisonment of Aboriginal people engaged in traditional fishing practices.
Dr Smyth notes in his report that the bill does not formally recognise the co-existence of native title fishing rights with state laws. He states:
Such co-existence—
this is in the north—

would not, in my view, result in any significant dislocation of Australia's commercial or recreational fisheries—across northern Australia indigenous people are already exempt from most fisheries laws and regulations. It would, however, permit those Aboriginal people in southern Australia who wish to continue their traditional practices to do so . . . It may also encourage fisheries managers to actively seek the involvement of Aboriginal fishers in the management of Australia's fisheries.

Senator Bishop referred earlier to that aspect of the recognition of native title rights. It is an opportunity for genuine reconciliation that is based on the justice of recognising practices that Aboriginal people have been conducting for many years and for which they have suffered persecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier the minister answered a question from Senator Panizza about fishing. I want to follow up that answer, particularly with regard to non-commercial communal quantities. I think the minister said that these quantities are easily identified or can easily be quantified. I would like to know who on earth would be able to decide what is the correct amount of a non-commercial communal fishing quota or amount to be caught.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that really disturbs me is: what if the `non-commercial communal quantity' together with `personal or domestic' means that it is enough to either hunt an animal or fish to extinction? The thing that really concerns me is that, if a species is endangered, there is no provision in this legislation that says that, under the terms of personal, domestic or non-communal commercial needs, it cannot be fished or hunted to extinction. I would like to know why this law should apply to holders of native title to allow them to hunt and so on when other non-Aboriginal Australians are not entitled to do the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Ferguson's first question, the normal context in which one would expect this kind of issue to arise would be by way of a defence to a prosecution—for example, of the kind that has been launched against some Aboriginal people on the south coast of New South Wales who have been taking abalone, notwithstanding the absolute prohibition upon such taking other than by those who are commercially licensed. Then it would be a matter for the court at which the case was heard to apply this particular provision and satisfy itself, firstly, that the native title right existed. This creates an interesting task for the court. It might want to adjourn the matter whilst these things are considered and maybe the claim just would not be able to be credibly made, unless it had been through some determination process—and that may well be the situation.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the court, once it was satisfied that there was a genuine native title based claim, would then have to address these issues of quantity that are concerned and make a judgment on the practicalities of the matter, how much of the fish or—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it doesn't.
—These are the sorts of judgments that the courts make every day of the week, judgments about `commercial quantities'. In various contexts these are judgements that can be made—
—Oh rubbish!

—Senator Bishop would know; she knows everything. These judgments can be made on the basis of the available evidence bearing upon the particular facts of the particular case. That is all I can say. There is no point in me waffling on further about it and adding further conditions and criteria which ought to be self-evident.

PARA.TAB: As to the other point that Senator Ferguson made, I repeat again that I am not aware of any endangered species legislation. I stand to be corrected if we have other information.

TALK.START.PARA: —In our state we have very small bag limits on fish.

—Usually endangered speeches legislation amounts to a total prohibition; therefore you would be in breach of that if you sought to take it. If there is a total prohibition, it is not an activity in respect of which a permit or licence is given to anybody. I will put it this way: with the really endangered species, those where every single example, every individual element of animal, bird or fish in the species is at risk, there is an absolute prohibition. The black cod is a good example of a fish; the platypus is an example of a mammal; and there are birds where there are absolute prohibitions. There is no question about that.
—Under native title they can't be?
—Even with native title, under this clause you cannot take any sample at all.
—What about wild turkeys?

—I do not know about wild turkey. That was a brand of American bourbon. That is the most I know about wild turkey but that is again demonstrating my city qualifications. If one is talking about species which are less endangered but in respect of which obviously there is some sort of management or control regime in place with bag limits or something of that kind—
—In danger, rather than endangered.

—Yes. Then I think one is faced with the situation of just acknowledging that the kind of quantum that would be involved in Aboriginal native titleholders taking that species would not be such as to contribute a major problem. If there were an open-ended exemption for Aboriginal native titleholders, simply because they were Aboriginal native titleholders, to take commercial quantities of the species in question, maybe the alarm bells would properly jangle. Under those circumstances, one would say, `Hang on; that is going too far'.

PARA.TAB: But the limits that are in the bill satisfying personal, domestic or non-commercial communal needs I genuinely believe set a stringent enough criterion not to be a problem for what Senator Ferguson describes as species in some danger, rather than endangered species. We could not have a criterion as loose as that with species that were genuinely totally endangered and in respect of which there was a total prohibition elsewhere. That would be too loose a criterion, but for other sorts of species like ducks and so on where there are bag limits, then one would see this as a reasonable way through the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some brief remarks to the government's amendment to clause 197(1)(c). It would seem to me from having read the fishing industry's careful submissions to the Senate standing committee's review of this bill that the amendment does not go at all to addressing the fishing industry's very fundamental concerns about this whole bill. This bill is another example of this government's complete disregard for the industries that actually create jobs and wealth in this country. Its feel-good policy has led it to completely disregard the effects of this bill on the creation of wealth.

PARA.TAB: The industry, in its submissions, made it quite clear that it had absolutely no consultation whatsoever over this bill. It is terribly worried about the complexity. It makes the point that the bill fails to validate its fishing licences at all. It is no good allowing a state to confirm that fishing rights prevail if those fishing rights are not indeed valid. There is absolutely no guarantee of that. There is no guarantee that the states will even act to confirm, so the industry is left with nothing.

There is the problem, as the industry identified, that fishing permits do not extinguish native title as a co-existence. There is no satisfaction in relation to the potential for compensation of holders of fishing licences. There are huge problems for the industry in this bill, and merely to change the words `fishing access' to `statutory fishing' goes no way to solving the problems that the industry quite clearly identified when it put its submissions to the standing committee.

I just ask the minister in relation to the amendment: do the words `fishing access' not contemplate the coverage of statutory fishing? How does the change of those words actually improve the position for the industry at all? We have problems of what are statutory fishing rights. Are they only commercial? Are they recreational? How does the description `statutory fishing' really differ from the expression `fishing access'?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, fishing access rights would include public and private rights of a non-statutory character basically other than commercial type rights that are specifically provided for in a commercial regime. The utility of this provision from the industry viewpoint is, as I said, that it confirms that statutory fishing rights do prevail over any other fishing rights—anything at all, including native title rights—but it is subject to the legislation. So the clause 196A provision we have just been talking about would be a partial exemption to that, but the only one.

PARA.TAB: However, that is not the only provision that we put in here in response to worries by the fishing industry about the terms of the original bill. The onshore rights provisions of which there is a whole gaggle of amendments—namely, our amendments to clauses 16, 22, 220, 225 and 238; all of them address this question of the definition of onshore waters—was our response to one of the most vigorously expressed concerns of the Australian fishing industry.

I remind those opposite again, although it is obviously embarrassing for me to do so, that the failure of those opposite to come across and support us in our amendment No. 74, which was designed to address the question of the definition of fishing rights in the intertidal zone area, is something that does impact adversely on the abalone, pearl and barramundi industries and is a source of real concern to those industries. So we did our best to clarify the status of onshore rights. We have done that.

We did our best to clarify the status, in particular, of intertidal waters. We have not been able to do that because those opposite did not support our amendment. We are going to try now to add this extra provision that is sought by the industry, and legitimately so, to clarify the priority of statutory rights in this particular industry. It is up to those opposite now as to whether they support us in doing that, but do not indicate that we have been less than sensitive to the concerns of the fishing industry. We have been very sensitive indeed and have tried to respond accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to clause 192, the land fund clause. The minister correctly said to Senator Troeth that it was one of the more important clauses in the bill. I do not want to canvass the issues that Senator Troeth raised. Could the minister indicate to the committee what sorts of sums the government has contemplated being paid to the fund each year? That is my first question.

PARA.TAB: My second question is: will the moneys be given in terms of grants or in terms of loans? My third question is: is it possible those grants could be made to individuals? My final question is: is it contemplated that moneys from the fund could be used to purchase urban property; in other words, defining land in perhaps a broader sense?

TALK.START.PARA: —These are essentially all questions that remain to be resolved. As to the quantum issue, the Prime Minister has said that the amount to be devoted to the fund will be `significant'. But it is to be decided in a budgetary context and we simply have not turned our mind to what is possible or desirable in this respect at this stage. We obviously will, but there is a consultative process to go through as well as our own internal budgetary processes.

PARA.TAB: As to whether the fund would operate by way of grants or loans or both, and what kinds of recipients there might be for the fund money, is, again, I have to say, subject to determination. I think it is unlikely that individuals would be beneficiaries; it is more likely to be Aboriginal corporations or communal groups or bodies of that kind. But, again, I do not want to pre-empt the government's consideration of that. That is what we will be looking at. What was the other question about?

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether it can be used to purchase urban property.

—Perhaps. That is quite possible. It is because the essential concept of the land fund is not just in the context of native title and responding further to the needs or requests of native titleholders for property purchases. Part of the object of the whole land fund notion is to get some equity into the equation as between those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who can still credibly claim native title and regain access to the land in that way and those Aboriginal people who have been dispossessed and lost all of the kind of contact with the land that could begin to justify that title status.

PARA.TAB: The social justice package is also designed to deal with that part of the problem but we hope that the land fund will also have some impact in redressing that sense of inequality between different categories of Aboriginal people. These are sensitive and delicate issues. They have to be addressed in consultation with Aboriginal people and organisations. There will, no doubt, be a lot of consultation on all these issues in the months ahead before this issue is bedded down, as we hope it will be in next year's budgetary context.

TALK.START.PARA: —What size fund do you envisage?
—It will be significant, as the Prime Minister said, but it is to be resolved in the budgetary context as to what that means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 175 deals explicitly with legal aid. I draw the minister's attention to clause 194, as amended, which would enable either the Commonwealth minister or ATSIC to provide financial assistance. What type of financial assistance is intended there? Why is it not spelt out? I draw the minister's attention to the explanatory memorandum which states that the purpose of this provision is to enable the ATSIC body:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to represent or help Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders, if it is reasonable to do so.

That implies that this is really just an extended form of legal aid. Is it limited to that or is it really meant to be a very substantial means of providing financial assistance for a whole range of other purposes; and if so, what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is intended to be financial assistance for the purposes of the effective implementation of this act, not for extraneous or other pro-Aboriginal purposes. It is designed to be a vehicle to enabling organisations like the land councils—not ATSIC because ATSIC is the delivering vehicle rather than the recipient—and other representative organisations.
—For administrative purposes?
—To assist in the preparation of claims, the conduct of litigation and the determination process which will be associated with that.
—Why isn't that legal aid under 175?

—Clause 175 is designed primarily, as I understand it, to assist non-Aboriginal people—pastoralists and others—who may have interests that are potentially put at risk in some way or that need to be represented. Again, what kind of quantum will be available for doing this and what the ground rules are has yet to be fully resolved. That is being developed at the moment. I said in answer to questions here in question time some weeks ago that the government accepted the principle of at least some degree of even-handedness in this respect. Clause 175 is the primary vehicle for delivering that to non-Aboriginal people.
—Certainly not on the face of it.
—No, maybe not, but the other provision we are talking about for Aboriginal organisations—clause 194—is the primary vehicle for delivering that form of assistance to Aboriginal people.

—Why isn't that expressed to be legal aid in clause 194 in the same way that clause 175 is expressed to be assistance `in relation to the inquiry or proceedings'? In other words, that is clearly a legal aid provision. Why isn't 194 in roughly the same language? It seems to be open-ended on its face.
—There is a reference in clause 194 to the functions to be performed under subsection 193(4) which states:

PARA.TAB: (4)A representative of Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander body may:
(a)facilitate the researching, preparation or making of claims, by individuals or groups from among Aboriginal peoples . . .
(b) assist in the resolution of disagreements among such individuals or groups about the making of such claims . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It is an obvious assistance provision; it is finite; it is spelt out. It is not in the form of legal aid as such, because the function here does not necessarily involve the conduct of litigation, defence of criminal prosecutions or things of that kind. It is a little broader in scope. I think that would be self-evident if, once again, Senator Alston read the actual text of the clauses as I, of course, have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired for consideration of these clauses. The question is that government amendments Nos 41, 42, 43, 45, 46 and 68, together with Green amendments Nos 33B and 34A, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that clauses 192 to 206, plus postponed clause 11, as amended, be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I was distracted for a moment and I wondered whether we had voted on government amendment No 45?
—In fact, we have.
—I vote `no' to that. Did you do it in a block?
—Yes, I did.
—We did do it in a block, but did you want to vote on it separately?
—I did want a separate vote on that, please.

—I accept that because, right from the outset, we have said that any senator who wants a separate vote on anything is entitled to get it. As much as I dislike the consequences of that in this instance and as much as it puts more pressure on people on the other side, they now have another minute or two to rethink their position on this fishing industry clause. Maybe this is the big opportunity to restore some credibility. Maybe they would welcome the opportunity of it being put separately.

—Can we be quite clear on this, Mr Chairman. Is this the Greens again claiming to have missed the bus and wanting to make their position clear—in which case they could simply have it recorded that they voted `no'; or is this yet another shameless attempt at grandstanding along the lines—
—Option one.

—Yes, I agree—along the lines of the very tawdry and transparent public relations and marketing exercise that we have had to endure over the last fortnight, when everyone knew from day one what the Greens intended to do? I must say that we called it right from the beginning, and we are reinforced more than ever in our view. If this is a grandstanding exercise, let us be told just that. Otherwise, let Senator Chamarette have it recorded that she wishes to vote `no' and we can get on with the business.

—Order! The sentiment of opinion was that, in the event that any senator wanted one amendment drafted out, we would so do. The only thing I can say to Senator Chamarette is that I called them all and she did not call. There is a provision under standing orders which allows her to record her vote and I am happy for that to be so done. There was only one call and so under standing orders, of course, she cannot call a division.

—The problem I have is that my understanding is that our vote would have meant that the government did not gain its amendment No. 45, and I believe that issue deserves clarification. I made it quite clear in initial statements during the debate that we would not be supporting it. I did it right at the beginning. While it was clearly my error that when you called them in a block I did not differentiate, when you were previously in the chair, you had assuaged my anxiety that I would slip up like that because you actually called those on which agreement had been signified in a different group from those that would not have the consent and the passage of the chamber. While I understand the problem, I think there is a difference between recording a dissenting vote and failing to call a division where a motion would have been lost.
—Senator Chamarette, I will call it for the noes and, therefore, the resolution is resolved in the negative in respect of amendment No. 45.
—May I clarify that the Australian Democrats are supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That clauses 192 to 206, as amended, and clause 11 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have moved essentially three batches of amendments. The first batch contains amendments Nos 38 and 39, together with amendment No. 46, which is consequential on amendment Nos 38 and 39 being passed. These amendments deal with commercial leases, particularly in the area of tourist developments. They seek to ensure that native title is extinguished only on that portion of the lease on which there is a substantial development. It does not extend over a whole area, which might well be a large hinterland of natural forest that should not be part of a commercial lease.

PARA.TAB: Our next amendment is amendment No. 35, which seeks to omit clause 213(9). It simply has the effect of narrowing the definition of `past act'. Amendment No. 37 seeks to invalidate any leases that are granted to corporations in the Northern Territory which, as history has shown, have been set up precisely for that purpose but which are, in effect, sham corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just take all the national parks off everyone—right?

—Just before the dinner suspension I moved the Australian Democrats' amendments to these clauses. I will briefly state them by number only before I expand on amendment No. 53. I moved Democrat amendments Nos 35, 37, 38 and 39, the consequential amendment No. 46, and amendment No. 53.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 53 amends clause 220 and deals with the renewals, regrants or extensions of certain leases. This amendment was made necessary because government amendment No. 14, relating to clause 24, was not agreed to. According to our legal opinion, when a valid lease was nearing the end of its term and native title had been extinguished by that valid lease that native title could be revived between the time of the old lease coming to a conclusion and the new grant being made.

The removal of the provisions of the government's amendment, according to our legal advice, made it impossible legally to grant the new lease. It was therefore thought imperative to rectify this situation. Democrat amendment No. 53 has been arrived at to cure that possible danger. The amendment includes in the `permissible future act' the renewals, re-grants and extensions of commercial, agricultural, pastoral or residential leases. This is provided the granting of the lease does not create a proprietary interest where previously the interest had been a non-proprietary one and provided that it does not create a larger proprietary interest than was previously created by the lease.

In addition, the amendment ensures that where the lease contains a reservation or condition for the benefit of Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders, the renewed, re-granted or extended lease contains the same reservation or condition. This would probably have been the case anyway but the inclusion of that clause, which I am glad to say I took a personal interest in, makes sure of that. I believe that this amendment is important. I commend it to the coalition parties and in particular to those National Party senators who crossed the floor last time. This amendment satisfies a number of interests including those of the Aboriginal people and native titleholders concerned, as well as those of the pastoral industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the minister to clause 208(3), which deals with the definition of native title and statutory rights and interests. In a previous discussion involving clause 11 and the question of common law native title being treated as laws of the Commonwealth, Senator Alston raised the issue of the Western Australian conversion of native title rights into statutory rights as an example of the application of 208(3). He was suggesting that judicial decisions in relation to actions involving statutory rights in Western Australia could then become part of native title common law. The minister dismissed the suggestion that those Western Australian statutory rights could possibly be considered native title within the definition as set out in 208(3). The Parliamentary Library has advised officially all parliamentarians in relation to this section as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of `native title' in proposed section 208 provides that, if native title rights and interests have been compulsorily converted into, or replaced by, statutory rights and interests, then those statutory rights and interests are also covered by the expression `native title'. This means, for example, that even though the Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993 has extinguished native title and replaced it with statutory rights of traditional usage, then these rights of traditional usage will be given the same protection as native title under the Native Title Bill. Reference to `native title' in the following discussion should therefore be taken to include any statutory rights to which native title has been compulsory converted.

So the legal department of the Parliamentary Library certainly took the same view that we did; that is, clause 208(3) does cover the native title statutory rights and interests created in Western Australia with all the implications that follow from that interpretation. There is clearly a great deal of confusion about what that means. I wonder whether the minister could enlighten us on exactly why there will not be confusion when this bill becomes law. Why is the Parliamentary Library so wrong? Why are we wrong? Is there something that we have not seen in relation to this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entirely sure what the Parliamentary Library said in relation to clause 208(3) as I was receiving some advice when Senator Minchin referred to that. Basically, clause 208(3) clearly deals with the situation that has arisen in Western Australia where there has been a purported overturning of the common law native rights that existed in order to create a new statutory regime with less rights in practice attached to the statutory native title rights under the Western Australian legislation than would have been available to common law native rights holders. In particular, there are all sorts of provisions for the effective diminution or, ultimately, termination of those rights by ministerial discretion and so on. There is none of the panoply of protections, procedures and institutional opportunities available for common law native titleholders under the Commonwealth legislation.

PARA.TAB: We all know that that is the effect of the Western Australian legislation. In effect, clause 208(3) gives a re-birth to those Western Australian native title rights—or any similar native title rights that have been overridden—and creates those rights in a statutory form with exactly the same status as common law native rights. So they have been recreated and re-born as a result of the effect of this statutory provision overriding the Western Australian provision as, again, the equivalent of full scale common law native title rights. All the opportunities, all the processes and all the rights associated with those common law rights are effectively secured as a result of this particular subclause.

For the sake of completion, I wish to add a supplementary remark to what I said earlier to Senator Minchin. This is, in a sense, a kind of belt and braces provision. Our working presumption is that the legislative effect of this particular bill when passed and enacted, noting its operative dates and so on, will be to overturn the Western Australian legislation and create a result that were as if that legislation had never been enacted—in other words, as if the common law native title rights in WA had never been extinguished by statute; quite apart from what happens to them thereafter. If we are wrong about that—and if, for whatever reason, the courts hold that our law is incapable of having the retrospective effect of denying the initial validity of the Western Australian legislation—then, as I said before, the effect of clause 208(3) will be to recreate in essence those Western Australian former common law rights which, on that hypothesis, would have been regarded as being extinguished by the Western Australian statute and secure their recreation as a kind of native title equivalent right given that status by virtue of the Commonwealth legislation.

This is very complicated jurisprudential stuff; I am very conscious of that. As I understand it, that is the way these clauses are intended to operate—maybe with some further qualification which I had better find out about. I am reminded that these provisions are of general application and applicable to all state legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have Western Australia on the brain, and you have just proved it.

—There is a kind of reason for that. It is the path Senator Crane has chosen to go down, not because he is uninterested in these issues, dishonest or a thoroughly unattractive human being. It is simply that Western Australia is where it all happened first and where lousy, rotten legislation was passed which was aimed at securing all these lousy, rotten results. Therefore we had to do something about it. Should any other state be minded to go down that lousy, rotten path; exactly the same legislative provisions will apply to them.

—To be fair to the minister, I raised the issue in the context of Western Australia. It seems that he is saying that statutory rights will be treated as native title for the purpose of this bill. Senator Alston raised the issue of these statutory rights. If they are to be treated as native title, how do we logically separate that from common law native title? To the extent that a court deals with statutory rights in Western Australia, the law thus created is not part of common law native title.

—There is a nice little symmetry about this. Just as we, for the purposes of clause 11, pick up the common law and give it statutory force, in essence in clause 208(3) we are picking up the Western Australian statute and giving it the force of common law. What it really means, as Senator Minchin said, is that we are treating these particular native title rights as if they were common law rights.

PARA.TAB: In every place in this legislation where we see a reference to native title rights, we should treat them as subsumed within that description, whatever their extent in Western Australia, and in effect ignore their source. We should ignore the fact that they were common law, became Western Australian statute and now have been picked up as Commonwealth statute by virtue of the overriding provisions of this legislation.

—I am just jumping in to make sure that Senator Panizza does not get too excited about mineral rights.

—I am not talking about mineral rights. Senator Evans said that permission had to be sought to use the air space. It is unlimited going upwards and limited to the centre of the earth going downwards, and it does not include mineral rights. As far as airspace is concerned, permission from native titleholders is needed to do magnetometer work, which is simply measuring the field strength, so one is not touching the earth; and permission is needed to do satellite work, which is only imagery. Is it correct that Senator Evans said yesterday that permission is needed?
—No.
—I thought he did say that permission is needed to do magnetometer work.

—I did not say that. I said anything that involved physical interference on the land, such as laying seismic lines and that sort of thing. I said, equally, if one is flying over it, it would be difficult to see that that would be regarded as involving any impact at all, except in the most—
—But why then does the definition of `land' on page 113 include air-space? Why is it in the definition if there is some qualification on airspace?

—Just as land includes water, under the bill, in some contexts, not all, so potentially it includes air-space. What follows from that in terms of whether this is regarded as an interference in native title depends entirely on the extent to which native title is determined to include some air space component. Our reference to up to the heavens and down to the centre of the earth was a reference to prevailing common law rules about ownership. It is not to be assumed that common law rules in other contexts will be applicable to findings about native title; that has got to be worked out. I am not sure of the context in which it would ever become relevant to sort it out and whether the tribunals would be terribly minded to get stuck into the details of undertaking this particular conundrum. But it is not to be assumed, simply because such and such is the rule as a matter of common law, that that rule will be applicable to native title.

PARA.TAB: I do not think we should make any assumptions that there is any air-space component to native title. Even if we did make that assumption, it is a pretty large assumption that flying an exploration with a magnetometer across air space above a native title claim area would constitute an impermissible future act, or any other kind of future act, other than perhaps an extremely low impact future act, within the meaning of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming through this legislation is almost a hatred, or a vindictiveness, in relation to Western Australia. Senator Evans's response to Mabo might well be appropriate for what has happened on the eastern seaboard. I am not saying that what has happened in Western Australia is perfect, and I do not want to convey that impression.

PARA.TAB: What has happened in Western Australia is far superior to what has happened in the other states; although South Australia and the Northern Territory have gone some way towards the Western Australian situation. Maybe I am out of order in not strictly debating this legislation, but I think it important that some facts be placed on the public record. In the state of Western Australia there has been a reservation for indigenous people for some 100 years. The reservation has been provided for in legislation since 1934, and prior to that it was a condition of lease. As imperfect as that may have been, it is one hell of a lot more than has happened in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, and in particular Tasmania. It amazes me that people stand up in this place and pontificate on how moral and wonderful they are.

Also, it is important to place on the public record that in the mid-1980s—and I am very proud to have been associated with this initiative—Western Australia put in place the process of the purchasing of stations. Obviously last night the minister was not aware of this and nor were his advisers. In responding to me the minister said that those stations were very limited when, in fact, they cover approximately 10 per cent of our pastoral leases and form an ongoing program. I have to say, from first-hand knowledge and experience, that the way in which those stations are now being run is very little different from the way other stations are being run. Some stations are very good, some are of a middling standard and some are not so good. But in my view the whole process in Western Australia has worked extremely well. Also, in Western Australia excision legislation was put in place. As imperfect as it might be, once again it is one hell of a lot better than the situation on the eastern seaboard.

As a Western Australian I feel I should put these points on the public record. We can look at a whole range of matters. The Greens want the eastern states response to Mabo, plus whatever they can pick out of the eyes of the legislation that has been put in place. I will not stand here and say that the Western Australian government has it totally right. But what I do say is that, in my view, the response of the Western Australian government in relation to the things I have spoken about is much more appropriate than the response we are getting in relation to this legislation.

I know, and indeed have known for a long time, many elders in Western Australia. I have been consistently told by them that they prefer the Western Australian response to the federal government's response. Yet we see that so much of the federal government's response—and, unfortunately, this has come through consistently in this debate—is targeted at Western Australia.

In that respect, I sincerely believe that the federal government has taken its eye off the ball, which I think is very unfortunate. For the whole of my primary school life, I attended school with more Aborigines than Europeans. A lot of those people are still very good friends of mine; I see them from time to time, although perhaps not as often as I would like.

Many of those friends are very fine individuals who have accepted their responsibilities in their particular communities, as I would have expected of them. I want it on the public record that I was very sad at the way this debate over the last three or four days has had to be cut short. The Greens and the Democrats can throw all the barbs they like at us for not moving any amendments to the legislation. Our job in opposition is to scrutinise legislation. We have absolutely, totally and clearly demonstrated that there are so many difficulties and holes in this legislation that we will be back here within six months, probably three months, with a whole raft of additional amendments. I am not sure how many amendments have now been made to the legislation but it must be getting close to 300. I now have in front of me three amendments: 14A, 14B and 14C—I am not sure whether we will get a 14D.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are safe.

—Thank the Lord for that. I have spoken with the Aboriginal elders in Western Australia. We know that the legislation will be passed tonight and, from the bottom of my heart, I hope it works. Unfortunately, I do not believe that it will—I believe that we will be back here in a few months with a raft of additional amendments.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day it is important for all Australians, whether or not indigenous Australians get native title rights, that there be equity and economic development in which those people can share with those of us who arrived some time later. On my father's side, they came out in 1926 and, on my mother's side, they came out in 1829 or 1831—two years after settlement in Western Australia. So we go back a long way.

I hope the bill works. Unfortunately, the government has lost sight of the fact that, for a long time, different circumstances have applied in Western Australia. As inadequate as our response over the years might have been, it has been one hell of a lot better than what has occurred on the eastern seaboard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond immediately to Senator Crane to say a couple of things for the record about this. I do not doubt for a moment Senator Crane's sincerity on this particular issue. He has made a contribution to this debate, which has on occasion been robust and on occasion emotional but, by and large, it has been constructive. It has been a contribution that has been based on concern about the way in which the legislation would operate rather than just mindless opposition to it. I acknowledge that and I respect that.

PARA.TAB: However, the government's response, equally, should not be construed as mindless opposition to anything that comes out of the west or ignorance about or indifference to the views that prevail in the west. On the contrary, we have sought throughout the course of this saga to discuss, to consult, to negotiate, and we have been disappointed by the unwillingness of that process to bear fruit.

If what we are doing in this legislation is in some respects directed at state legislation like that passed in Western Australia, or which might conceivably at some stage in the future be passed elsewhere, it is really for a very good set of reasons which were very well captured in what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in his second reading speech introducing this bill and which I picked up and applied in the language of my response to the second reading debate.

What we are concerned about with the Western Australian legislation—or any other legislation that might be like it in the future—are really three things: first, the compulsory wholesale extinguishment of native title as embodied in the common law and with it the inherent right, not the granted right, of Aboriginals and Torres Straight Islanders who meet the criteria of the common law.

The second concern is the mandatory replacement of this by a form of statutory title. The fact that it is replaced with something is obviously better than nothing. But the replacement of it by statutory title which is only conferred at the pleasure of government and which can, under the structure of that legislation, be extinguished in particular cases virtually at a minister's whim is of concern. None of the kinds of procedures are provided that we are providing for in this legislation that we think are inherent in the common law right if properly protected.

Thirdly, in the Western Australian legislation there is a detailed land management regime which provides only, as we see it, as we characterise it and as we judge it, the flimsiest of protections for Aboriginal people—protections which are far less than other land-holders enjoy in the way in which they can be overridden by miscellaneous grants or other competing interests. That is the problem with the Western Australian legislation.

What should be regarded as a recognition as of right has turned into, by a stroke of the legislative pen, an act of parliamentary, governmental, charity. Aboriginal rights are what the parliament, the government, is prepared to concede they are at any given point of time. They are not something inherent, not something which flow out of the dignity, the culture, the background or the history of Aboriginal people which has been ignored, overlooked, suppressed or destroyed for so long. They are something granted in a rather grudging and limited way by a parliament that is basically so concerned about other competing interests that it is not prepared to take the risks of giving those rights to their fullest possible extent.

That is what we are concerned about with the Western Australian legislation. It is not because it comes out of the west, not because we do not understand that Western Australia is where most of the real action on the ground is and not because we are obsessed with eastern states' models which have no real application most of the time in most contexts to the real world situation that applies there. We do understand that. But what we have difficulty in understanding—what we certainly have difficulty in accepting—is that there is any legitimacy about that kind of statutory process which cuts that degree of a swathe through the Aboriginal rights which, for the first time in over 200 years, have actually been recognised.

That is what we are about in this legislation. That is why we want to get this right. I think we have got it right. I think the demonstration over the last 36 hours now of committee debate here has got this bill looking a lot better in terms of its integrity, its cohesion and its specific language clause by clause than opposition senators probably thought it was. Maybe it is even better than I thought it was when I got up to start defending it because I think it stands up pretty well to detailed scrutiny.

Legislation of this complexity, of this length, prepared in this way, in this kind of process, is bound to show up some flaws. Some of those flaws have been identified. We sought to correct them, but we could not because of the politics of this place at this time. We will need to go back to them at an early stage to have another look at them.
