Other flaws are bound to show up in the course of the monitoring and the implementation of this legislation. That is the way it works out over time. That is inherent in the nature of this.

I want us all in the future to approach this legislation in a much more constructive spirit—as a given, as a here and now reality in Australian legislative life. Let us not get back to the kind of attitude that for so long we have had in relation to Aboriginal land rights legislation.

I got into the Aboriginal land rights game back in 1973 when I was working as an adviser—a fresh-faced young lawyer-academic—to Gordon Bryant with the Kulaluk people in the Northern Territory, in Darwin, starting the Aboriginal legal services. That is when I first became aware of this as a burning issue for Aboriginal people. I have been concerned with it on and off in a personal and ministerial career ever since.

I am one of those people who had the most acute sense of disappointment, of despair almost, at our failure to be able to implement a national land rights policy back in 1984-85. It was a worthy aspiration, but it failed. I felt an enormous sense of disappointment, almost betrayal of the Aboriginal people, that we failed to get it right then to capture the majority of the constituency to get a legislative package through.

The High Court, almost out of a clear, blue sky, has done the job for us in Mabo. It has broken through that barrier of indifference, those barriers imposed by a multitude of other competing interests drowning out the still small voice of the Aboriginal people, what is left of them. Mabo has given us a chance, an historic opportunity, to get it right. Maybe this legislation is not perfect but it gets it more right than any previous attempt. That is why we have fought this issue so passionately, so hard, for so long, not just because it is another legislative exercise, not just because it is another political battle, but because it has real historic significance. That is why we fought the Western Australian model because we think it diminishes, it does not dignify, the rights that we are trying to protect.

What we think we have achieved with this piece of legislation is quite possibly the most important piece of social justice this country has ever seen. What we think we have achieved in this legislation is some degree of decency and respect embodied in the legislation for Aboriginal people. That is why we are fighting this issue the way we are. It is not for some mean-spirited, throwaway, transient political reason; it is because we think the cause is just and worth fighting in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone on the opposition's side would doubt the sincerity of the minister's views or indeed those of many of the ministers in the Keating cabinet who feel so passionately about implementing national land rights as the government is seeking to achieve through this legislation. Equally, I think the minister would recognise, whether or not he likes it, that people on our side of the chamber, even though we respect the deeply held views of the minister and some of his colleagues, think that the way the government has gone about it is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Many of us think that we can look after Aboriginal rights; we can make sure that they are protected; and we can ensure that the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people can be delivered in a very different way. The consensus that broke down during the 1980s, particularly because of the political expediency of the then Premier Brian Burke—which I am sure I do not need to remind the minister about—reflected the strong community opinion that a national land rights scheme was not the right way to approach the problem.

I guess all of the constitutional issues that are involved in trying to develop a national land rights scheme, as this bill does, will sooner or later be fought out in the courts. Again, those legal battles will do very little for the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people. There is no doubt that this legislation will be subject to High Court action. The Richard Court WA legislation is already subject to action. Those actions are only a product of governments going well beyond their constitutional powers, creating far too much power in Canberra, going through an undemocratic process, creating what we describe on this side of the chamber as a divisive piece of legislation which is separatist in our view.

I am sure that we have heard many arguments as to why it is not separatist, but I think it is a great shame that where a government goes well beyond its constitutional powers—or at least tries to stretch the use of those constitutional powers to the absolute limit—in the end, some of the things that we seek to achieve by abusing those powers will actually work against what we are trying to achieve for the Aboriginal people and for the people of Australia as a whole.

Having said that, I want to move back to the point that Senator Panizza was referring to earlier in relation to the definition of land and particularly airspace. I wanted to ask the minister whether or not he was aware that approximately two years ago in Western Australia the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable Judith Watson, by ministerial decree banned air flights over some Aboriginal sacred sites and reserves because they were doing magnetometer work.

Whether he was or was not aware of that, I would like the minister to assure the committee in unequivocal terms that in no circumstances would the minister, the tribunal or anybody associated with this system be able to ban that sort of prospecting work from the air using magnetometers or any other form of exploration equipment and that people doing that sort of exploration work from the air would in no circumstances be required to create a permit. The precedent has certainly been set in Western Australia by the former Labor Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who did ban that exploration activity. That is why some of us from Western Australia have particular concerns about there needing to be any sort of application before the system to ensure that that sort of exploration can take place. I think it would be a very important guide for the future, if the minister can make that commitment here in the committee stage of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that it is by no means clear that the airspace above a land area would be regarded as being within the scope of native title. That is a matter for determination; it is not to be assumed. It is only if the airspace were to be regarded at the threshold as part of native title that the question would even begin to arise whether intrusion on the airspace was a prima facie intrusion on native title.

PARA.TAB: The second question to bear in mind is the definition of `future permissible acts' and the freehold test that is associated with that. The essence of that freehold test is that what one can do in relation to freehold land one can do in relation to Aboriginal land. Since there are no inhibitions or restrictions as to what one can do basically about flying over freehold land, equally there would be no inhibitions or restrictions in terms of what one can do by way of flying over Aboriginal land.

I do not know what else I can say to give comfort in that respect. It seems to me that, even if one did regard it as impacting on Aboriginal land and affecting the native title, one then gets into the realm of the low impact definition as another possible way through this. I think that is of less likelihood in its applicability than just the threshold decision that these issues simply do not arise as a form of impact from which consequences flow.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has now moved from a position a couple of days where that was considered totally allowable and it did not need to apply to it. Tonight he has said that it could under certain circumstances be regarded as a low impact future act. I have informed the minister—he may not have known of it before—about the stupid action by the state minister, Judith Watson, to do so. It was quickly regarded as such and I think she quickly changed her mind. The people in Western Australia who obviously went to the minister and said, `We want these flights banned because we don't want magnetometers over our land' are clearly still in Western Australia. The minister who will be making these decisions in a few months' time will be asked to confront these dilemmas; so will the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: The government can have the greatest intention in the world, but the minister told the committee two days ago that aerial exploration would not need any sort of permit. Another example was given to me by Robert Champion de Crespigny, who told me a couple of years ago that there was a ban on the use of aerial exploration over some land rights areas in the Northern Territory. Aeroplanes were actually banned from doing aerial surveying and aerial exploration in the Northern Territory. So we have two examples where this is already occurring.

The minister has simply been unable to assure the Senate that in future he would not require a permit to do aerial exploration. There is no doubt in anyone's mind who has seen aerial exploration taking place that it is not a low impact action; it is a no impact action. If the minister is now saying that it might be a low impact future action, then the people in both the exploration industry and the mining industry and the people who rely on those industries for their jobs have even more reason to be concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference to a low impact future act was just an afterthought. I hung my hat on clause 212, and I continue to do so. Clause 212 states:

SPEECH.PARA: An act "affects" native title if it is wholly or partly inconsistent with the continued existence, enjoyment or exercise of the native title rights and interests.
I am trying to contemplate a situation where it might conceivably, in some way, be regarded as affecting native title interests, but I am having the greatest difficulty in doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about a photograph of a sacred site—one that would not be allowed to be published under some action before the Federal Court?

—I do not think that there are too many situations where sacred sites themselves—the existence of the physical landscape feature, as distinct from churingas, sacred objects, or something of that kind—are inhibited from scrutiny.
—What about the ones that women are not allowed to see, if you had a woman pilot? Are you going to ban women pilots too?
—I suppose it is conceivable.
—Women are to have fewer rights, are they? You can't have female pilots, if female pilots aren't entitled to see the site.

—The trouble with Senator Bishop is that she is just not prepared to even begin to acknowledge that there are competing sensitivities to her own in these matters. The notion of her having any sensitivity about anything is a pretty extravagant kind of concession on my part, and I do not make it readily. At issue here are competing sensitivities, competing cultural traditions—not just any old traditions, but the traditions of the indigenous inhabitants of our continent whom we dispossessed 200 years ago and to whom we have special obligations.

PARA.TAB: If it comes to, in the sense of, intruding upon sensitivities that are very strongly held and there are some competing values and virtues in the way in which we go about doing things, there is at least a question to be addressed here—not something to be assumed in the kind of strident and rather ugly way in which Senator Bishop addresses every one of these issues about which she has anything to say. I do not think that this would be construed as a situation of impact or of effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm not interested in what you think. What is the fact? What is the government's intent?

—I am a little more modest than Senator Bishop. I do not know what the courts and tribunals will hold about all these matters because they are matters of great difficulty, great complexity and one cannot anticipate every conceivable variation on the situation that will be before the courts. What we can do at best, given the materials that we have to hand—and with the High Court decision and its guidance—is give some statutory signposts. We cannot map every last inch of the terrain. We are conscious of that fact. We are conscious of the fact that we are creating institutions and processes; we are not codifying every last aspect of the situation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop can bellow, scream and shout in her own particular strident way—and it will be a matter of profound indifference to me because she has brought no intelligent, thoughtful or sensitive appreciation to these issues. It is just the same boring, tedious old point scoring that we have been familiar with for so long. I do not know unequivocally the answer to the kind of question that she put because it depends on a number of variables. It depends on the way in which native title will be construed to exist for the particular site in question. It depends on the judgments that are made about airspace. It depends on the nature of the judgments that are made about impact. There are plenty of ways in which these competing interests can be sensitively balanced, and the ways of doing so are amply set out in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get back to the definition of land and airspace. I asked the minister: why include the airspace if it is intended not to have any effect?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of including it if we did not intend it to have any effect. Why did we include a reference to airspace if we did not intend it to have any effect? Because it is a matter for determination by the courts as to whether airspace will be construed as part of this.
—It says in the definition section that it is part of land.

—Just as this bit of land here is potentially, but wildly implausibly likely to be, claimable by Aboriginal people, so too airspace is potentially able to be claimed as part of a native title claim. But that does not lead to any assumptions at all about whether it is to be regarded as part of any particular Aboriginal claim. That is a matter for determination.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, in order to avoid further harassment from my advisers, who are becoming obsessed with the fact that we have not quite got the description accurate of what has been happening by way of these other amendments that are being moved, I mention that clause 231, amendment 46, was not being pursued. My understanding now is that it has been moved, and I make it clear for the record that our response to that is in the negative.

The other particular clause that is involved here is the Greens' amendment No. 37 to clause 208, which I indicated previously the government would oppose. I now wish to correct that for the record and for the sake of the clerks and everybody else who is trying to keep track of this. The Greens' amendment No. 37 relating to definitions of `mining', `native title' and so on is in fact acceptable. That is the situation in relation to amendment No. 37.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means exactly what? Is it something to do with what I am talking about?
—There is a man with a real grasp of what is going on. That is fair enough; this is getting a bit complicated. The Greens' amendment to clause 208(3), states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 208, page 95, subsection (3), after "subsection (1) are" insert ", or have been at any time in the past,".

The purpose of this amendment is to state quite clearly what we believe to be the High Court definition of native title so that this can be given the protection afforded by Commonwealth law. In the interests of transparency, we tried to make that as clear as possible, but I have been willing to listen to the arguments about all this. As drafted, this amendment would cover any type of interest, such as a lease or licence granted to Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders, whether or not they held native title. That is something we regard as appropriately built into this definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five minutes ago I was almost certain that the minister had said that native title does not include airspace. Now I do not quite know. I do not want him to get up and go through it again. The further we get with this questioning, the more it seems to me that it does include airspace. Bearing in mind that Senator Campbell said that former minister Judith Watson in Western Australia banned magnetometer work over native land, I have grave fears that it might include airspace. If it does include airspace, I can see other problems, because it will affect not only magnetometer work. After all, magnetometer work is only measuring the magnetic field strength of the ground, so one is not even sending radio waves, gravitational waves into that land. It is simply measuring something from afar, the same as satellite imagery.

PARA.TAB: The minister said that airspace as defined here goes to the heavens. I could make a comment there, but I will leave it at that. That means we go into airline travel—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—It does. The minister cannot get away from it. If native title includes airspace, issues affected include airline travel, magnetometer work, imagery work from the satellites, radio waves and microwaves—and all the other waves.
—Ha, ha!

—The minister can laugh as much as he likes. Those things go through that space. If there is any doubt on that, it will be tested in the High Court one day, sooner or later. I would have preferred the minister to completely rule it out and say that native title does not include airspace except whatever is reasonable, which would be what the CAA normally specifies. I would be very happy with that, but the minister brings all these other things in. The minister can have a go later at ruling it out but until it is ruled out, I am very frightened.

PARA.TAB: There is one more definition that I would like to speak about. Someone has to ask this question tonight, so it may as well be me. What is the definition of an Aboriginal? Senator Evans has carried on about our spending 37 hours and 45 minutes or whatever debating this bill. This is also one of the most costly bills to ever go through the parliament. I assume that this bill will be passed tonight with the support of the Greens—the big enemies of Western Australia. Unless it is struck down by the High Court, the act will be around for a mighty long time—perhaps 100 years or more.

So I ask the minister, quite earnestly, to give me a definition of `Aboriginal'. There are certain rights associated with being an Aboriginal. As Senator Bishop pointed out earlier, it is a case of South Africa revisited—although South Africa has now gone the other way. Certain rights and concessions are given based on Aboriginality. Fishing was one example. Aboriginals will have rights in that area, as well as other rights about which we have spoken for three or four days.

I want some idea of the definition. I could get two Aborigines to recognise me quite easily because I have known many over the years. I have a book called Yilgarn—Good Country for Hardy People which is about the area I am from. If people were to take a cursory look at this they would find out about our family. I know that I may be accepted as an Aborigine if two people recognise me as such. I could go to Kalgoorlie and two members from one family would accept me. That means that I may be entitled to the licences which will be issued under this legislation. That is an extreme case, but I put it before the minister.

As years go by, what will happen to the degree of Aboriginality? Ninety-nine years from now, whoever is standing here—I doubt whether he or she will be speaking this close to Christmas again—will have to answer this question. In the racing game, the cattle industry or anything like that, entries are out of the stud book after four generations. I want to know what will be the minimum claim for Aboriginality in 99 years time. I am a first generation Australian. My grandchildren and great grandchildren—if I ever have any—will still have a little bit of Italian in them in 99 years time. I would like the minister to give me an answer to this question. How will he define Aboriginality?

TALK.START.PARA: —This became an issue in the Tasmanian dams case where the legal concept that was given primacy was the notion of Aboriginal descent—that is, genealogy, relationships, establishable bloodlines, if you like; whatever that might mean, or whatever the quantum might be. That was not prescribed, and it has not been prescribed. The Commonwealth tends to use what is described as an `administrative definition' which, given the difficulty of establishing genealogy, descent and all those things for routine administrative purposes, operates on a combination of self-identification plus recognition and acceptance as an Aboriginal person. It is not a case of a couple of mates down the pub being prepared to say that they regard a person as such for the sake of whatever return might be in it, or something of that kind. It would have to be a better established test than that.

PARA.TAB: I repeat that the legal definition is one essentially based on descent. As a practical matter, it is a combination of those other two factors. It is a matter really for Aboriginal people themselves to sort out, for practical purposes, whom they regard as satisfying this Aboriginality criterion. Certainly, in the context of native title applications of the kind that are in issue in this case, the kind of background and association with the land over a long time, whether in the context of physical direct proximity sustained over time or some other form of less physical connection, would generally be such as to leave little doubt as to who satisfies this description. Commonwealth legislation generally refers to `a person of the Aboriginal race', again emphasising the element of descent, genealogy, parentage, grand parentage and so on.

These are very sensitive issues. In days gone by, considering the social contexts which prevailed at the time, it was unfortunately for a great many people a matter to be avoided. In latter days, mercifully and thankfully, Aboriginal descent and Aboriginality has become a matter of great pride. I hope that this legislation will be part of the process of reinforcing that pride. Maybe over time we can get better and clearer definitions. However, I suspect that it will be always a somewhat messy and imprecise business based on a combination, one way or another, of those three criteria: descent, self-identification and recognition and acceptance by others. I would like it to be clearer, because obviously it is a rather central, threshold issue which underlies many of these definitional issues, but it is not an issue about which it is possible to be more precise than I have been just now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to address the question of the definition of `land' and the inclusion of airspace. I want to deal very particularly with why I say that this legislation fails on two grounds. Firstly, it does not solve the uncertainty that flowed from the decision of the High Court in Mabo No. 2. Secondly, it is based upon providing different laws for Aboriginal Australians from those for the rest of Australians, which I believe is fundamentally wrong.

PARA.TAB: I believe in individuals; the government believes in collectives. It will always sacrifice the individual to the collective. I will never sacrifice the individual, including men, women, children and people of any ethnic background. Once they are Australians, they are entitled to the same respect, rights and hopes as each other.

When I look at this definition, I see airspace. We have already established earlier in the debate that Aboriginal people have a right that ordinary Australians do not have—that is, the right to exclude people from their land, be they there perforce of state legislation or regulation. It can be the bush fire brigade, the police or whomever one chooses. Therefore, if one can be excluded from coming on to land, one can also be excluded from airspace. That is something that no other Australian can do. Ask Gary Punch and his residents in Rockdale, who complain about overflights and the building of the third runway. However, the government is providing for a right to be given to one group of Australians which is different from the right available to other Australians.

The question that I raised about the rights of women is a very serious one and needs to be addressed. There seems to be some sort of curious underlying acceptance by those who come into the category of collectivists that something that is cultural and discriminates against women is okay. I am here to tell them that it is not okay. As a woman and an Australian citizen, I am entitled to every right in this country that a man is entitled to. That includes the ability to be a pilot of an aeroplane and to fly over sites and engage in photographic exploration.

There is an acceptance by some that there are certain things in Aboriginal culture which women may not see. I will not go into the reason for women being precluded; I am simply saying that, as a woman, I find it offensive. The net result is the possibility of a particular Aboriginal owner saying, `Women are not permitted to see this area or photograph it, but men are'. That automatically establishes the possibility of women—Australian women citizens—being discriminated against, simply because we have a piece of legislation setting up two sets of laws.

I have said it before and I will say it again: this is separate development; this is the beginnings of apartheid. That is something that I find un-Australian. I want Aboriginal people to enjoy their rights and entitlements to education and health—to all the things Australians regard as part and parcel of their expectations because the law and the rule of law guarantees them. There are plenty of examples of where it has not been possible for all Australians to take advantage of those things but that is not remedied by introducing laws which divide Australians into two categories—those subject to this piece of legislation and the rest.

In a very funny way the government is making Aborigines second class citizens. There is so much in this bill that is paternalistic. Again and again, as specific questions have been asked of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) he has given his opinions. They have been very interesting to listen to but they are not worth a pinch of salt. We have heard either the minister's opinion or that of his advisers. The advisers have worked hard; they have given the minister much advice. But at the end of the day, it is the intention of the government and the ability of the written word to be interpreted by courts and/or tribunals that will finally determine the meaning of this piece of paper.

I put to the minister that he is wrong when he says, as I heard him say earlier, that this legislation is a good piece of legislation because it meets the intent of the government. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is wrong in saying that he has solved these problems and has introduced a new era. We have opposed this legislation because it is fundamentally flawed. It is bad law. It is fundamentally flawed because it establishes two sets of laws—a them-and-us situation. By my definition, that is divisive. The minister and I differ fundamentally. I believe in the individual—that every single individual Australian has a right to be considered. The minister considers collectives, and if a few people fall by the wayside that is tough luck.

I notice from the amendment—I presume it is still current—that the minister takes away from that part of the definition that says `but does not include the bed or subsoil underwaters'. Can the minister tell me why he has amended that particular definition in that way?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hold everyone else up. Because of the time limit imposed, I have asked the last question that I am going to ask in this debate. At this stage, because I am not allowed to talk at the third reading stage, I would simply like to put on record my appreciation of the support our colleagues in the eastern states have given Western Australia. We have said all along that the Mabo decision had more to do with Western Australia than any other state. That is why we went in so hard; that is why Richard Court acted in the way that he did.

PARA.TAB: We had quite heated debates on this matter in our party room, as those opposite no doubt had in their caucus meetings. Fortunately, our colleagues in the eastern states agreed with us on the right way to go and they have remained rock solid. I appreciate that, and I put my appreciation on the record. I was earlier invited by Senator Evans to cross the floor, but solidarity means just that. I could have done something but I would have regretted it, sooner rather than later. Those are all the remarks I want to place on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note what Senator Panizza has said. If that is his last contribution to the debate, I would like to thank him for the spirit in which he has contributed to the debate over most of this period. It has been a bit better humoured and a little more constructive than that of some of his colleagues, not least the one who immediately preceded him.

PARA.TAB: What I want to say about Senator Bishop's contribution is this: so often she erects a great edifice of propositions on a totally muddled foundation. In this instance, her opening line was that Aboriginal native titleholders are capable of excluding people from their land in a way that is not possible for ordinary Australian proprietary interests or freeholders. She says that if this is so, we can extend it to airspace; and if we can extend it to airspace then women pilots flying over cultural sites are going to be discriminated against on the grounds of sex—and is that not terrible and the beginning of apartheid?

So this great muddle-headed, rickety edifice goes higher and higher into the sky but the foundations are absolutely shonky, as with just about every contribution Senator Bishop makes to the public debate. How on earth she has attracted any kind of reputation among people with an IQ of about 93 1/2 continues to amaze me because of the way in which she contributes to the public debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order in the gallery!
—Fair enough too.
—They're just laughing at his jokes.

—He is not the gallery; he is one of ours. To say that Aboriginal people with native title rights are capable of excluding others from the land is to wave a great big broad brush—which is simply not part of what native title rights are all about. There are some kinds of native title rights, just as there are some kinds of ordinary proprietary interests, which are perfectly capable of producing an exclusive occupancy regime; which would lead to that result.

PARA.TAB: But the basic characteristic of native title rights, in terms of what one can do by way of excluding governmental and other acts over the land in question, is that of equivalence with the rights of ordinary freeholders. Over and over again in the legislation this concept of the freehold test is employed, not in order to produce an identity of native title rights with freehold rights—because there is not always the identity in terms of exclusive occupancy or anything else—but in terms of finding a common touchstone for determining whether there can be various forms of interference.

The freehold test which applies in a number of different contexts is that if one can do something in relation to ordinary freeholders, then one can do it in relation to native titleholders. They do not enjoy any special immunity from the overwhelming majority of acts, practices and legal regimes that are applicable to ordinary freeholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already established that in the Federal Court they will have different rights.

—A couple of special additional protections go to native titleholders—and let us understand what they are. There is a right to negotiate; which is not enjoyed by non-Aboriginal titleholders when it comes to the negotiation of mining interests over Aboriginal land in this sense. There is a right to negotiate created when there is a compulsory acquisition of native title land for third party purposes. That is not a right of negotiation which is available to ordinary land-holders in a freehold or roughly equivalent situation. There is a right to compensation on just terms for the extinguishment of native title; which is not applicable anywhere else in the legal system.

PARA.TAB: When we take out those three special protections of native title, it is very difficult to find any basic distinction between the native title right that is conferred and equivalent rights that may be applicable right now under the existing law of property. It is important that that be understood. Those special rights are there for a particular purpose and they are counted as special measures within the meaning of the Racial Discrimination Act and the international convention—and they have been identified clearly as such. They are exercises in positive discrimination with the rationale for that behind them.

In reference to another storey of the rickety edifice, I would point out that the notion that if we can exclude from land we can exclude from airspace again is based on a false premise. We cannot exclude from land any more than ordinary Australian titleholders can exclude from land other than in the context of rights to negotiate, which I have mentioned, which do not carry with them automatic rights to exclusion at all, and then only in very specific and narrow contexts. But it is not to be assumed that airspace is even to be regarded as part of native title. That is just part of the definition of land as employed in the bill. But right through the bill the issue is whether a particular piece of land and the airspace that goes with it is to be regarded as subject to native title rights or not. It is not making any assumptions about airspace being a part of the native title regime.

Senator Walters asked me with great portentousness, as she does in all her contributions to any given debate in any given context, why it did not include the bed or subsoil under waters. She asked, `What is the conspiracy that underlies this particular statutory provision, this particular qualification which manifestly does not seem to have anything to do with anything that is not part of the ordinary law?'.

When Senator Walters looks at the definition of water, she will see why it is excluded from land—because the bed or subsoil under waters is counted as part of the definition of water. Most of the bill is about simultaneously land on the one hand and water on the other and it is a matter of sorting out which particular category it is in. There ain't no conspiracy about the subsoil under water. It just happens to fit better with water than it does with land. Life's like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Doesn't the minister know that Senator Walters left some time ago?

—There is a small problem with a forensic genius approaching a debate such as this, not having read the bill and not having understood those bits of it which she has read. It is just another great populist tirade of the kind that she has made peculiarly her own. I am unimpressed and so is anyone who has been listening to her.

—I would like to clarify the situation as to the Greens' amendments because they were rather complex when they were first introduced. The Greens are withdrawing their amendment No. 54. I would just like to run through the amendments that are not supported by the government which may gain some support from the Democrats and ask the minister some questions in relation to this.

PARA.TAB: Greens' Amendment No. 44 refers to clause 213(9). We feel that that amendment should have been supported because it is inappropriate that future actions can be reflected as past acts, and that is exactly the effect of clause 213(9). An example of this is that the forestry reservation and logging agreement is a future act which gives permission to a future act. Yet in this bill it is being treated as a past act and is being validated. Obviously the Greens have concerns about this and wish to register it as the reason why they flagged amendment No. 44 and why we will be expressing a vote on it, even though we know that we do not have the support to pass that amendment.

I have some questions in relation to the next series of unsupported amendments. They are amendments 58, 62, 63 and 65. In relation to amendment 58, which refers to clause 222, page 104, paragraph (c), we simply put in that amendment to correct what we saw as a drafting error. In paragraphs (a) and (b) the reference to expedited procedures contains a reference to land and water and paragraph (c) refers only to land. Because there may be sacred waterholes or sites that should be covered as constituting `water', we believe it would be more appropriate to include that reference.

Amendments 62 and 63 relate to definitions of pastoral lease, not including a grazing licence. We feel that it is inappropriate that the clause does not include a grazing licence. We would like the minister's clarification. We placed amendment 63 on the record because we believed it corrected a drafting error to ensure that a revocation of recognition of a state-territory body can be made. Without this amendment, it may be argued that the minister has no power to revoke the standing of such a body.

Amendment 65 removes from the definition of interest an inappropriate expansion of the normal meaning. The expansion covers restrictions on land which are not tied to any particular land in question. We would like the minister to clarify what he sees as the intent of clause 238(c). The other amendments not receiving support are amendments 36 and 38 which look at the bill's definition of native title mirroring the common law and allowing Aboriginal people to show connection with the land even if they have been displaced and unable to maintain continuous contact. We are very grateful that the government has indicated support for amendment 37 which makes it clear that past as well as future conversions of native title to statutory rights are to be treated as native title rights.

For clarification, I indicate that the other support that we have from the government is on amendment 39, which amends clause 210, where we are requiring that the native title tribunal makes a determination of those native title rights which it considers to be of importance without requiring the tribunal to list all rights exhaustively. We believe that an exhaustive listing would unnecessarily intrude on the culture and spirituality of native title claimants. We welcome the support of the Democrats and the government for that amendment. The next group of supported amendments—47, 49 and 51—are technical ones which take out the phrase, `in the same capacity'. We understand that that allows a transfer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which amendments are you talking about now?
—Amendments 47, 49 and 51 which amend clause 214. I was talking about those to clarify that they do not need further comment. I would like the minister's response to amendments 63, 65 and 58.
—What's happened to 62? Is 62 still part of your repertoire?
—I welcome a comment on amendment 62, but I do not believe that we are gaining the government's support for that. It is the definition of pastoral lease.
—You are not getting support for 65 to 85 either!

—No, we are not getting support for those. That is why I would value the comments of the minister going on the public record. I would like to speak to clause 14C and also to unsupported amendments 48 and 53. They relate to the pastoral lease situation which the Greens have felt most strongly about in Western Australia. Thirty-eight per cent of Western Australia is under pastoral lease control. This basically represents 500 pastoral leases. There are approximately 10,000 Aboriginal people living all over those areas.

PARA.TAB: We are very grateful that the government has been able to include a clause 14C because it was very hurtful, in our view, that the Native Title Bill guaranteed extinguishment of a genuine native title claim if it were to prove the pastoral lease invalid. We believe that if that is deeply embedded in this legislation, and the government has proved intransigent on that, the least we can do is protect the people that may be living on those pastoral leases from dispossession. That is what clause 14C represents. I am indebted to the WA state legislation for clause 14C.

When the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, with one stroke of legislation, extinguished native title, he at least did one reasonable thing, which was to replace immediately any existing rights—the equity and usage rights that people have on land where they have had their proprietorial rights absolutely wiped out—with statutory and common law protection. That is the least we can do for people. If we are going to talk about validation—whether it is technical or just an endeavour to put economic certainty higher than recognition of native title rights—the least we can do is to ensure that Aboriginal people living on the land, where they and their families have lived for hundreds of years, are not dispossessed by a single act of the federal legislation.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Chapman)—Senator Chamarette, because you have already moved the amendment which you wish to withdraw, you will have to seek leave to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw amendment No. 54 that has been moved in the name of the Greens. Also, the Greens are not supporting government amendment No. 53. I hope that will clear up what the Greens have been presenting in this section of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need for the Greens not to support amendment No. 53 because we indicated our willingness to withdraw it some time ago. I have been asked to comment specifically, as I said I was prepared to do, on the reasons for our attitude to certain of the measures that Senator Chamarette mentioned, particularly amendments 58, 62, 63 and 65. I am happy to do that, particularly because on closer scrutiny it seems to me and my advisers that we might have been a trifle ungenerous in a couple of those amendments the first time around.
—Please feel free to reconsider.

—Senator Chamarette has asked me to reconsider. While she has been talking, I have been reconsidering. They are both very minor matters and it is a question of judgment as to whether or not the amendment is necessary to achieve a particular result. The initial reaction was that it was unnecessary but we may have been a little more persuasive.

PARA.TAB: As to amendment No. 58, the Greens wanted to include a reference to waters after the reference to land. The effect would be to allow acts that do not involve major disturbance to waters to proceed under the expedited procedure that is set out in the legislation. As presently drafted, it is only acts that do not involve major disturbance to land that can attract this procedure. The initial reaction of advisers was that disturbance to water was a rather difficult concept to come to terms with. That is why they were not originally moved by it.

But, since we are talking about both onshore and offshore waters and, as Senator Chamarette indicated when she spoke, questions of waterholes, rivers and riparian right equivalents and so on are at issue here, I do not see any harm in accepting the addition of the reference to waters. I think it is probably something where it is possible to contemplate a disturbance and, as such, an expedited procedure would not do any harm being applicable to that. As I said, it is a fairly minor, technical matter, but it is one that we can accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one was that?

—That was amendment 58, which involved a small change to clause 222. As to amendment 62, I am afraid the Greens' luck is not so good. That is an amendment to clause 233, which we see as both unnecessary to achieve the policy objective the Greens are chasing there and is likely to create uncertainty, moreover, if it was put in there. I do not think there is any policy difference between us. It is just essentially a drafting argument.

PARA.TAB: As to amendment 63, that is another technical drafting argument which boils down to a complicated half page of wrangling about the different grammatical tenses with which various concepts are expressed. Looking at the balance of the issues involved here, I think this is essentially a technical matter. There is no policy issue involved. The initial response that maybe the amendment was unnecessary seems to me perhaps a little robust. I think we can accept the amendment. It is not doing anything other than to clarify a particular clause which has a little bit of mystery about its drafting, which is probably penetrable at closer examination, but certainly is not at first sight. So we can accept that.

As to amendment 65, again being even-handed I have to say no. The definition as it stands does include, as an interest in land or waters, a right to stop other people doing something in relation to land or waters, such as having the benefit of a height restriction on buildings that can be erected on neighbouring land. It is important to validate any such restrictions which might well in certain circumstances be of value to, or protective of, the interests of Aboriginal people. We see this proposed amendment as potentially acting against the interests of Aboriginal people and, as such, perhaps it is a little misconceived. I hope that gives Senator Chamarette the answers she wanted on those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three issues that I specifically want to address this evening in this particular section. We are of course dealing with the definitions contained in the bill which are detailed at clauses 207 to 238. In effect, 25 clauses of the legislation are under consideration. It is very interesting to note that the amendments to those specific clauses that we currently have before us by the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Greens total 42—16 by the Greens, six by the Democrats and 20 by the Labor Party.
—They are pretty long clauses.

—They might be pretty long clauses, but I think it is very indicative of the paucity of this legislation that the section the government has dedicated to definitions requires 20 government amendments to 25 clauses. The Greens and the Democrats are also proposing an additional 22 amendments to the area of definition. Is there any wonder that the confusion in the community is profound? The definitional areas of this legislation require 42 amendments for consideration. Of course, a number of them have already been withdrawn by the Democrats and the Greens as they have heard the discussion which has taken place and the arguments that we have put forward at this particular point.

PARA.TAB: The minister has indicated that there are about six or seven of the Green and Democrat amendments to which the government is enticed and is favourably disposed. The fact that there are so many, together with the 20 amendments that the government is seeking to 25 clauses of the legislation, speaks for itself. There is little wonder that this particular legislation will definitely end up in the High Court and will be to the disadvantage of Aboriginal Australians because of that.

But let me get specific with regard to the issues that I want to address. The first point that I want to address is the issue of stock routes. I am very pleased that Senator Chamarette has withdrawn the proposed amendment that she had put forward to the definition of public work to exclude stock routes. The effect of the amendment that was to be put forward on stock routes would have been that stock routes would not come within category A and would come within category D, to which the non-extinguishment principle applies. Parts of these strips of land, which frequently run through other properties and divide them, would have been subject to native title which would operate to the extent it had.

If the amendment had proceeded, a property holder would have had to negotiate the crossing of native title land to get from one part of a property to another—how ridiculous. Depending on the enforceability of laws on native title land, uncontrolled activity on the land would have affected the economic viability of any venture on the surrounding lands. I am extremely pleased that the Greens, after obviously being under pressure, have seen commonsense in that particular area.

The second issue that I want to address relates very specifically to clause 213. I was amazed when I first found this proposed amendment on the original Greens schedule. I note that they have since dropped it. But of course the Democrats have continued to pursue it, and that issue seeks an amendment which would potentially destroy the national parks system in the Northern Territory. It attempts to make all titles of the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory unable to be validated.

Democrat amendment No. 37 proposes to insert a clause 213(10)(b) which provides that any grant to the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory or the Northern Territory Land Corporation would be deemed not to be a past act. If grants are not a past act, they are not capable of being validated. The freehold and leasehold interests held by these bodies would then be invalid. This has the potential to destroy the national parks system in the Northern Territory. I really question whether this is the intention of the Democrats, given the very significant national parks, which number dozens now, being very well developed—I notice Senator Collins is nodding; I am pleased to see that endorsement—by the Conversation Commission of the Northern Territory.

The amendment that the Democrats are proposing is discriminatory and ill-considered and it should be—thankfully, the minister has indicated that it will be—totally rejected. The Democrats, in their centralist Canberra driven-style of management and control, have no confidence or trust in the Northern Territory government. Anybody who walks through the Northern Territory as a tourist would be well aware of the sensitivity about national parks and their importance, not only to tourism.

The third issue I want to raise concerns the Greens' amendment 14C which relates specifically to subclause 196(b) of the bill. The bill currently provides that pastoral leases fall within the definition of category A, past act, and, if validated, extinguish native title. Clause 15 provides that any reservation for the benefit of Aboriginal people must be preserved when a pastoral lease is validated. The government's proposed subclause 208(4) specifies that a statutory reservation for Aboriginal people in a pastoral lease is not to be taken as being native title. From these provisions, it would appear that governments would be able to deal with pastoral land in the future since any activity would not affect native title. The Greens' proposed amendments dramatically change the ability of pastoralists and governments to deal with pastoral land. The amendments seek to enforce a permanent right of residence and access of Aborigines to all pastoral lands.

The consequence of these amendments will be that all pastoral land will be frozen according to its current use. Never again will pastoral land be able to be used for some alternative purpose which is inconsistent with those rights of residence or access. For example, there will be no more tourist developments on pastoral lease land, no pastoral leases on the edges of town could be subdivided and no pastoral leases could be used for agricultural purposes. It may be that these problems could be overcome by compulsory acquisition of the right of residence, but at what cost? The economic impact of these proposals on future governments will be quite substantial. Given that the minister is inclined to accept these amendments, I ask very specifically: how will it affect land management on pastoral leases?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the Democrats'—

—I am talking about Green amendment 14C to clause 196, which the minister has indicated he is inclined to support. The consequences of this amendment highlight the government's disregard for the issues that consequentially arise specifically in the Northern Territory. On a number of occasions in this debate the minister has rejected any right of the Northern Territory government to bring the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory into line with this particular legislation. I ask the minister to address those particular problems that I have raised on that clause.
—Let me address the Democrats' clause 14C and indicate briefly that the Democrats can speak for themselves. We endorse what they have said already, but I will add as follows.
—Greens.

—I am sorry; it is the Greens' amendment 14C. Senator Spindler does not need to be quite as strident in his identification. The purpose of this amendment is to guard against the possible effects of the validation provisions on Aboriginal people whose legal rights have been extinguished, despite the fact that they have access to or reside on a pastoral property. Clause 15 already provides protection for Aboriginal people who benefit from a reservation in the legislation or a lease or otherwise have rights under the common law or rights of usage. Amendment 14C affords protection to any Aboriginal people currently living on or with access to validated pastoral leases who are not protected by clause 15.

PARA.TAB: The amendment, I guess, is moved against the background of some of the really very dark moments in the history of our country when Aboriginal people were forcibly dispossessed of their land, in many cases to live just in corners of their former domains by the grace and favour of the new owners. In some cases Aboriginal people living on pastoral leases had the protection of legal rights and, by virtue again of clause 15, the validation of any such pastoral leases will preserve those legal rights. Having considered this whole matter rather carefully, the government believes that it is right to afford this additional protection for Aboriginal people who are unable to demonstrate a right under the law to their presence on pastoral leases other than any native title rights which might be extinguished as a result of the provisions of the bill.

The amendment provides that such people cannot be ejected or removed from the property simply by virtue of any such extinguishment. I think it does convey, accordingly, a pretty important message. It may well be that the whole context of validation, as I have said so many times before, is a largely theoretical one, but in the practical world of actually identifying pastoral lease properties where there was an invalid grant by virtue of the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act and so on, and that has subsequently to be validated, it may be that those cases will prove to be theoretical only and that, in practice, there were few, if any, actual such examples.

To the extent there may have been examples, and it seems likely that the part of the country where this issue is most likely to arise is the Kimberleys to the north-west of Western Australia, and to the extent it may have practical impact the question of forcible ejection and dispossession may have some practical relevance utility, as well as being a standard in principle set by the legislation and, as such, we support it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —(9.52 p.m.)—I want to pursue the issue. I did not get a good response.
—Do you want Senator Spindler's reply as well on behalf of the Democrats?
—I have spoken on amendment 14C of the Greens. What else does Senator Tambling want an answer to? Is it the Democrats' amendment 37?

—I was very clear in asking what the government's intention was specifically with the examples I drew to the attention of the minister. I asked whether the consequence of this amendment would be that there would be no more tourist developments on pastoral lease land, no pastoral leases on the edge of town could be subdivided, and no pastoral leases could be used for agricultural purposes. I believe that is a very serious consequence of this amendment, and I was looking for the government to very clearly flag its intention in that regard.

—Can Senator Tambling give me some arguments as to why that would be the consequence because I do not see that that would be the case? We are talking about Green amendment 14C, the addition of subclause (2) to clause 14, which is about extinguishment not conferring by itself any right of ejection. Is that the clause that Senator Tambling is talking about?
—Yes.
—Would Senator Tambling give me the chain of reasoning that produces the very-far reaching results that he claims will occur?
—The amendment Green 14C, which honourable senators will recall was amendment 14, 14A, 14A revised, 14B, 14B revised, and now appears as 14C, reads:

PARA.TAB: Clause 14, page 10, at the end of the clause, add the following subclause:

"(2) The extinguishment effected by this section does not by itself confer any right to eject or remove any Aboriginal persons who reside on or who exercise access over land or waters covered by a pastoral lease the grant, re-grant or extension of which is validated by section 13.".

I drew the minister's attention to the juxtaposition that would arise in this regard with this legislation. I ask for the minister's response: what is the government's intention as to the effects of this legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling still has not answered my question about how this legislation is supposed to stop subdivisions, tourist developments and all the things he is talking about.

PARA.TAB: Let me begin again at the beginning. What we are talking about here is the validation of notionally invalid leases by virtue of the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act or some other law in connection with the law of native title. We are not talking about valid pastoral leases or other kinds of leases that always have been valid and in respect of which no credible suggestion arises about invalidity. We are only talking about those which may be invalid. The standard case that people think of in this respect is invalid by virtue of the non-discriminatory provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act—which came into operation in 1975, not before.

There are not many pastoral leases that have been granted anywhere in the country since 1975. Even those that have been notionally identified as new pastoral leases after 1975 are subject to an argument, I understand, that maybe these were not new pastoral leases at all but simply continuations in a slightly different guise of earlier granted leases.

Then there is the question of whether or not, if they were granted after 1975, we can say they were granted in a way that was offensive to the Racial Discrimination Act because no compensation was paid—this being in a situation, of course, where nobody knew at that stage, until 1982, that there was such a thing as native title.

So we have to erect theoretical possibility upon theoretical possibility, and we are only doing it in relation to a very small proportion of the number of pastoral leases that exist in this particular country—a tiny proportion, at best. The suggestion from the National Farmers Federation is that there might have been somewhere between two and 13 such leases that would, prima facie, come within the scope of this legislation. That is out of all the thousands of pastoral leases which exist across the length and breadth of this country. So, when we are talking about dire consequences following from any reading of the effect of the validation clause, we are only talking about this theoretical possibility in relation to a tiny proportion of the total number of pastoral leases.

But, when we do focus on that as being the particular situation we are talking about, we then see the effect of this particular clause. Bearing in mind that the effect of clause 14 is to extinguish any Aboriginal native title that may have existed as a result of the validation exercise, what it says is that the extinguishment effected by this section does not, by itself, confer any right to eject or remove any Aboriginal persons who reside on or who exercise access over land or waters covered by a pastoral lease which has been, in effect, validated. That is all we are talking about. The extinguishment by itself does not confer any right to eject or remove.

There are other ways under the law, as spelt out in this legislation, by which such a removal of Aboriginal people could be accomplished. One is by agreement—they might choose, in effect, to renounce or relinquish their physical possession of a particular part of the area in question to which they might otherwise have established some non-extinguished right and to use that as the basis for an agreement with a tourist development or something of that kind. Again, we have the compulsory acquisition provisions which apply to any non-extinguished native title situation anywhere in the country and which would equally apply in this situation, with the compensation that is payable pursuant to that acquisition varying depending on the nature of the title, the interest and so on. So we have ways of achieving the result that may be necessary for economic development purposes.

But I repeat: Senator Tambling is only looking at the operation of this whole clause in the context of an essentially theoretical validation exercise. There are some big principles attached to this subclause—and we think it is not unimportant to state these principles for the reasons I have spelt out. But, in terms of its practical impact, on any view the impact of this clause will not be great.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I was anticipating a response to the challenge I threw to Senator Spindler on the intention of the Democrats with regard to the Northern Territory national parks.

PARA.TAB: I have attempted in this debate over the last few days to keep my comments very focused on the interests of the Northern Territory and Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. I made a number of comments in my speech during the second reading debate and throughout the committee stage. I focused very specifically on issues that will impact and I drew various comparisons between this bill, which I consider to be very fundamentally flawed, and the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory. This bill, with 238 clauses and over 200 amendments proposed here in the last few days, is very indicative of the changes that are expected.

Aboriginal Australians who are expecting a major change from this legislation will be very disappointed that many of their expectations have not been met. Those who are expecting social justice will have to wait until next February for the Prime Minister's response. Those Aboriginal Australians who were looking to this legislation for respect for their traditional customs and lore will again be sorely disappointed because the points that were raised in various forums have not been met, and they will be let down by this legislation.

Others who hope that the legislation will deliver Aborigines from government dependency will also be disappointed. There is a lack of certainty for industry to operate and expand. That has been very well demonstrated by reports in the last week or so and certainly in many other areas. There is a failure to enhance private sector employment opportunities for Aboriginal and other Australians. And that is the greatest issue facing the federal government at the moment—how do we provide private sector employment for all Australians?

This legislation fails to address the inconsistencies, as I have said time and again, with the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory, particularly as it affects mining exploration, confidence, investment, pastoral management, and access to waterways, river beds and river banks. I am fearful that, because of the government's, the Greens' and the Democrats' unnecessary haste with this legislation, it will now inevitably end up in the High Court for years and years and, consequently, the losers will be Aboriginal Australians. Labor's relentless push seems to be driven by an international agenda and a timetable rather than reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the comments by Senator Tambling about our amendment which seeks to ensure that native title claims are not excluded from the conservation-land corporation areas established under the conservation commission legislation of the Northern Territory or the Northern Territory Land Corporation established under the Northern Territory Land Corporation Act 1986. The reason is very simple: these structures were used, and possibly intentionally established, to withdraw large tracts of land from native title claim by setting these corporations up and saying that they were deemed not to be crown land so that native title claims could not be made. That is the legal reason why we think that such subterfuge should not be permitted. We have added subsection (d) which, for good measure, prohibits any act in bad faith.

PARA.TAB: There is the substantive issue, of course. Senator Tambling does not seem to understand that Aboriginal people do take care of the natural environment and that there is absolutely no reason why native title could not coexist with national parks.

TALK.START.PARA: —What reason do you have to substantiate that?
—Senator Tambling should have a look at Uluru.
—You said I didn't understand it. Withdraw that.

—I will not withdraw it because Senator Tambling's claim that these national parks should not be available to native title indicates that you believe that the two are incompatible, whereas they are clearly compatible. We only have to look at the way Aboriginal people have looked after the natural environment and the way we have despoiled it in the 200 years that we have been here. Clearly, the two are not incompatible, and we should not use a somewhat surprising concern for the natural environment as a reason to exclude vast areas from native title claim.

PARA.TAB: I should also comment on one or two other things Senator Tambling said in his general comments. He adverted to the fact that this bill, when it becomes an act and its various provisions come into effect, will not provide sufficient protection for employment or sufficient incentive for economic activity. I believe that as a nation we must reconcile what is social justice in this particular case with our economic objectives.

Ultimately, when we have a nation that is proud of its identity and has resolved an inherent conflict because of the unjust act that we as a country have perpetrated on indigenous people, we will benefit both economically and socially. We must bite the bullet, if I can put it that way, and do at the moment what is just. In the long term this will not be an economic disadvantage.

I feel privileged to have been part of this process. People have said that this legislation is extremely complex, and so it is. But the process to get it through this chamber has been even more complex. When we look at the various people who have been involved in developing this legislation and in reconciling the myriad of different political views that have existed, it is little short of a miracle. But miracles do not happen, and I think we should take heart from this process for the future of Australia. If we can make this work, it augurs well for us as a nation—just as if we had not made it work, if we had failed today, it would have been a bad sign for the future of Australia.

It is useful to reflect briefly that just about every participant in this process started with different political expectations and aspirations. We all have different views about what is politically possible in a particular situation, and this situation is so complex with so many interests which need to be reconciled in a balance—

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't get thanked in the High Court; neither will the Aboriginal people thank you.

—We owe a debt of gratitude to the High Court for having given us this opportunity to establish once and for all that when we came here this land was inhabited by Aboriginal people. Had we left it to the High Court and not taken legislative action, we would have entered decades of uncertainty and had hundreds of legal cases on our hands. As it is, we have reconciled—I believe successfully, although I appreciate that views differ—the various interests and expectations. Being aware of how different the various expectations were, how much some people thought this would give them and how little others thought should be given, it is a credit to our political and social process.

PARA.TAB: Obviously it was not just politicians who worked on this to achieve what we have achieved tonight. When I say `we' I do not mean the politicians; I mean the Aboriginal people from across the whole spectrum of Aboriginal communities who participated in this process; I mean the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the government—and certainly I include the legal advisers who have assisted on a voluntary basis and those employed by the various Aboriginal and other organisations.

It is tempting to use some names, to pick out people; but I am going to resist that temptation. If I named one or two or even a dozen, I would leave out 20 or 30 others who have worked equally hard, equally courageously, and have been equally committed.

We should also put on record that we owe a gratitude to the Prime Minister, Paul Keating. It is not often that I agree with the Prime Minister, I must say. But on this occasion it is useful and right, I believe, to put on record that we owe this bill ultimately to his single-minded conviction that this must be achieved. I believe that Cheryl Kernot, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and the two Green senators also deserve a mention. I know that Cheryl has had a longstanding commitment to this particular aim. She is a member of the Aboriginal Reconciliation Council, and I know that in the last few weeks and months she has lived almost exclusively to this end. I would also like to say that while at times we have found the positions adopted by our Green friends somewhat exasperating, they too played a part; they too provided a building block in the political process that has finally achieved what we have tonight.

There is very little else to say except that, once again, I feel privileged to have been part of this process. I believe it is a good start for building our nation from here on in. While we know that we need to continue to work at the detail of this bill, we have made a start, and I believe an important one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this debate finally draws to a close, there are some matters in this section that I feel compelled to raise with the minister. I refer to amendment No. 50A of the government dealing with clause 208. I want to know what the government's intention was here, because subclause 208(4) has been changed. As I see it, it works like this: Senator Evans said that subclause (3) gave a rebirth to native title as a result of state legislation; he referred to Western Australia but it was to refer to all states. This subclause says that, to avoid any doubt, that subclause does not apply to rights and interests created by a reservation in relation to a pastoral lease, provided those reservations are not native title rights and interests.

PARA.TAB: As we know, in Western Australia, and in other states, there are reservations on pastoral leases—this goes back some time now—which have specifically allowed Aboriginal people in the area to hunt on the property, to traverse across the property. It has been said that in those cases the pastoral lease does not necessarily extinguish native title completely because these reservations or conditions on the pastoral leases are effectively reserving the rights of Aboriginal people.

Why then has the government brought about this change in the amendment to say that these reservations and conditions are not included in subclause (3), which are not native title rights and interests? That is implying that some of them might be and might not be. That is the confusion I find. Can the minister enlighten me?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do the best that I can. Senator Ellison will be aware that under clause 208(3) the definition of `native title' includes native title rights and interests which have been compulsorily converted into statutory rights. This amendment provides that rights and interests which have been created by reservations or by conditions in pastoral leases—whether in the lease or by virtue of the legislation under which the lease was granted—are not converted by subclause (3) into native title. Because these rights and interests are created by statute, they cannot be native title under the definition in clause 208(1). This provision, 208(4), is making clear that 208(3) does not result in these rights being treated as native title by this bill.

PARA.TAB: If, under the common law, a native title survives the grant of the pastoral lease—that is, of course, an issue that remains to be tested—it will then fall within the definition of native title in clause 208(1). The determination of this issue is left for the common law. We are not trying to pre-empt that process at the moment. That is again a rather complex explanation, but I hope it makes sense. If Senator Ellison has any further questions, I am happy to try to wrestle with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that these prior reservations and conditions which were in favour of the local Aboriginal people are not enjoying the rebirth as described in clause 208(3) that the minister mentioned; they are being excluded?

—They do not enjoy rebirth because, by definition, they never had the status of being common law native title. They were created by statute to begin with. They are not eligible for rebirth, as I put it, under this provision.
—Then it shows that they are excluded as coming under the category of native title.

—They are not excluded if, as a matter of common law litigation, they were held to be capable of surviving the grant of the pastoral lease. The matter in issue in all of this—the great unresolved issue at common law—is whether the granting of a pastoral lease will succeed in extinguishing native title. The working assumption which underlies this bill is yes, it will, because that is the result that is pointed to by so many of the judgments in the Mabo case; but it has not been absolutely and finally determined. There is a strong sentiment around the place, understandably, that rather than pre-empting that issue we should leave it to the courts to finally resolve it. That issue is still left for resolution.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the process that is laid out in this particular complex set of provisions, the working assumption of the legislation is that the bits of title that we are talking about were created by statute originally and were not the product of the common law existence and, therefore, do not come within the scope of this particular statutory provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a long four days and we have covered a good deal of ground in this bill. But I just finish on the note that the complexity of this bill never ceases to amaze me. As has just been demonstrated in that last exchange, it still might be that this has to be resolved by a court. We are not left with any sufficiency of certainty. I will give the committee an example. If one looks at the definitions section, one sees the definition of `native title party'. If one looks at clause 29, we see that phrase mentioned there. One then goes to clause 207 which contains the list of definitions. Under the phrase `native title party', one is referred to clause 238. When one goes to clause 238, the meaning of `native title party' is set out. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: "native title party"—
this is the third clause that we have looked at—
has the meaning given by paragraphs 28(2)(a) and (b) and section 29;

So we then go back to clauses 28 and 29, which is where we started. We then have to wrestle mentally with what `native title party' is. That is just one phrase which appears in the bill; there are many others. With due respect to the government, I do not believe that this bill has effectively addressed the issue. Any person who picks up this bill and reads it to see what redress or cause of action they would have would be seriously confused.

PARA.TAB: I agree that this is a very complex situation. I have been very lucky to have served on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and to have had the benefit of lawyers advising the government on this situation. I compliment them on their work. Mr Orr has been most helpful in the questions that I put to him. Nonetheless, we have a bill which is so complex that the average man or woman would have no chance to come to grips with it. This chamber has been wrestling with it now for four days. I think we have seen just how many pitfalls there are in relation to the bill's efficiency.

Leaving aside the purposes for such a bill, the ideals which it is supposed to promote and the problems that it seeks to address, my thrust is whether it does the job. That is what legislation is all about. I know that, because laws are imperfect and human beings are imperfect, the system will never run perfectly; it will never be that smooth. But the responsibility stops in this chamber to make sure that the legislation we pass does work and can run as smoothly as possible without leaving matters to be determined in the courts, which will give batteries of lawyers lots of work to do.

I remember a client of mine who once said that the problem with the law is that it is not simple. I asked him how he would fix it. He said that he would simplify it, so I asked him how he would do that. He replied that he would make it more simple. I could see that I was getting nowhere with him. It is very easy to say that legislation should be simple but, when day-to-day events in human affairs, especially over a passage of time, evolve and are determined, they become more and more complex. So any piece of legislation which sets out to govern human affairs and behaviour always offers a very difficult task to the person setting out on that course. I do not think the definitions and the drafting—not necessarily the style of drafting, but the way in which this bill is set up—are an effective response to the Mabo No. 2 decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I finish by referring to another aspect. The bill quite cleverly divides past acts on one side and future acts on the other; that is, what category of acts has gone before and what is to come. That would seem to be the most reasonable approach.
