The problem with the definition of past acts is that it says, if one were granted a lease in the past and one has an option to renew it in the future, that act in the future is really a past act. That is one of the most confusing things about this legislation. I could cite more examples but time does not permit me to do so tonight. The same applies to future acts, impermissible acts and permissible future acts. That is the reason I wish to place on record my grave concerns about how this bill will work.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate the minister's endeavours to assist me over the last four days with the inquiries I have made of him and I do appreciate the assistance given by his advisers. But I must respectfully say that, at the end of the day, I am not drawn to the conclusion that this bill will work. Time will tell; it will be only by experience in the courts that we will unfortunately discover these flaws.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have questions to ask Senator Chamarette and Senator Spindler. I refer to the Greens amendment 14C which replaced 14B which replaced 14A—
—At least it has been consistent. You can find your way through.
—Yes. I ask Senator Chamarette what impact clause 14 will have on pearling leases.
—That's a pearler.

—Yes, I agree, that is a pearler of a response. I am very grateful to Senator Crane for actually allowing me to comment on amendment 14C—and the various other titles that it went by—which amended clause 14, because that really represents the major sticking point that the Greens (WA) had with this legislation as a whole. We had no problem with clause 13, which was the validation of all past leases. We felt that that was a reasonable and appropriate response from the government in view of expressions of uncertainty and concern.

PARA.TAB: However, we felt that the principle was very strongly supported that coexistence of native title with validated leases was a totally appropriate response. The technical point conveyed was that a lease may be invalidated because it was issued after 1975, and, due to the fact that native title could be appropriately held to be present on it, it should by this legislation be extinguished even though compensation was paid to make it valid and make it conform to the RDA. At the same time as calling itself the Native Title Bill, this bill actually extinguished some rights somewhere.

The reality is that many times in question time in the House of Representatives and certainly in the Senate we were trying to elicit how many people would be affected by this particular clause. While we have not been able to gain much information, certainly the concerns of the Greens (WA) lay in the area of pastoral leases. We believe that there may be in the region of 11, or X number, of those. There is no way of telling at the moment whether they will involve any other kinds of leases. But our principle still stands. While validation of a pastoral lease or a commercial lease is appropriate—this would involve the pearling industry or a tourist lease—the principle of coexistence should have been an integral part of this bill.

We were unable to support the bill until the government was in agreement with something in the order of our amendment 14C. Mind you—and Senator Crane knows this—there were many other sticking points which we did fight for, but this was the one that really hit home in Western Australia. Basically, we regard that clause as a protection against dispossession. We regard it as one of the basic requirements of human rights that, if validation does happen to lead to extinguishment, the least we can do is make sure that Aboriginal people do not suffer what they suffered when we had the equal pay debate many years ago, and in the other ways that they have suffered in the last 200 years.

I am sorry that I cannot give Senator Crane any details about the pearling industry. As far as we know, it is a theoretical possibility only that a native title entitlement of some kind may put into question another kind of lease. Clause 14 of this legislation would reassure any of those people who may be concerned about it.

In this clause we see that nothing which is already in existence as a usage, statutory or equity right can be removed. As the honourable senator praised the Western Australian legislation—I must say we would not do that because we feel it is a violation of indigenous people's rights—he will be glad to know that, as I said earlier, the clause we chose was modelled after what the Premier of Western Australia did. Where he has extinguished title, he has provided total support for whatever was in existence so that nobody could be dispossessed. We have to give him credit for that at least.

I am sorry to have taken so long, but we felt that this was our response to the fact that pastoral leases had been included in category A and regarded as extinguished. We felt they should have been in category D or at least left up to the courts. When we did not gain support for our amendments Nos 48 and 53, which sought to change the classification of pastoral leases from category A to category D, we asked for protection for those people who could be in danger of dispossession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that very simple, straightforward question highlights the complexity of this legislation. It highlights the fact that amendments have been made on the run and thrown around this chamber for the last four days and that the people who moved those amendments have not had any idea of what they were doing or what was happening. I think that is very sad.

PARA.TAB: If we go to the definition of a pastoral lease, we will see quite clearly that it has a very direct impact on a pearling lease. It is directly connected. I wanted to draw out that point. I did not pose it as a trick question; I merely wanted to demonstrate the complexity of so much of this debate. I notice that the minister is checking this out. He does not have to give us a five minute speech on it, because I have checked it out. I think that is one of the sad things about this debate.

I find this an extraordinary amendment. It affects only two states—South Australia and Western Australia—and the Northern Territory. The rights conferred by this amendment already exist in legislation in those two states and the territory. The amendment does not address the problems on the eastern seaboard that I have referred to previously. With all due respect to Senator Chamarette, I believe she has missed the mark with this amendment. She has made an assumption which I do not believe is reasonable.

I would like to ask another couple of questions because I think I have made my point about the complexity and difficulty of this legislation and why it will end up in the High Court. The honourable senator's amendment refers to those `who exercise access over land or waters'. As far as pastoral leases are concerned—I am now talking about running sheep and cattle basically—is it intended that that part of the clause will confer more rights than exist now under the reservations that have been made?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not exactly sure which particular amendment it is, but I know that the Greens have moved several that regard water—

—Amendment No. 14C mentions those who exercise access over land or waters. In terms of the reservations that now exist in those states that it will affect, is the intention to maintain the existing rights or increase the rights which exist there now?

—No. The intention is simply to preserve the rights that exist so that they are not undermined by this legislation. It is not to enhance in any way but to make sure that this is not a discriminatory piece of legislation that removes what it is purporting to protect. That is our interpretation of it and that is the intention for which it has been designed.

—I am relieved to hear that, because there are different rules for different waters, for very good reasons—but we will not go into that now. Senator Chamarette mentioned existing rights. I am sure that, in moving an amendment such as this, she is aware of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication program. In all the states, some changes had to be made to the reservation in terms of being able to fence off areas to separate clean animals and dirty animals, which are those that are diseased.

PARA.TAB: Does this amendment exclude those state governments when there is a similar type of program for taking the necessary actions to either control a similar situation—one could think of a whole host of diseases that might come into this country—or, for example, the spread of noogoora burr or bathurst burr down the Fitzroy River? Is there still sufficient scope in the amendment to allow that sort of action to be taken to take control? Once again, having moved this amendment, I am sure Senator Chamarette would be aware of the situation that exists in the area that I am referring to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain whether it is fair that I am answering these questions and the minister is not, but I will certainly tell Senator Crane what the intention is.
—Order! Senator Crane is entitled to ask questions only of the mover of the amendments, notwithstanding the fact that Senator Gareth Evans is probably dying to contribute.

—Mr Chairman, thank you for your guidance. The reality is that the intention of the Greens was not to in any way interfere with any of those sorts of programs or something that is going on. We want to ensure that there is no dispossession.

PARA.TAB: The reason I thought it was appropriate for the minister to answer was that we framed it so that it would prevent any ejection or removal of any Aboriginal people who were members of a community residing on a lease that was being validated because of questionable validity. We wanted protection from that situation for them. The minister gave it very close scrutiny before he accepted it. So if there are any complexities that I am not aware of, he would be more aware of them.

I can assure Senator Crane that, as far as we are concerned, the passage of this bill, with clause 14 in it, which included the extinguishment of native title rights, was an enormous barrier. The only way in which we could come to it was to ensure that native title rights were protected and not impaired. It was not to cause any interference whatsoever in the validation process or the process that is possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is all encompassing. It does not allow for variation by state government statute. I hear what the honourable senator is saying about referring it to Senator Gareth Evans, but it is not appropriate to refer it to him because it is her amendment. The honourable senator is from Western Australia and represents, one would hope, all Western Australian interests. It is important when moving an amendment in this place to at least understand what is being moved and the impact of it.

PARA.TAB: To that I would add that this will also have important ramifications for all pastoral leases, including the 10 per cent held by Aboriginal interests. So I ask the honourable senator precisely what she means by `rights'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Crane referring to my amendment 14C?
—Yes.

—I do not think that the rights referred to are those conferred on Aboriginal people by validation; they are the rights of people not to be dispossessed or removed from where they reside or exercise access because of statutory reservation or for an equity reason. For example, Aborigines may have been living in a certain area for many years and have a particular attachment to it as part of their culture. The clause does not actually contain the word `rights' except in so far as it says that extinguishment does not confer any right to remove people on a statutory usage or equity basis.

—This is a classic example of an amendment coming in at the last minute to allow the government to get its bill through. I doubt whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) knows what a bathurst burr in the Fitzroy River is, let alone what the practical effects of this particular amendment are.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask Senator Spindler a couple of questions with regard to clause 53. I ask the honourable senator firstly: why is this amendment drafted in such a way that it will not cover the creation of new leases in Western Australia? Since Senator Spindler moved this amendment, he would be aware that there has to be new legislation in Western Australia to allow new leases to be created. There is no provision for lease renewal or an extension of time; there has to be a new lease. Secondly, in putting forward an amendment such as this, why has he discriminated against the mining industry? So there are two points: firstly, why has he discriminated against Western Australian pastoral lease holders; secondly, why has he discriminated against the mining industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer the first question: this particular amendment is directed towards the renewal or extension of leases. It does not prohibit the granting of new leases, it simply does not deal with them because that is not its intention. We realise that new leases will be created on Crown land—there is no objection to that—but this amendment simply does not deal with that matter.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the second question: the distinction we make between mining and pastoral leases is simply based on the different kinds of activity carried out under the terms of each lease. Whereas a pastoral lease, unless it is simply a grazing licence, requires exclusive occupation for long periods of time, a mining lease is limited to intensive operations for a short period of time. Since mining leases do not extinguish native title, and native title revives after the mining operation has concluded, there was no reason to give additional security to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again this demonstrates how amendments have been made on the run. The mover of the amendments has not got a single clue about what he is doing. There are 400 pastoral leases in Western Australia and the only way they can continue to exist to the year 2015 is for a new lease to be created, and I think that is very sad. I was not talking about new leases on crown land; I was talking about existing leases.
—This does it.

—It does not cover the creation of a new lease. Senator Spindler has not got a clue. This demonstrates how much Rick Farley of the National Farmers Federation has been involved in this process and in these leases. I think it is very sad that he has set himself up as the modern-day Neville Chamberlain of Australian politics. That is the effect of what has happened. Finally, I want to thank the staff and the various other people who have contributed to this debate and put on record my appreciation of their contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister a question about clauses 220 and 221. This is a very complex bill. Does the minister agree or disagree with Mr Peter Eggleston, the Executive Officer of the Chamber of Mines and Energy of Western Australia? In his evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, he said:

PARA.TAB: To understand the bill you have to understand the definitions . . . A past act can occur in the future—that is, after the commencement of the bill. A future act can occur in the past—that is, before the commencement of the bill. A permissible future act can be impermissible in certain circumstances, and an impermissible future act can be permissible also in certain circumstances. I put it to you that it is extraordinarily confusing—almost incomprehensible—to the user.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Eggleston went on to say:
. . . how can land administrators, miners, farmers, fishermen, pearlers, tourist operators and the Aboriginal community hope to even begin to make this work?
I ask the minister how the government is going to make this bill work when it becomes an act. It looks like an absolute shemozzle.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comment Senator Brownhill quoted from the Western Australian mining industry spokesman was the most perceptive, intelligent, thoughtful and understanding piece of analysis I have heard coming from that support. He is dead right on all counts. It is in the nature of some of these definitions that they are capable of application, in prima facie odd looking ways, in particular situations because of things to do with the commencement dates for the introduction of the bill or the commencement of the operation of certain clauses.

PARA.TAB: I think the point can be made that, complex and lengthy as the bill is, it is a bill that has withstood remarkably well the extraordinarily close and meticulous scrutiny to which it has been subjected over the 38 hours or more that we have been debating the committee stage. There is no single clause in it which has been demonstrated to have any fundamental flaw. There were a couple of minor things along the way that we have said probably deserve some scrutiny and possibly some attention in a later review exercise, but there are no conceptual defects. There are no flaws of a self-evident kind. The complexity that is there is nonetheless a complexity that is the product of the complexity of the subject matter, rather than being arbitrary or the product of poor drafting or ill-thought-out drafting.

It is really a very great achievement for Australian government parliamentary counsel to have produced a bill as complex as this one obviously is in the issues with which it deals, but to do it in a way that clearly still has every clause meaning something, the concepts and the principles underlying it emerging still with clarity at the end of the day and the detail being workable in every respect. That has been demonstrated in the course of the debate in this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister basically saying, at this stage of this long debate, that it is going to be a potential legal nightmare for people. Whether it is permissible or impermissible, whether it is going to be in the future or in the past—I do not know how we can change the past—basically it is going to—
—You certainly can't do that in the National Party.
—It is interesting that Senator Schacht should say that; he will have the chance to say something in a minute.
—That is the first contribution he has made to the debate.

—It is the first time Senator Schacht has opened his mouth. Why does he not look after his own portfolio instead of getting into something as contentious as this? Before I yield to Senator Campbell and Senator Chris Ellison, who have played such a good part in this debate, surely it is going to be a legal jungle and a real money maker for the legal fraternity.

—I am afraid that Senator Brownhill is going to have to do a bit better than that if he is to try to put words in my mouth. I had occasion earlier in this debate to describe Senator Alston as a kind of cut-rate Rumpole. Where that question leaves Senator Brownhill is a cut-rate Bronwyn Bishop.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a gender difference for a start, so Senator Evans is wrong in that perception. I also think that somebody who is entitled to be called Biggles should sit down and stop flying so much.

—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. For those seeking the call and who have not spoken during the debate, I simply remind them that the guillotine was not of my making. Can I suggest that we deal with the amendments which the government has indicated it will not support, so as to draft those out from the clauses which the government will support. I propose to put the following amendments: Democrat amendments 38, 39, 46, 35 and 37; and Green amendments 36, 38, 48, 53, 44, 62 and 65. They are amendments to clauses 207 to 238 inclusive and postponed clause 14. The question is that those amendments be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I propose to put the government amendments and the amendments which I understand the government is supporting. They are in this order: 47, 56, 58, 59, 60, 69A, 48, 49, 50A, 65, 66, 67, 71, 51, 52, 55, 57, 70, 73 and 54. There is amendment 53 for the Australian Democrats. The Green amendments are: 37, 39, 47, 49, 51, 58, 63 and 14C, which is an amendment to postponed clause 14. The question is that those amendments be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That clauses 207 to 238 and clause 14, as amended, and the title be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill has been passed with 115 amendments. Less than two weeks ago, in the second reading debate, we were told that there was no need for any amendments, that the government fully understood all that was required, that there was no complexity or uncertainty and that the bill deserved to be passed in that form. The fact is that this bill ended up having one less amendment before the chair than there are clauses—238 clauses with 237 amendments. Ninety-nine government amendments were ultimately put before this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Tonight an historic opportunity has been lost. No-one, let alone any political party, has a monopoly on compassion or concern or social justice. Australians very much appreciate that there are very many Australians, particularly Aboriginal Australians, living in conditions of extreme social and economic disadvantage. The solution to those problems lies in addressing those issues on the merits. We have always been committed to doing just that. We have been enthusiastic participants in the reconciliation process—much as those opposite would like that to be yet another point of division between the political parties, because they have the most divisive political leader in Australian history who is intent on polarising the nation. But we supported the government and we supported the Australian community in terms of the reconciliation process.

However, the High Court decision is not about reconciliation. The High Court decision was a landmark decision which recognised for the first time a different and distinctive form of land title, known as native title. That decision had inevitable consequences, which we accept. The approach to land management in this country has been altered and as a result there is a need for a governmental and legislative response. But that does not mean that we need to have a bill rammed through this parliament in the disgraceful jackboot way we have seen over the last four days.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the longest debate in the Senate's history.

—Indeed, because this is probably the most significant bill in Australian history, which deserves to be taken seriously and which does not deserve to be jackbooted and rammed through to suit the government's political convenience just because it has a prime minister who less than 24 hours ago said that this bill could be before the chamber until Christmas day and we could come back on Boxing Day if necessary. Less than 24 hours later he tells Senator Evans to make sure it is rammed through the Parliament.
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides. There will be a number of speakers from both sides and I ask that the chamber hear them all in relative silence.

—This decision of the High Court demanded a sensitive, considered and consultative approach. After all, the decision was handed down in June 1992. It took the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) almost six months to even turn his mind to it in the lead-up to the election campaign. It took almost a further 12 months before the bill was introduced into the parliament. Quite clearly, the government had enormous trouble grappling with the complexity of the decision. What was required above all was to consult—
—You cannot say that; you rammed through our amendments.

—Senator Cook is hardly ever here; I do not think he would understand it. He should stick to rams and we will stick to bills. The fact is that there was a perfect opportunity for the government to practise the politics of inclusion and go out into the highways and byways to take evidence in a proper and civilised manner, to try to involve the states.

PARA.TAB: The government pays lip service to the fact that land management is a state responsibility. What does it then do? It introduces a bill which is utterly and completely about taking away the rights of the states to make land management decisions. There was no attempt at all to recognise the very different conditions which prevail across Australia. Australia is a federation which tries to bring together very different states, very different regional areas and very different conditions under which its citizens exist.

My state of Victoria does not have a significant problem with the Mabo legislation. The state of Western Australia, on the other hand, has a very big problem with Mabo because at the moment about 12 per cent of the land mass of Western Australia is already covered by Aboriginal reserves, special purpose grants and the like, and another 30 per cent or thereabouts is vacant crown land and therefore potentially claimable under this legislation. Western Australia has a unique condition which needs to be addressed separately.

Yet what does the Prime Minister want to do? He basically wants to treat the premiers with contempt. He wants to get through a uniform solution to a series of very different problems. That is the politics of exclusion. There is no serious attempt to recognise the problems that are faced by farmers and miners. They just happen to be pandering to all the greenophobia that comes out from certain sections—`They are the ones who are ripping it out and flogging it; they are the ones who are causing the problems; they are the ones who are devastating the environment'. There is never any recognition these days from the greatest economic rationalist of the 1980s that Australia's real future and real prospects of prosperity in the years ahead lie in economic development, in increased living standards, in greater employment opportunities and in the capacity to deliver increased welfare and support to those in need.

That all comes from economic solutions which do not pretend there is a pot of gold, which do not on the one hand say, `Here's a bill that will directly benefit five per cent of the Aboriginal community; the other 95 per cent will be picked up by a land fund or social justice package. We can't put a figure on it, we want a blank cheque, but we can tell you that it will cost hundreds of millions of dollars over the next 15 or 20 years'. Of course, this is together with all the litigation that will have to ensue. If there is one thing we know, it is that we are starting off on a long and tortuous road—and that road leads immediately to the High Court of Australia. If the Canadian experience is any guide, it will lead to 20 years of litigation followed by royal commissions from time to time. All of this means—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your alternative?

—Our alternative was a 12-point plan which we laid down before the Australian public. It involved an acknowledgment of the validity of the High Court decision and a need to address the very important native title rights that were proclaimed by that court. We also accepted the need for the Racial Discrimination Act to prevail over any other land management decisions hereafter; to the extent that there was any infringement, then compensation would need to be paid on just terms. Also, fundamentally, we acknowledged that land management decisions remained the responsibility of the states. That was the basis for an inclusive and considered approach to an historic High Court decision.

PARA.TAB: Yet, after 18 months of trying to come to grips with the decision, trying to get a COAG meeting to agree, suddenly the Prime Minister said, `That's it, I've had enough. I'm going to force this bill through. I'm going to put it before the parliament. I'm going to ensure that the Senate gets it through, by hook or by crook'.

Let me go a little further. I do not want any misunderstanding about this as it is very important. The fact is that we are committed to addressing Aboriginal disadvantage; we are committed to properly implementing the decision of the High Court. But we would not do it in the way that those opposite have sought to do it: by an approach that is essentially divisive, that has essentially polarised the nation and that will lead to very severe economic and social consequences in the future.

What was the urgency about this? The urgency was that, for the Prime Minister's political convenience, this bill was to be passed through the parliament before Christmas. The fact that the bill goes well beyond the Mabo decision is simply something which is brushed aside. The miners are clearly self-interested and selfish—ignore them. In other words, if there is a problem—if Mr Farley falls off the cart; if the miners say they cannot hack it any longer; if all of the Liberal leaders and the state premiers around Australia, except Mr Goss, who of course threw his own separate tantrum, say that the legislation is unworkable—he ignores all of that. He just says to Senator Evans, `You've got your riding instructions; I'll get out there one day and say that we'll sit through until Christmas; but you go away and work out how you can guillotine this legislation through the parliament'.

There will be a swag of amendments next year—we know that—all because of the fact that we continue to have no idea of the ultimate consequences of this legislation. Therefore, I say that this is merely the start of a long process. We will continue to take a constructive approach to the problems of Australia. We will not pretend that somehow we can redress the problems overnight; we will not pretend that the solutions lie in blaming ourselves and our forebears. We will look ahead; we will look at the country's capacity to afford to address these issues; and we will do this in the most sensible and inclusive way we can.

I just simply say in passing that, given that we do not have the phalanx of advisers who are available to the government, we are grateful for the services of Peter van Hatten, who has been with us for the last four days providing us with invaluable assistance.
The final thing I would say is this: we did not move amendments to this legislation because it would have been tinkering at the edges. It could not possibly—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am waiting for the rabble to subside. I cannot help saying in passing that the name Democrat has been abused beyond recognition in this chamber by the Leader of the Democrats, who the other day asked why it was that there was a need for anyone to make a personal explanation. She refused to acknowledge, presumably, the most basic right that we all have—the right of freedom of speech, the right of freedom of expression.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot denied the legitimacy of a need to make a personal explanation which in itself when allowed resulted in Senator Evans conceding that indeed we had not filibustered, that the debate had been of a very high calibre and that there were a number of very constructive contributions. So let us not have the humbug. Let us not pretend that anyone has a mortgage on virtue. We maintain that there was a better way. The government had the chance and blew it. We, as citizens of Australia, will all have to live with the consequences for a very long time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have a Native Title Bill which is, in effect, unworkable. We are putting at risk 160,000 direct jobs and 470,000 indirect jobs in the mining industry—that is all at risk. We are putting at risk $37 billion in export earnings, $20 billion in mining earnings and $17 billion in agricultural earnings. That has been the sum total of the debate that has been going on now for some eight or nine days; the days have merged into each another as we have debated this through till midnight and then resumed at 9 o'clock in the morning. That is where we are at the moment.

PARA.TAB: We are going establish a land fund to help the Aborigines who will not be picked up by this legislation. No-one knows what that will cost or how that will fit into the government's deficit reduction strategy. How much will taxes be increased to pay for this? How is it all going to be paid for? What will be the cost on jobs? What is the cost on Kelty's regional development task force? He has identified that unemployment in regional areas is very high and will now go much higher. It will be much harder for Aborigines to get work in those areas—all those things will be the repercussions and the fall-out that we will go through to have this bill.

This bill will only make it worse for Australia. Already we have seen a lot of industry moving offshore, and the bill clearly has not resolved uncertainty. But the government now has to accept that there will have to be amendments. There will be problems with the mining and pastoral industries, and the government will now be obliged to bring in amendments that will hold those massive job creating and wealth creating industries in place.

This legislation will affect not only white Australians but also black Australians. The long debate has exploited the difficulties that we will see in the mining industry and the pastoral industry. Honourable senators have raised those issues and have pointed out to the government where the problems will lie.

I personally do not like the bill. I think it will be very harmful to Australia. The bill may benefit 12,000 Aborigines but it discriminates against the rest of Australia—16 million Australians will not pick up anything from this bill. But, ultimately, the numbers are there for the bill to go through, and I can count that.

The Australian people will have to accept the bill if they accept parliamentary democracy in Australia. Until the government is changed and the numbers in the Senate fall our way, it is a matter of fact that the bill will be law. In conclusion, I would like to wish the Aborigines who have come down to see this bill go through all the best.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that we have had to have some negativity at the end of this historic debate tonight on the Native Title Bill. It is a pity that we did not have cross-party support for something so important for Australia's future. The fact is that tonight a majority of the Australian parliament has done a wonderful, historic thing for indigenous Australians and for Australia itself. Although delivered 205 years late, we have delivered just a modicum of justice to indigenous Australians. We have put aside the myth of terra nullius. We have said at last that we are prepared to own our history.

PARA.TAB: One of the things surrounding this debate that I think we should look at is that of the process. The opposition said that it had no amendments and that we were all at fault because we had 99—or however many there were. The fact is that those amendments were the outcome of a constructed, negotiating process in which the opposition chose not to be involved. Those opposite cannot cope with this new process. They prefer to deal themselves out every single time.

The outcome of this process is a bill which has finely balanced the competing interests of Aboriginal Australians and those traditional interests of industry—interests which have been taken for granted and on which, as a result of the High Court judgment, we as a parliament had to make judgment in an attempt to get the balance right. That is what we have done in this legislation.

Apart from the many people who have already been mentioned this evening, I want to single out three people who have been incredibly helpful to the Australian Democrats in this long and complicated process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gareth.

—No, Senator Vanstone has got it the wrong way round; I was very helpful to Senator Evans. The three people I want to thank are: Mr Ron Castan QC, Ms Isabelle Meyer on my staff and Ms Kathy Whimp. Their legal advice was absolutely invaluable.
—What about Sid Spindler?

—My colleague Senator Spindler knows that I am incredibly grateful to him for the time he spent in the chamber on my behalf. I have spent a lot of my life working for the Aboriginal cause—for the struggle, as we call it. I am very moved that I have ended up in the federal parliament playing a role and casting a vote to bring about justice for Aboriginal Australians whom I honour with my vote this evening.
—You don't render justice; the High Court does.
—Could Senator Vanstone be positive for one minute?
—This is not your gift; it is the High Court's.

—My vote is my gift. I choose to exercise it in this meaningful way on behalf of all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Queensland whom I represent. I will continue to work relentlessly for meaningful reconciliation and constitutional change, which is the next step in the recognition of the High Court judgment. This reconciliation process, which we are about to embark upon as a nation, will be a process in which Aboriginal leadership will play a role of continuing and dynamic significance. That is one of the enduring legacies of what has surrounded the native title debate. Politics does have some rewards and being here tonight for this historic vote is one of those rewards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill 1993, having been substantially amended by the Senate, is now a piece of legislation that the Greens (WA) can support. Our position on this legislation has always been that it should support and build on the positive decision of the High Court in Mabo and others v. Queensland, 1992. Any legislation arising from that decision should be of benefit to Australia's indigenous people and, as a bottom line, should not directly harm the present position of Aboriginal people, nor should it inhibit their capacity in the future to seek further development of their native title rights.

PARA.TAB: The bill, as presented to and passed by the House of Representatives, fell well short of that aim. But now, with the major amendments that have been negotiated and passed during the committee stage, the bill has been modified from the original aims that we believe were being expressed. First and foremost it seemed a bill for every other vested interest in this country before Aboriginal rights were addressed. I regard the article in the Australian of 11 October 1993 as a prophetic one. In that article, Professor Henry Reynolds said:

A principal objective of the Bill is to validate all existing titles, to provide up-front statutory security for every conceivable interest. No one, it seems, is forgotten—owners, lessees, licensees, holders of interests in minerals/water . . . and anyone else whose interests might in any way be infringed by native title.

SPEECH.PARA: That was what it could have been. I believe that it has now changed because some restraints have been applied to that and some respect has been achieved for the traditional rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. As Henry Reynolds says in his article, there could have been a truly even-handed approach which could have had a very different outcome—even from this piece of legislation that we are passing here tonight. The article continues:

The Federal Government, as Professor Garth Nettheim suggested some time ago, could have declared that all recent Crown land with resident Aborigines could be presumed to be held under native title. The onus would then have fallen on the Crown to prove the contrary, to establish if, when and how, extinguishment had taken place. Such an approach would have been fully in the spirit of the High Court's Mabo judgment.

The process has been very different. The Greens (WA) would have liked to have seen the approach to a native title bill starting with communication with the elders of the communities around Australia. Robert Bropho of the Nyungah circle of Elders has maintained and insisted all along that there will be no harmony and success if the two laws do not agree with one another. That need for consultation is ever present and needs to be addressed by the committee that will be an outcome of this bill. Regional agreements and better consultation processes are possible, and I urge that we do that.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to remind ourselves, as we consider the final stage of this legislation, of the history of Australia since 1788. It is also important to ask ourselves at this time: what does this piece of legislation really mean; what do we hope to achieve from its passage; and, more importantly, where do we go from here?

Tonight, we must move on—some very gratefully. Tonight, we must take the next step on the continuing road towards justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Tonight, Senator Dee Margetts and I wish to pay tribute to all the people from all over the country who have brought us to this stage, for tonight is a night that we did not believe would occur. We did not believe that the government would have come so far towards meeting our concerns and the concerns expressed by representatives from indigenous organisations from all over Australia. That it has done so is a tribute to the dedication and commitment of the people—many of whom are present tonight in the gallery. We thank the Australian Democrats and some strong supporters from the Australian Labor Party. We pay tribute to Senator Gareth Evans for his effort in guiding this Senate through the complex procedural maze of the committee process.

Both Senator Margetts and I also pay tribute to the large number of Aboriginal people who have come from our state of Western Australia. We thank you for being here. Finally, I express appreciation towards the Aboriginal negotiators and the myriad people who trooped in and out of our offices, not to mention the dedicated if not courageous lawyers, and the ecumenical prayer group that met daily during this last few days. We thank you for the patience and persistence that you have had with us.

I especially remember those who did not want this bill to be passed but who did respect that the Greens would be trying to raise their concerns and make an effective input into this legislation. I here refer to the Miriuwung and Gajerrong Families Heritage and Land Council, the Nyungah Circle of Elders, with Robert Bropho, Yaluritja—Clarrie Isaacs, Mingeli Wanguri, and all the others.

The Greens' philosophy is that we must acknowledge the historical injustice that we have done in this country to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before reconciliation is possible. The world is moving towards recognition of indigenous people's contributions and culture and rights, which is part of the healing of the planet.

I conclude with a quote from Paul Behrendt, the Director of the Aboriginal Research and Resource Centre, himself an Aboriginal person, who gave a talk at the Martung Upah Indigenous Conference called, `A Just and Proper Settlement', which I regard as ironic. After I have completed my speech I will seek leave to table this document which relates to the history of our country from the perspective of the University of New South Wales Aboriginal Research and Resource Centre. Paul Behrendt said in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: A native Canadian once said that while governments will come and go, and court decisions will come and go native people will remain the same as we were before anybody else came here.

And so it is in this country. I do not know what the mix of the population will be in a hundred years time but I will give you a written guarantee that we are going to be here, and by not addressing the issues that affect contemporary Aboriginal society you will simply be bequeathing the problems to our grand children in much the same way that your grand parents left them to you.
It may then be fortuitous to mark Xavier Herbert's words when he said:

Until we give back to the black man some of what we have taken from him, and give it back in the same spirit that it was taken—without provisos or strings to snatch it back, we shall remain what we have always been, a people without a soul, not a nation, but a community of thieves.

Aboriginal people are not asking, nor have we ever asked for anything that isn't ours. We are not asking for anything over and above that which is available to, and is expected by every other member of the Australian community.

We simply seek those precious things that were projected by the Jesus that Europeans introduced to our people: a sense of understanding, a capacity for compassion and a will for justice. From this will flow a fundamental acknowledgment that has for so long been denied of our people, a respect for our dignity as human beings.
I seek leave to table that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one of us believed that this legislation did not involve deep questions of social justice, equity and certainty before the law. Whether this parliament has discharged its duty to examine this legislation in such a manner as to enhance the best interests of all Australians and not to do harm to the federal compact upon which the constitution is based, only time will tell. Whether we have done so in such a manner as to advance not only the social but also the economic wellbeing of all Australians, only time will tell. I believed, and have always believed, that it was necessary to address these measures against the need for a reconciliation amongst all peoples in this country.

PARA.TAB: No-one has a mortgage on morality in this place. As Senator Alston said, no-one has a mortgage on compassion in this place; no-one has a mortgage on social justice in this place. I believe all members of this parliament attempted, according to their own ideas about these principles, to address this measure in the best interests of all Australians.

But this parliament comes second place because it was the High Court that showed us the way. It was the Mabo No. 2 decision that showed us the way. That is really to the shame of the parliament. I stand here as a legislator. I do not agree that the laws of this country should be made by a court, whether it be the High Court or any other court. I believe we as the elected parliament should have had the foresight to see what needed to be done. We should have realised how the High Court was moving. In a celebrated 1983 case—which I prefer not to refer to at times, but I will do so on this occasion—Mr Justice Brennan had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The approval of the proposed law for the amendment—
that was the constitutional amendment—

was an affirmation of the will of the Australian people that the odious policies of oppression and neglect of Aboriginal citizens were to be at an end, and that the primary object of power is beneficial.
In that same decision, Mr Justice Deane had this to say:
. . . it became increasingly clear that Australia, as a nation, must be diminished until acceptable laws be enacted to mitigate the effect of past barbarism . . .

We should have realised how the High Court was moving. In fact, I suppose on a couple of occasions we attempted to do something about it. All honourable senators know that. But the parliament had to be almost dragged screaming to face reality because of a High Court decision. To me, that is shameful. To have acted sooner would have been the appropriate thing to do.

PARA.TAB: There has been some speculation in sections of the press as to how I would vote on this matter. There has been speculation as to how I would vote on a number of matters. In the 18 years that I have been here I have said something about almost everything. All that members of the press or honourable senators need to do is look up the Hansard to see what I have said. I remind the Senate, and anybody else who is interested, what I said on 23 August 1988 on the reconciliation motion that was proposed in the Senate at that time. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Meeting in this new place, it is fitting that we acknowledge the fullness of human history in this land. This motion will stand as a statement of our commitment to national and individual reconciliation with the descendants of those who have suffered dispossession and dispersal in the wake of European and other settlement in 1788. Among those descendants I am proud to name one as my son-in-law.

Much has been said about reconciliation, but we have not seen a great deal of reconciliation amongst us during this debate. At times we did. I must congratulate a number of those senators—Senator Ellison, Senator Alston amongst others—who have asked detailed questions of Senator Gareth Evans. I do not always congratulate Senator Evans, but on this occasion I think he has done a vigorous and sterling job.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senator—Robust.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not robust, thankfully, but a measured and sterling job.

PARA.TAB: I am coming to the stage now of deciding whether this bill—it is acknowledged that it is flawed—should be read a third time tonight. I believe that the bill needs amendment. I do not think anyone around this chamber does not acknowledge that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes, there is.

—I do not think there is. I believe that this measure should be read third time tonight. I will vote for that third reading because of my consistent approach and the need for this to be not only an act which has a beneficial effect for all Australians but also is a symbolic act of reconciliation in this year, the International Year of Indigenous People.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In just a few minutes, we will be voting to give the Native Title Bill 1993 its third reading, thereby concluding what has been the longest debate on any bill in the history of the Australian parliament. The previous record holder—not entirely coincidentally—was the 1989 ATSIC bill, which had a total of 39 hours and 5 minutes of debate. We passed that milestone around 9 o'clock this morning just after we began.

PARA.TAB: For the record, we spent 10 hours and 21 minutes on the second reading. According to my calculations, we spent 38 hours and 45 minutes on the committee stage, for a total of just over 49 hours. The guillotine procedure—one might want to exclude that—took nearly two hours. The third reading will now take 45 minutes. That totals 51 hours and 45 minutes.

A great many people have contributed to the outcome that has been achieved as a result of all this deliberation. I am delighted to see so many of them around the galleries tonight. First of all, there has been my ministerial colleagues. Leaving aside for the moment the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), I want to mention Frank Walker, Michael Lavarch, Robert Tickner, Duncan Kerr, Warren Snowdon, Michael Lee, Simon Crean and, in this chamber, Bob McMullan, Bob Collins and Nick Bolkus. I also want to mention Barney Cooney and those other senators who played such an extraordinary and productive role in leading the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs through the inquiry that occurred last week.

I would like to thank very warmly and very appreciatively the public servants who have contributed so much to this: Sandy Hollway, who lead the team, Robert Orr and Mike Dillon. They were the essential leaders of it. They gave me absolutely outstanding support over very many months of hard slog. They also gave me absolutely outstanding support in this chamber during the 38 hours and 45 minutes that I was on my feet in the committee stage debate. Without them, I would not have been anything like as half-way plausible as I might on many occasions have appeared to be.

There is then the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander negotiators, who have been so absolutely crucial to crafting this legislative product. Many of them are in the gallery tonight, and I am delighted to see them: Lois O'Donoghue, the chairperson of ATSIC; Noel Pearson; Marcia Langton from the Cape York Land Council; David Ross from the Central Land Council; Darryl Pearce from the Northern Land Council; and from the Kimberley Land Council, Darryl Cronin and Peter Yu.

There have been the lawyers. The lawyers do not always get the gratitude, attention and the thanks they deserve, and rightly so. Ron Castan QC, after all, almost single-handedly set this whole affair going with his advocacy in the Mabo case. Kathy Whimp, who has been mentioned earlier tonight, has worked with the Democrats. I see that Father Frank Brennan is in the gallery. He has been a phenomenal contributor to the Aboriginal cause over so many years. All of them played an absolutely major role.

As to other parliamentary colleagues, I owe a great debt of gratitude to the Greens for finally coming aboard in the way they did. As readers of this morning's Canberra Times may guess, it was not always as easy a relationship and as easy an outcome as some on the other side seem to assume.

I would like to thank Cheryl Kernot. She is right in saying that she, through her leadership of the Australian Democrats, contributed to this result. It was not an ordinary, run of the mill, routine political contribution from Cheryl Kernot as leader of the Democrats. Throughout, it was an outstandingly constructive and thoughtful one from someone genuinely committed to the public interest and not just to political point scoring. That is something I very much appreciate in this place; we do not see enough of it.

There is one politician whose contribution to this whole exercise gigantically exceeds that of everyone else, and I make no partisan point when I say that is the Prime Minister, Paul Keating. It was Paul Keating who saw, starkly and clearly, the huge issue of principle, of social justice and basic human decency that was involved in the Mabo case. It was Paul Keating who saw that we were diminished—to use the phrase that Senator Harradine quoted from the courts—by that whole unhappy history. It was Paul Keating who saw the opportunity for a process of national reconciliation by consolidating and implementing into Australian law the Mabo legislation.

It was the Prime Minister who drove the process of consultation that occurred so relentlessly over the last 12 months through endless meetings at an endless series of locations with an endless number of groups and individuals. It was Paul Keating, as Prime Minister, who immersed himself in the detail of this legislative exercise to a greater extent than any Prime Minister has ever done on any single issue of which I am aware—certainly, that I have ever witnessed. It was Paul Keating who was not deterred by the cynicism, scepticism, ribaldry, hostility and indifference expressed by so many people on so many occasions about this issue.

The Prime Minister drove this process and by his leadership he produced a bill which, despite all its complexity, has four simple, clean themes running through it, which still emerge, after all this process, as starkly, as cleanly, as simply and as compellingly as they did on the first day they were conceived. They are the themes of: ungrudging and unambiguous recognition and protection of native title; provision for clear and certain validation of past acts, including grants and laws if they have been invalidated because of the existence of native title; a just and practical regime governing future grants and acts of native title; and rigorous, specialised and accessible tribunal and court processes for determining claims to native title for negotiation and decisions on proposed grants out of native title land.

I think that Prime Minister Keating can be very proud of his achievement. It is an historic one. It is an enormous, landmark achievement for a cause which he made very much his own, and one for which, I believe, he and his government will be remembered for generations.

Above all, this is a landmark achievement, and one that I hope will also be recognised as such, and very proudly so, by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people here in this gallery and across this country. We do owe our indigenous peoples, our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander fellow Australians, a huge debt for the destruction and dispossession that we non-Aboriginal Australians wreaked for over 200 years of Australian history. I hope that, by passage of this legislation tonight, we have repaid just a little of that debt.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993SOCIAL SECURITY (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was hoped there would be some government amendments tonight but, unfortunately, shortly after 9 o'clock the government decided it was not going to proceed with them.
—They reneged on you—a deal done outside and they reneged on you.

—I make no apology whatsoever for attempting to improve the lot of rural families by negotiating with the government to try to increase the assets test for the additional family payments. All was looking promising—
—I wish the gallery was still here to hear this, Meg.
—Thank you. I make absolutely no apology whatsoever for trying to improve the situation for farm families. In this case it was not successful but that does not mean I shall not keep trying.
—But the gallery should be here to see how the government has behaved towards you this time.

—It was more than a little disappointing that this has happened right at the very end of the process, when we had a signed undertaking from the minister. We were looking at a new deal for farm families. We were looking at an increase in the amount so that there would be no loss. Indeed, we were looking at an increase of over $4 a week to make up the amount that moving from Austudy back to the additional family payment would have meant to families as well as a guardianship allowance and rent assistance available for single parents. The only reason given to me was that, apparently when the government had redone its sums, it found that sufficient savings were not going to be made. Therefore, we have no amendments before us tonight. The reason we delayed was that we were hoping that some amendments would be made. We need now to proceed quickly. The Democrats will be supporting the move to make sure that 16-year-olds stay in Austudy. In other words, we will be supporting the status quo.
—My running sheet tells me that Senator Woodley has two amendments to clause 2—or are they to the clauses immediately following clause 2?
—We are not proceeding with those.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clause 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is the clause stand as printed. Just so that we can make it clear that there are no typographical misunderstandings, I also have circulated government amendment 4 which I take it is not going to be proceeded with.
—We are not proceeding with it.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 88 and 89—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I have an indication of a government amendment.
—We are not proceeding with that.
—Amendment No. 7 stands in the name of the opposition on this clause.
—So that I am clear, when I am in the chair, I draw a distinction between an affirmative clause and opposing a clause. Are you opposing the clause?

—We are opposing the clauses. In the item circulated in my name, we indicated that we would be opposing the clauses. I would like to speak to that. We do not have an amendment; we are opposing the clauses. I am quite sad that the gallery is empty because if it were not, the members of the public who were here clapping this government would hear exactly what had happened to the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: We are debating these clauses on what is still Thursday in this Alice in Wonderland world—it is really 10 past 12 on Wednesday morning outside this place. This matter could have been debated when we were debating the whole bill. But, no, it was deferred. Why was it deferred? Senator Kernot talked to the gallery tonight about the new age of consultation. She said to the coalition, `What you need to do is be part of this new consultation process and you can negotiate and debate with us'.

Senator Lees has been stung badly by that new consultation process. I can understand why she feels angry. I feel angry on her behalf. She got a written agreement. She came to me and she said, `Here, I've got this written signed agreement'. I was reasonable. I said, `If that's the case and you want to move some amendments relating to that or if the government says it's going to move some amendments, we'll defer that item'. We deferred it. But what happened? The government did the dirty on her, frankly.

The reason we were going to oppose the amendment if the government brought it in, was that we were concerned that we did not know in detail who the winners and losers would be and we also did not know what the costing would be. I was going to ask in the committee stage debate on that amendment what the details were of the breakdowns of the costings. Obviously, the government had not done that before it did the deal with Senator Lees, because when the government went and did it, it backed out on her. The people in the gallery were clapping this government only a few minutes ago for some deals that were done on amendments. Suddenly we find another deal that was done, and the government backed out of it. I feel that is not the way to do business in this place—to sign an agreement telling somebody that you will move amendments and then pull out.

I hope Senator Lees has learnt her lesson. That is not the way we do business with the Democrats. We like to debate here in the chamber and have it out in the open, which is where the debate should be going on, not outside in the back rooms, which was what was going on. Clause 2 was brought in here and I did not know what was going on. It made me look like a bit of a goose. I did not know what was going on because there was a little deal being done between the Democrats and the government; a written, signed statement was being cooked up. It fell through. I am not the goose. There are a number of geese around this place and I do not happen to be one of them. I think it is appalling.

Clauses 88 and 89 would save the government about $27 million a year when fully implemented and would make about 75 per cent of people worse off than if the present system of Austudy for eligible 16-year-olds were kept in place. This is because of lower income and asset test thresholds that apply to family payment. This is another measure—and I am sorry the people in the gallery have gone—that the Australian public was not told about before the last election. It is another underhand measure that the government did not foreshadow. But we have got used to that. In fact, almost everything that I have got up and spoken on on social security in the last half of this session has been things that the government did not tell the public about, unless it was good news.

We have constantly had these tightening of measures, but when we said we were going to tighten things, we were the baddies; we were the ones who did not care about people, just as the government tried to portray tonight. I found the suggestion that I do not care about justice for Aborigines totally offensive. We have more Aborigines dying in childbirth now than we had in 1973. Senator Gareth Evans stood here pontificating about what happened tonight—Aborigines have an incredible incidence of diabetes, they are glue sniffing and alcoholism takes their lives at a very early age, and the government talks to me about justice. It is just unbelievable. Those opposite did the same thing during the election campaign—the coalition did not care. I find that offensive too.

We cared enough to tell the Australian public the truth, and we will live by that. I do not have any concern that we told the truth. Maybe we are not on that side of the chamber, but we did not lie our way into government—we told the truth. The Democrats might find when we are in government after the next election that we will tell the truth and we will not do deals, as has happened tonight, and pull out on them. We will be straight. The Democrats got done, just like the public got done at the last election.

This measure would be particularly hard on low to middle income families. For example, a family with an income of $27,000 and one dependent child would lose over $52 a fortnight. The measure is regressive and it also would have a particularly harsh impact on rural families. The government's rationale for the change is that there has been an increase in school retention rates so it is no longer considered appropriate to provide Austudy to 16-year-old students. But it must be remembered that much of this increased retention rate is due to the adverse employment climate for young people under this government's policies, particularly young people in regional and rural areas where we see unemployment amongst young people at astronomical levels.

If one goes, as I do, to regional Victoria, one will see the numbers of young people who are desperate to get jobs and their families who are desperate because they have not got jobs. Many of these people are staying on at school. The government argues about its increased retention rate. Much of that is to do with the fact that young people cannot find employment. We will not be supporting these two clauses. I believe the Democrats will be supporting us on this. I say again that they got diddled, just like the Australian public, because they were not told about this measure that the government was going to bring in after the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the opposition in opposing these clauses. I just want to make a short comment on the business of deals. As a newcomer to this parliament, I do not find negotiating with people as something to be despised.
—No, but you let other people in on it.
—Just a moment, Senator Patterson; I have not finished.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope Senator Panizza listens to what I am about to say. I do not find negotiation to be a bad process at all. For example, it was interesting to note that, in the middle of the negotiations with the staff from the Department of Social Security, there was a phone call to my office. That person said he could not continue to negotiate any further with me because he had just received a call from the opposition, which might offer him a better deal. He went round, talked to the opposition and came back afterwards. So all of us are involved in negotiations. I think that is a very good process. I really do not belittle it. Sometimes it works—
—Name the officers who said that.
—I am making a statement. I do not have to put on record the names of public servants. That is not what this is about.
—That is not the way they behave.

—I am afraid that is exactly what happened on this occasion, Senator Patterson. I am really saying that negotiations take place all the time. That is how this place ought to operate. If we can, as Senator Lees has said, get a better deal for farm families, I will go to the end of the earth to do that. If I do not get the deal this time, I will not give up; I will negotiate again. In the end the objective is that we get a better deal for farm families—and for all families in Australia. Surely we will commit ourselves to whatever process that takes, as long as we retain our integrity.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I accept that Senator Lees has entered into these discussions on the social security legislation in good faith and with integrity. I regret that we cannot proceed with the arrangement we entered into. I reject the implication of some of Senator Patterson's assertions that we `did the dirty' and `diddled' on the deal. The discussions on the agreement were entered into in good faith. It is very common to have quite lengthy discussions on a variety of matters in this place. That is not unusual. I do not think anything in particular is wrong with that at all. Indeed, the very nature of this place is designed to encourage that process.

PARA.TAB: The government proposed in the budget the measure that we are considering tonight in order to bring the arrangements for 16-year-old secondary students more in line with the conditions applying to younger children in the family payments system. These conditions include payment to the mother; continued access as appropriate to guardians allowance; rent assistance; the home child-care allowance; and a tighter income and assets test, with a reduced poverty trap problem, where a number of children are present. We have sought to negotiate the outcome with both the opposition and the minor parties, but we have been unable to come to a satisfactory solution on the arrangements that protect the bulk of the budgetary savings, which are estimated to be $24.6 million in 1996-97.

The Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was prepared to meet some of the concerns expressed about this measure, such as the reduction in the maximum rate of payment comparable to Austudy and the distinction between 16- and 17-year-olds. However, I am advised that the opposition parties pressed further amendments. Those amendments largely erode any of the budget savings that we have anticipated. While not objecting to those amendments in principle—I understand but do not agree with the proposals of the opposition and the Democrats—the minister has decided that that approach must be considered in the budget context. As a consequence, both the initial proposal and the other issues that have been raised in the negotiations will be reconsidered in the forthcoming budget.

It is true that on Saturday the Minister for Social Security came to an arrangement with the Democrats that would allow a modified version of this proposal to proceed. However, the subsequent 72 hours have given us a chance to look very closely at the costings and it appears that they are to the disadvantage of the budgetary process and that is why we have deferred it to the incoming budget. I thank Senator Patterson for most of her contribution, although I do reject the continual assertions about lies in the last election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Patterson can laugh. I accept her bona fides on these issues. I suggest she try to convince her party of the bona fides and attempt to present it in a better balanced policy way than she did at the last election, and she might have some better success in future. I thank Senator Lees.
