TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the Greek annexation of 51 per cent of the territory of Macedonia in 1913: (a) has the Greek Government, since that time, practised a policy of detentionalisation and assimilation of the Macedonian people; (b) has this policy included the denial of such basic rights as freedom of religion, freedom to speak and be educated in the Macedonian language and freedom of cultural expression; and (c) has the Australian Government made representations about these issues, and with what response.

(2) With reference to human rights organisations, including Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch, and newspapers such as the Times and the Economist which have recently published reports which are highly critical of Greece's continuing suppression of freedom of expression, does the Government's own monitoring of the situation agree with concerns raised by these organisations; if so, what is its response.

(3) With reference to the conclusion of the Helsinki Watch report that "Friends of Greece around the world—and everyone concerned about freedom of expression—ought to speak up and tell the country's misguided Government to pursue its Macedonian policy through persuasion, not coercion": (a) does the Government agree with this conclusion; (b) has the Government made representations to the Greek Government in these terms and what has been the response; and (c) what influence can the Australian Government exercise with its Greek counterparts.

(4) With reference to the Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch reports which specifically mention 20 cases in which ethnic Macedonians and their friends are being charged through the Greek legal system for having done nothing more than express opinions that differ from those of the Greek Government, with 15 of these cases still being current, is the Australian Government aware of the identity of these 15 people and is it prepared to exercise such influence as it is able to bring to bear on the Greek Government with a view to having the charges dropped and the peoples' rights to freedom of expression restored.

(5) Can assurances be given that the Australian Government will use such forums as are made available through the United Nations (UNHRC, the Conferences on Human Rights and the General Assembly) to raise the issue of the Greek Government's denial of basic human rights to ethnic Macedonians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The question of sovereign rights over the area known as Macedonia is a long-running and complex one reflecting the intricacies of various rivalries, conflicts and tensions which have taken place in the Balkans. The "Macedonia" in question that existed before the 1912-1913 Balkan wars was an Ottoman Province with a heterogeneous population, and with Slavs probably comprising the largest single element. The 51 per cent acquired by Greece, ie Aegean Macedonia, was ceded to it in the 1913 Treaty of Bucharest: (a) The term "Macedonian people" is subject to very wide interpretation by the countries and communities of the region. The Greek Government regards the Macedonian people as people from the region of Macedonia in Northern Greece. The Greek authorities deny that these people are systematically detained and, moreover, that the question of assimilation is not relevant as they do not recognise the existence of a "Macedonian minority". The only minority that Greece formally recognises is a "Muslim minority". (b) Freedom of speech and of the press is provided for in the Greek constitution, and is respected in practice, but there are notable exceptions. Greek law prohibits "exposing the friendly relations of the Greek state with foreign states to danger of disturbance," "spreading false information and rumours liable to create concern and fear among citizens and cause disturbance in the country's international relations" and "inciting citizens into rivalry and division, leading to disturbance of the peace". This law has been enforced on a number of occasions with respect to Macedonian issues. Organisations of Greek citizens of Slavic (Macedonian) origin are not allowed to use the word "Macedonian" in their names. Open performances of Slavic dances and the speaking of the Slavic language have also been discouraged. Education in Greece is carried out in the Greek language with the exception of that relating to the "Muslim Minority" which have the right to Turkish language education. (c) The Australian Government monitors the human rights situation in Greece through the Australian Embassy in Athens and has made representations to the Greek Government about individual cases of human rights concern including about Greek citizens of Macedonian origin.

(2) and (3) The Australian Government's assessment of the human rights situation in Greece is in general accordance with that put forward by reputable human rights non-government organisations such as Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch. As stated above, the Australian Government has made representations to the Greek authorities on individual cases of human rights concern. Moreover, the Australian Government would anticipate that the Greek Government would take note of representations made by Australia or other members of the international community concerning allegations that Greece was in breach of its international human rights obligations.

(4) As to the 20 cases of ethnic Macedonians being charged through the Greek legal system for having expressed opinions that differ from those of the Greek Government referred to in the Amnesty International and Helsinki Watch reports, the Australian Government has been aware of a number of cases and has made specific representations in relation to Mr Sideropoulos and Mr Bulis. The Australian Embassy in Athens has been following their cases closely. Mr Sideropoulos's case has been raised with the Greek Foreign Minister. The information gathered on these cases by the Embassy is consistent with the Helsinki Watch and Amnesty International Reports. The latest information we have on their situation is that the two men were convicted on 1 April 1993 and sentenced to five months' imprisonment. However, these sentences were suspended on appeal and they were released.

(5) There is no indication of international support for raising the issue of Greece's "Macedonian minority" in international human rights forums. The Australian Government will, however, continue to monitor the situation and, as appropriate, make representations to the Greek Government on issues of concern.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Asian Development Bank: Coal Project in Philippines

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Asian Development Bank and the proposed development project of a coal-fired power plant at Masinloc on the island of Luzon in the Philippines:
(1) Has this proposal been approved for funding by the Asian Development Bank.
(2) Does the local community at Masinloc accept the need for the establishment of a power plant in their region.
(3) Has the proposal conformed with all Asian Development Bank guidelines, including the requirement that all development projects be socially acceptable to the local community.
(4) Has the Bank conducted a cost-benefit analysis which has taken into account the social and environment costs of such a development.
(5) What alternative sites has the Asian Development Bank considered for the proposed power plant.
(6) Does Australia's representative on the Board of the Asian Development Bank agree with the proposed development project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. On 30 October 1990 the Board of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a loan of $US200 million for the Masinloc coal-fired power project.

(2) Yes. As provided for in the loan agreement between the ADB and the National Power Corporation (NPC), the NPC entered into an agreement with the local community in which the local community representatives indicated their acceptance of the power plant. The Philippine Government was also party to this agreement which provides for financial assistance equivalent to about $A14 million from the NPC to the local community during the building and operation of the power plant. This assistance is to be used for local infrastructure projects and for programs such as an artificial reef, a marine sanctuary, livelihood assistance, mango tree replanting, watershed reforestation, a local health clinic, water supply upgrading, training and scholarships, vehicles and boats, a feasibility study of mango processing and an environmental guarantee fund.
(3) Yes. In particular, the ADB is satisfied—
(a) that the project is an integral part of the optimum long-term solution to current serious power shortages in the Philippines;
(b) that the design of the power plant and the accompanying environmental measures are such that the project will be environmentally acceptable; and
(c) that it is socially acceptable to the local community.

(4) A cost-benefit analysis, taking into account economic, social and environmental costs and benefits of the project, was made by consultants engaged by the Philippine Government and working to ADB guidelines.
(5) In addition to Masinloc, two other sites were considered for the power station: San Juan in Batangas and Limay in Bataan.
(6) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 9 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does Worksafe Australia review safe exposure levels of chemicals used in the workplace.
(2) Does Worksafe Australia regard schools as workplaces.

(3) Did Worksafe Australia, in April 1992, acknowledge receipt of a nomination of Ethylene Glycol Mono Butyl Ether as a Priority Existing Chemical from the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union; if so, why has the chemical not yet been reviewed and when will it be reviewed.
(4) How many chemicals are reviewed each year with respect to safe exposure levels by Worksafe Australia.

(5) Is the Chairman of Worksafe Australia also the Chief Executive of Du Pont Chemicals Australia; if so, does this dual role present the possibility of a conflict of interest in relation to setting priorities for the assessment of existing chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Worksafe Australia sets occupational exposure standards for workplace chemicals. These exposure standards are then adopted by the State and Territory jurisdictions.
(2) Yes. It is a matter for individual State and Territory jurisdictions to ensure that schools are covered in their relevant occupational health and safety legislation.

(3) Yes. Worksafe Australia received 78 nominations for priority existing chemicals (PECs) during the public nomination phase in 1992, including the nomination of Ethylene Glycol Monobutyl Ether (also known as EGMBE or 2-butoxyethanol) by the Federated Miscellaneous Workers' Union (FMWU, now known as the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers' Union).

The assessment of priority existing chemicals (PECs) is carried out under the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989. The PEC program is run on a cost-recovery basis, with the business plan identifying a maximum of six PECs to be assessed each year. A group of independent experts reviews information on the nominated chemicals against agreed criteria, helping to establish priorities for assessment. To date, other chemicals have had a higher priority for assessment than EGMBE.

Worksafe Australia is currently summarising the information available about EGMBE to assist in determining its priority for assessment in future. This information will be made available to the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Union to help meet its concerns.

(4) Apart from the chemicals assessed under the PEC program, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission establishes exposure standards on a priority basis through its Standards Development Standing Committee. Exposure and health effects' information on about 12 chemicals each year is examined to decide whether an exposure standard needs to be established or revised. Each proposal for an exposure standard includes a three-month period for public comment.

(5) Yes. The Chairman has no conflict of interest in relation to the setting of priorities for assessment of existing chemicals. Recommendations on the priorities for assessment of existing chemicals are made directly to the Minister for Industrial Relations by the Director, Chemicals Notification and Assessment, a statutory office holder under the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989. The Chairman of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has no statutory role under this Act.
The recommendations are based on independent advice. Only the Minister for Industrial Relations can declare a particular chemical to be assessed as a PEC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1993 :

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australia House, London:
(1) What progress has been made in the planning to refurbish and maintain this major asset.
(2) What was the total budget in the 1992-93 financial year for: (a) maintenance and repair; and (b) public information and display.
(3) What progress is being made to upgrade the library and reading room to make for easier public access and dissemination of information.
(4) When will news services be improved to ensure access to up-to-date material.
(5) Have there been any overtures to Australian media and transport organisations to facilitate speedier delivery of newspapers.
(6) Is there a long-term strategy in place for better utilisation of space at Australia House, that is, performance, display and educational space.
(7) What links have been established between the Australia High Commission and the Commonwealth Centre for Australian Studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A detailed assessment of Australia House has been undertaken. A proposal for a comprehensive refurbishment program will be considered by the Government in the context of the 1994/95 New Policy Proposals:
a major upgrade of mechanical and electrical services;
a more efficient use of the building by rationalising existing space used by Commonwealth departments;
consolidation of some 2,000m(2) of resultant surplus space for potential use by Commonwealth and State authorities;
rationalisation of recurring operational and maintenance costs.
(2)(a) The total budget in the 1992/93 financial year for maintenance and repairs of Australia House was $A540,030.

(b) The total budget allocated by Overseas Information Branch to London in the 1992/93 financial year for public information and display activities was $A30,000. These funds were used for the production of publications and for public affairs support activities such as photography and media monitoring. The publications produced are distributed to target groups such as business, investment, educational and cultural contacts and are not put on display to be freely available to the public at large. In addition, London also would be provided with a range of public affairs print, radio and TV/video material produced by the Overseas Information Branch in Canberra for promoting Australia abroad.

During 1992/93 Department of Arts and Administrative Services also provided #STG10,000 (@ $A22,727) for the taking of architectural photographs of the building and the production of a booklet commemorating the 75th anniversary of the opening of Australia House. This also is being distributed to target groups.

(3) As part of the re-organisation of the public affairs area of the High Commission and following a review of functions, it has been decided to close down the library and to donate the books to the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies, where they will be put under the control of full-time librarians and be more accessible to the public than at present. Insofar as building works are concerned, there is no current proposal to upgrade or alter the existing arrangements for access to the reading area.

(4) The main reception room at Australia House is used as a newspaper reading facility from Monday to Friday when not required for other purposes. There are no funds for the provision of newspapers solely for public use, and the newspapers obtained from Australia by the High Commission for official purposes are subsequently made available in the reading area as a service to Australians visiting London. It is acknowledged that these newspapers are sometimes out of date. However the High Commission believes that they provide a useful complement to other sources of Australian news through the two weekly and two monthly commercial Australian interest periodicals now provided free in London. A cable news summary is also provided daily in the reading area by the High Commission, and some Australian publishers supply newspapers on a complimentary basis for the reading area.
(5) No. A set of major Australian newspapers for official use in the High Commission are dispatched by the Department twice weekly. (See also answer to question 4).

(6) The long-term policy for using the space available for performance, display and educational purposes at Australia House calls for maximum effective use of the available space, including reception rooms, within the limitations imposed by resources and security requirements. During any year a significant number of receptions, seminars and recitals are held at Australia House. The facilities are also made available to Australian-interest organisations on request for any event which furthers Australian interests, provided the organisers are prepared to comply with security requirements and meet the additional resource costs involved.

(7) The Australian Studies Centre in London was established in 1982 within the Institute for Commonwealth Studies of the University of London with funding from the Australian Government. In July 1988, the Menzies Memorial Foundation took over responsibility for the funding of the normal operations of the Centre which was renamed the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies.

The Centre, located in Russell Square in central London is responsible for a program of teaching, postgraduate seminars, public lectures, research and conferences, scholarships and publications with the aim of promoting a deeper understanding in Britain and Europe of Australia's culture and role in the world, and in particular to encourage Australian studies in European higher education.
The High Commission has frequent contact with the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies and the Deputy High Commissioner is an ex officio member of the Board of Management.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australia House, London
(1) What progress has been made in the planning to refurbish and maintain this major asset.
(2) What was the total budget in the 1992-93 financial year for: (a) maintenance and repair; and (b) public information and display.
(3) What progress is being made to upgrade the library and reading room to make for easier public access and dissemination of information.
(4) When will news services be improved to ensure access to up-to-date material.
(5) Have there been any overtures to Australian media and transport organisations to facilitate speedier delivery of newspapers.
(6) Is there a long-term strategy in place for better utilisation of space at Australia House, that is, performance, display and educational space.
(7) What links have been established between the Australian High Commission and the Commonwealth Centre for Australian Studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A detailed assessment of Australia House has been undertaken. A proposal for a comprehensive refurbishment program will be considered by the Government in the context of the 1994/95 New Policy Proposals and includes:
a major upgrade of mechanical and electrical services;
a more efficient use of the building by rationalising existing space used by Commonwealth departments;
consolidation of some 2,000m(2) of resultant surplus space for potential use by Commonwealth and State authorities;
rationalisation of recurring operational and maintenance costs.
(2) (a) The total budget in the 1992/93 financial year for maintenance and repairs of Australia House was $A540,030.

(b) The total budget allocated by Overseas Information Branch to London in the 1992/93 financial year for public information and display activities was $A30,000. These funds were used for the production of publications and for public affairs support activities such as photography and media monitoring. The publications produced are distributed to target groups such as business, investment, educational and cultural contacts and are not put on display to be freely available to the public at large. In addition, London also would be provided with a range of public affairs print, radio and TV/video material produced by the Overseas Information Branch in Canberra for promoting Australia abroad.

During 1992/93 the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services provided #STG10,000 (@$A22,727) for the taking of architectural photographs of the building and the production of a booklet commemorating the 75th anniversary of the opening of Australia House. This also is being distributed to target groups.

(3) As part of the re-organisation of the public affairs area of the High Commission and following a review of functions, it has been decided to close down the library and to donate the books to the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies, where they will be put under the control of full-time librarians and be more accessible to the public than at present. Insofar as building works are concerned, there is no current proposal to upgrade or alter the existing arrangements for access to the reading room.

(4) The main reception room at Australia House is used as a newspaper reading facility from Monday to Friday when not required for other purposes. There are no funds for the provision of newspapers solely for public use, and the newspapers obtained from Australia by the High Commission for official purposes are subsequently made available in the reading room as a service to Australians visiting London. It is acknowledged that these newspapers are sometimes out of date. However the High Commission believes that they provide a useful complement to other sources of Australian news through the two weekly and two monthly commercial Australian interest periodicals now provided free in London. A cable news summary is also provided daily in the reading room by the High Commission, and some Australian publishers supply newspapers on a complimentary basis for the reading area.
(5) No. A set of major Australian newspapers for official use in the High Commission are dispatched by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade twice weekly. (See also answer to question 4).

(6) The long term strategy for using the space available for performance, display and educational purposes at Australia House calls for maximum effective use of the available space, including reception rooms, within the limitations imposed by resources and security requirements. During any year a significant number of receptions, seminars and recitals are held at Australia House. The facilities are also made available to Australian-interest organisations on request for any event which furthers Australian interests, provided the organisers are prepared to comply with security requirements and meet the additional resource costs involved.

(7) The Australian Studies Centre in London was established in 1982 within the Institute for Commonwealth Studies of the University of London with funding from the Australian Government. In July 1988, the Menzies Memorial Foundation took over responsibility for the funding of the normal operations of the Centre which was renamed the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies.

The Centre, located in Russell Square in central London is responsible for a program of teaching, postgraduate seminars, public lectures, research and conferences, scholarships and publications with the aim of promoting a deeper understanding in Britain and Europe of Australia's culture and role in the world, and in particular to encourage Australian studies in European higher education.
The High Commission has frequent contact with the Sir Robert Menzies Centre for Australian Studies and the Deputy High Commissioner is an ex officio member of the Board of Management.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answers to questions on notice nos 949, 1239, and 1189 (House of Representatives Hansard, 8 October 1991, p. 1481; 6 November 1991, p. 2516; 10 November 1992, pp 3071, 3074) concerning the bombing of the Hilton Hotel in Sydney in 1978, and the Attorney-General's commitment to cooperate with any inquiry into the bombing which the NSW Government or Parliament may establish `subject to the need to ensure that national security considerations are not compromised', does the Commonwealth Government or its agencies or departments hold any information which would therefore be excluded from such an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: As advised on 10 November 1992 in answer to Question 1239, the Government will co-operate fully with any inquiry the Government of New South Wales may establish subject to the need to ensure that national security considerations are not compromised. The Government is confident that suitable arrangements could be devised for this purpose. For example, in 1984, appropriate arrangements were put in place under which sensitive Commonwealth information was given to the inquiry conducted under section 475 of the Crimes Act 1900 (NSW) by Mr Justice Wood. Those arrangements allowed the Commonwealth to assist the Wood inquiry while ensuring that the confidentiality of the information disclosed was adequately protected.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) tell off-airport car rental operators that if they had not signed a contract to pick up pre-booked clients by 15 November 1993 they would have their authority to trade on the airport revoked.

(2) In a recent report, did the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) state that off-airport rental car operators who meet pre-booked customers at airports do not conduct business at airports; if so, then on what grounds do off-airport car rental operators need an authority to trade to pick up pre-booked clients at airport terminals.
(3) What is the difference between car rental operators meeting pre-booked clients and accommodation providers meeting pre-booked guests, or tour operators meeting pre-booked clients.
(4) Who has determined that the Alternative A contract as proposed by the FAC will be implemented: the PSA, the Trade Practices Commission or the FAC itself.
(5) Is it a fact, as suggested by the PSA, that `any charge levied for airport access simply reflects the FAC's market power'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Off-airport car rental operators were granted an authority to trade on the airport to 31 October 1993. They were advised that if they wished to trade on the airport after that date they would need to apply for and be granted an authority to trade in accordance with the Federal Airports Corporation National Car Rental Policy of April 1993.

An advertisement was placed in the "Hobart Mercury" on 30 October 1993, advising car rental operators that if they wished to operate from Hobart or Launceston Airports, they "must enter into an agreement with the Corporation no later than 15 November 1993. From that date any operator without such an agreement will not be allowed to trade on these airports".

(2) The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) in its report on the `Inquiry into the Aeronautical and Non-Aeronautical Charges of the Federal Airports Corporation' stated under the heading `Off-Airport Car Rentals': "Contracts for renting motor vehicles are not negotiated at airports; that is, no business is conducted at the airports".

While it may be questioned whether car rental operators are conducting business on airports, without doubt a service is being provided. Federal Airports By-Laws provide that for any person or organisation to sell or supply any goods or services, to carry on or to solicit for any business at a Federal Airport, a lease, licence or authority must first be granted under the Federal Airports Corporation Act.

(3) Car rental operators on airports cater for both `walk-up' and `pre-booked' clients. In the development of the Corporation's National Car Rental Policy, which involved extensive consultation with the whole of the car rental industry, these two distinct activities became inseparable.

In respect of accommodation and tour operators, i.e. hotel courtesy buses and coach operators, the Corporation accepts that there is little difference between them and car rental operators meeting pre-booked clients on the airports. Accordingly the Corporation has commenced a Ground Transportation Study that will review the operation of all landside transportation including the provision of infrastructure and the appropriateness of charging these other operators fees for their use of the airports.
The car rental industry was advised of this study in May 1993 and that it may be some time before the review is completed "given the enormity of the task".

For historical reasons most other operators are not charged fees, however this does not accord with the practice in many overseas countries. A limited number of these other operators have been issued with authorities to trade at Federal Airports Corporation airports, however at this stage only a small number are being asked to pay a fee.
(4) The FAC, following further consultation with the Trade Practices Commission.

(5) The Prices Surveillance Authority stated `it may be that these fees simply reflect use of the FAC's market power in the ownership and provision of airports'. The Federal Airports Corporation disagrees with this statement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) In which countries are: (a) tour operators; (b) accommodation providers; (c) taxis; (d) car rental operators; and (e) bus services, levied a charge for meeting customers at airports.
(2) What plans does the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) have to charge taxi companies for conducting business at FAC controlled airports.
(3) If there are no plans to levy taxis, why are car rental operators being pressured into signing contracts that impose charges for meeting pre-booked customers at airports.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)-(e) In most countries in the world, especially throughout Europe, Asia and North America, tour operators, accommodation providers, taxis, car rental operators, and bus services are levied a charge for meeting customers at airports.
A detailed survey will be undertaken as part of a current ground transportation study to confirm the extent of this practice.

(2) The FAC has commenced a Ground Transportation Study that will review the operation of all landside transportation. This includes the provision of infrastructure and the appropriateness of charging taxi companies for conducting business at its airports. As advised to the car rental industry in May 1993, it may be some time before the review is completed `given the enormity of the task'.
(3) See (2) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Embassy in Cambodia been closed for 18 years.
(2) During this period, have two residences been let.
(3) What is the total sum collected for rental during that period.
(4) Is it a fact that there is only $20,000 in the trust account when rental income has been earned for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question with respect to Cambodian Embassy's residences in Canberra is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Cambodian Embassy in Canberra has been closed since 1975 following the overthrow of the Government of Khmer Republic.

(2) For the first eleven years following the closure of the Cambodian Embassy (1975 to 1986) two residences belonging to the Cambodian Government were left vacant. In December 1985 the then Minister of Foreign Affairs authorised the leasing of these residences. The Melbourne Avenue residence was first leased on 7 April 1986 and the Canterbury Crescent residence was let on 14 July 1986.

(4) As of the 5 November 1993 the trust account has a credit balance of $28,109.29. The rental funds were used to pay for: preparing the residences for occupancy after eleven years of vacancy; rates and taxes including arrears back to 1975; real estate agent management fees; and ongoing maintenance and upkeep of these residences.
